TITLE: How much humanitarian aid is getting into Gaza? The exact answer can be hard to know
SUMMARY: The need for humanitarian aid in Gaza is enormous, but trying to decipher how much aid is getting into the territory and where it's going can be tricky.

TITLE: Alabama's largest hospital says it is halting IVF treatments in wake of court ruling
SUMMARY: Fertility clinics in Alabama are contemplating next steps after the state Supreme Court ruled that frozen fertilized eggs are children — and discarding them would be a crime.

TITLE: Federal appeals court revokes Obama-era ban on coal leasing
SUMMARY: A U.S. appeals court struck down a judge's 2022 order that imposed a moratorium on coal leasing on federal lands.

TITLE: Hydeia Broadbent, a prominent HIV/AIDS activist, dies at 39
SUMMARY: Broadbent, diagnosed at age 3, was one of the first generation of children born HIV positive, and known for raising awareness to lessen the stigma of the disease from a young age. She died Tuesday.

TITLE: A girl dies after a sand hole on a Florida beach collapses
SUMMARY: The collapse of a sand hole that killed a 7-year-old Indiana girl who was digging with her brother on a Florida beach is a danger that kills and injures several children a year around the country.

TITLE: Alabama seeks to carry out 2nd execution using controversial nitrogen gas method
SUMMARY: Alabama Attorney General Steve Marshall's office asked the state Supreme Court on Wednesday to set an execution date for Alan Eugene Miller. The state said the execution would use nitrogen.

TITLE: A man shot dead in Spain may be a Russian army defector
SUMMARY: A man who was shot dead in the region of Alicante, in Spain, is believed to be Maksim Kuzminov, a Russian helicopter pilot who defected to Ukraine last year.

TITLE: China says it plans to send more pandas to the San Diego Zoo this year
SUMMARY: In November, Chinese President Xi Jinping raised hopes his country would start sending pandas to the U.S. again after he and President Joe Biden convened in Northern California.

TITLE: Scientists scanning the seafloor discover a long-lost Stone Age 'megastructure'
SUMMARY: The more than half mile long wall, called the Blinkerwall, was likely used by Stone Age hunter-gatherers to herd reindeer toward a shooting blind.

TITLE: How the dead serve as bargaining chips in the Israel-Hamas conflict
SUMMARY: Israel and Hamas are both holding the bodies of those killed on the other side, refusing to release them. They've done so for years and are again using the enemy dead as leverage in the current war.

TITLE: Feast your eyes on Taiwan's distinct food (and understand a history of colonization)
SUMMARY: Taiwan has endured a long history of colonization. As a trip to the culinary center of Tainan reveals, those outside forces have helped create a cuisine that is distinctly Taiwanese.

TITLE: What GOP infighting in South Carolina can (and can't) tell us about 2024
SUMMARY: In Horry County, South Carolina, a squabble over who is the official county party sheds light on struggles the GOP faces more broadly in 2024.

TITLE: Nikki Haley says Biden is 'more dangerous' than Trump but neither is fit for the job
SUMMARY: In an interview with NPR, Nikki Haley says in a rematch between President Biden and former President Donald Trump, Biden is a bigger threat. But she's hoping she presents voters with another option.

TITLE: Private company Intuitive Machines is set to land on the moon. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: The Houston-based company hopes to make the first successful commercial landing on the lunar surface. It would also be America's first soft landing in decades.

TITLE: What fighting in the Middle East means for the U.S. troop presence in Iraq
SUMMARY: After the U.S. killed a commander of an Iran-backed militia in Baghdad, pressure is mounting on Iraq's government to expel America's 2,500 military personnel.

TITLE: A hospital is suing to move a quadriplegic 18-year-old to a nursing home. She says no
SUMMARY: The young North Carolina woman has refused to go to a nursing home in another state. While she wants to leave the hospital, she asks to live in her own home, close to family and her school.

TITLE: Sen. Joe Manchin on why he can't endorse Trump, but isn't sold on Biden
SUMMARY: West Virginia Democratic Sen. Joe Manchin talks to NPR's Michel Martin about Joe Biden, Donald Trump and Nikki Haley, and his decisions against another run for the Senate or a new bid for president.

TITLE: They came to clinics in Mexico for cosmetic surgery and got a deadly fungal meningitis
SUMMARY: The risks of medical tourism are depicted in a study of U.S patients who traveled to two clinics for procedures like tummy tucks and butt lifts — and were exposed to a virulent fungal meningitis.

TITLE: Haley says Biden is 'more dangerous' than Trump; Boeing ousts head of 737 Max program
SUMMARY: In an interview with NPR, Nikki Haley says in a rematch between Biden and Trump, Biden is a bigger threat. Boeing has removed the executive in charge of the troubled Boeing 373 program.

TITLE: Delta's special total solar eclipse flight sold out in 24 hours
SUMMARY: An Austin, Texas-to-Detroit flight along April's path of totality is sold out. There are other flights with a view, though your best bet may actually be here on Earth, says one astrophysicist.

TITLE: Some USDA programs have been mired in inequity. A panel's final report offers changes
SUMMARY: An equity commission created by the U.S. Department of Agriculture has released over 60 recommendations it says will finally bring more fairness to policies affecting farming and rural America.

TITLE: AT&T outage disrupts some 911 calls as tens of thousands lose service
SUMMARY: Reports of outages spiked around 3:30 a.m. ET, reaching more than 71,000 within a few hours. AT&T says it is aware of the problem and "working urgently to restore service."

TITLE: Leaked document trove shows a Chinese hacking scheme focused on harassing dissidents
SUMMARY: The large cache of more than 500 documents posted online anonymously last week details one Chinese tech company's hacking operations, target lists and marketing materials for the Chinese government.

TITLE: How Trump's trials for 91 felony charges in 4 states could take over his campaign
SUMMARY: <em>New York Times

TITLE: Biden and Haley spar over abortion after Alabama court rules embryos are 'children'
SUMMARY: Nikki Haley seemed to side with the Alabama court's decision, telling NBC News, "Embryos, to me, are babies." President Biden has seized the opportunity to call for enshrining<em> Roe

TITLE: Soccer star Dani Alves is found guilty of rape and sentenced to 4 1/2 years in prison
SUMMARY: Dani Alves, one of the most successful soccer players of his generation, was found guilty of raping a woman in a Barcelona nightclub in 2022.

TITLE: Guinness World Records posthumously strips Bobi of his title of 'oldest dog ever'
SUMMARY: Bobi's owner said the dog had lived a record-breaking 31 years and 165 days old when he died in October 2023. But a review by Guinness World Records found that evidence of his age was inconclusive.

TITLE: Boredom Followed By Unexpected Tragedy: A Ukrainian Soldier's Life At War
SUMMARY:
Quote – "The fight is here; I need ammunition, not a ride." That statement, from Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelensky to the U-S Embassy, came two days after Russian missiles began raining down on his country two years ago.

After weeks of speculation and warnings Russian President Vladimir Putin had declared war.

Fueled by grit, patriotism and billions of dollars from the US, Ukraine has waged a fight no one expected they could. But nearly two years in that could be changing.

US aid is stuck in Congress. This week, Russian forces captured their first city in 9 months. And that plea Zelensky made for ammunition in February 2022 – he's still making it.

Ukraine has waged a war against Russia that has exceeded expectations. Can it continue to stand up to Russia if western aid doesn't come through?

We get the view from the battlefield from a Ukrainian writer turned soldier.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Wendy Williams is diagnosed with aphasia and frontotemporal dementia
SUMMARY: News of the former TV host's medical diagnosis comes days ahead of the TV premiere of <em>Where is Wendy Williams?

TITLE: AT&T says cell service is back after a widespread outage and some disrupted 911 calls
SUMMARY: Reports of outages spiked around 3:30 a.m. ET Thursday, affecting more than 71,000 customers within a few hours. The FBI says it has been in contact with AT&T about the disruptions.

TITLE: Meet RDDT: Popular social platform Reddit to sell stock in an unusual IPO
SUMMARY: Reddit's IPO will be the first time since 2019 that a social media company has premiered on the stock market.

TITLE: 4 charged in transporting suspected Iranian-made weapons on boat intercepted by U.S.
SUMMARY: The criminal complaint alleges the defendants were transporting missile components for the type of weapons used by Houthi rebel forces in recent attacks. Two Navy SEALs died during the mission.

TITLE: Didn't get a Valentine's love song? These skywalker gibbons sing love duets
SUMMARY:
In the green tree canopies of forested areas in Myanmar, you might wake up to the sounds of gibbons singing love songs. Gibbons start their day with passionate duets and, though these love songs may sound a little different than the ones in your playlists, they just helped researchers figure out that Myanmar has the largest population of an endangered gibbon species on Earth. They're called skywalker gibbons, and until recently, scientists thought there were fewer than 200 of them – all living in southwestern China.

Want to hear us cover more animal news? Email the show at shortwave@npr.org to let us know!

TITLE: University of Georgia says it cancels classes after a woman is found dead on campus
SUMMARY: The person was found unconscious and with injuries near the university's intramural sports field. They were a student at another university, though police have not yet said where.

TITLE: A fire in the Spanish city of Valencia has killed at least 4 people
SUMMARY: A fire engulfed two residential buildings in the eastern Spanish city of Valencia on Thursday. At least a dozen people are missing hours after the blaze started, authorities said.

TITLE: Haley and Trump face off soon in South Carolina. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump is heavily favored, but Nikki Haley is trying hard to overcome the odds in her home state. Let's look at the keys to winning Saturday's primary and how it all works.

TITLE: Clues to a better understanding of chronic fatigue syndrome emerge from major study
SUMMARY: After seven years of research, the findings shed light on the long-neglected illness. Scientists say the results could lead to future trials for potential treatments.

TITLE: Biden officials keep states waiting on expanding Medicaid voter registration
SUMMARY: Officials in Oregon, Colorado and other states are waiting for Biden officials to approve plans to automatically register hundreds of thousands of eligible voters when they apply for Medicaid.

TITLE: Hybrid workers: How's the office these days? We want to hear from you
SUMMARY: All over the world, companies have settled on hybrid schedules for their employees. We're eager to hear how that's changing the office experience.

TITLE: Trump sells sneakers and Beyoncé is a country star. Is this the quiz or 2024 bingo?
SUMMARY: This week, the quiz gods bestowed upon us topics that led to several rewarding internet rabbit holes. Join us on our weekly news excursion and weird detours.

TITLE: Rep. Jim Clyburn on the future of the Democratic Party and his legacy
SUMMARY: <em>Morning Edition

TITLE: We fell down internet rabbit holes creating this week's quiz. You should join us
SUMMARY: Trump's golden sneakers turned up a rich history of political footwear debacles. And we learned about ring kissing, presidential auctions and reality shows set on other planets.

TITLE: What Tucker Carlson's interview with Vladimir Putin shows, and what it hides
SUMMARY: Tucker Carlson did not ask Putin about how so many of his opponents wind up imprisoned and murdered, or the warrant the International Criminal Court has out for his arrest for war crimes in Ukraine.

TITLE: The Science of IVF: What to know about Alabama's 'extrauterine children' ruling
SUMMARY: Why are so many frozen embryos created? And how is the Alabama Supreme Court ruling likely to affect IVF in the future? Here's what you need to know.

TITLE: China relies on Red Sea shipping, but its response to Houthi ship attacks is muted
SUMMARY: China's charting its own course, distancing itself from the U.S. in the Middle East, refusing to condemn the Houthis and looking to capitalize on ties with regional players to help solve the crisis.

TITLE: Hey, guys, wanna know how to diaper a baby or make a ponytail? Try the School for Men
SUMMARY: An innovative program in Colombia gives men a chance to master the skills needed to be a hands-on dad — and become closer to their kids along the way.

TITLE: Photographing Ukraine's deep scars, two years into a war without an end in sight
SUMMARY: On the second anniversary of Russia's full-scale invasion, NPR photographer Claire Harbage shares her experiences of covering the ongoing war in Ukraine.

TITLE: Alabama lawmakers move to protect IVF; massive leak reveals Chinese hacking operations
SUMMARY: Alabama lawmakers propose bills to clarify the state Supreme Court's ruling that frozen embryos are "children." Leaked documents show a Chinese company's hacking operations for the Chinese government.

TITLE: Biden announces over 500 new sanctions for Russia's war in Ukraine and Navalny death
SUMMARY: President Biden has announced more than 500 new sanctions over Russia's war in Ukraine and the death of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny.

TITLE: The science of IVF: What to know about Alabama's 'extrauterine children' ruling
SUMMARY: Why are so many frozen embryos created? And how is the Alabama Supreme Court ruling likely to affect IVF in the future? Here's what you need to know.

TITLE: China is mostly quiet on Houthi attacks in the Red Sea
SUMMARY: China's charting its own course, distancing itself from the U.S. in the Middle East, refusing to condemn the Houthis and looking to capitalize on ties with regional players to help solve the crisis.

TITLE: Negotiators are working on an Israel-Hamas cease-fire deal. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: lsrael is sending a delegation to Paris Friday to meet with officials from the U.S., Qatar and Egypt to discuss the latest outlines of a potential deal for a pause in the fighting in Gaza.

TITLE: Clues to a better understanding of chronic fatigue syndrome emerge from a major study
SUMMARY: After seven years of research, the findings shed light on the long-neglected illness. Scientists say the results could lead to future trials for potential treatments.

TITLE: Paleontologists discover a 240-million-year-old 'dragon' fossil in full
SUMMARY: <em>Dinocephalosaurus orientalis's

TITLE: Cezanne seascape mural discovered at artist's childhood home
SUMMARY: The previously unknown artwork discovered during renovations at the Cezanne family home in Aix-en-Provence, France, expands knowledge of the artist's development.

TITLE: Photographing Ukraine's deep scars, 2 years into a war without an end in sight
SUMMARY: On the second anniversary of Russia's full-scale invasion, NPR photographer Claire Harbage shares her experiences of covering the ongoing war in Ukraine.

TITLE: Senate GOP campaign arm urges candidates to back IVF after Alabama court ruling
SUMMARY: Concerned Republicans are pointing to polling that shows an overwhelming majority of voters support access to fertility treatments. Reproductive rights are a leading issue in congressional races.

TITLE: Haley launching '7-figure' ad buy, signaling she's staying in through Super Tuesday
SUMMARY: The Haley campaign told reporters Friday that she is continuing on, arguing that doing so is not just about the nomination but making a case that Trump will struggle in a general election.

TITLE: Trump and Haley face off soon in South Carolina. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump is heavily favored, but Nikki Haley is trying hard to overcome the odds in her home state. Let's look at the keys to winning Saturday's primary and how it all works.

TITLE: Why MLB's new uniforms are getting mixed reviews
SUMMARY: The new Nike-designed MLB uniforms have received mixed reviews from players, with some calling them comfortable to others saying they look cheap.

TITLE: Biden is looking at options for the border. But he's running into legal issues
SUMMARY: President Biden told governors that he's looking for ways to take executive action to reduce the number of migrants crossing the southern border — but he's limited by laws and lack of funding.

TITLE: Jury finds NRA, Wayne LaPierre liable in civil corruption case
SUMMARY: Top executives for the gun rights nonprofit were accused of using millions in NRA donations for private luxuries.  A jury found former CEO Wayne LaPierre liable for more than $5.4 million in damages.

TITLE: N.Y.'s crusading attorney general wins again with NRA verdict, Trump judgment
SUMMARY: New York Attorney General Letitia James has built a reputation targeting powerful national figures. Critics say her lawsuits are politically motivated, but she keeps winning in court.

TITLE: U.S. lunar lander is on its side with some antennas covered up, the company says
SUMMARY: Odysseus — the first U.S. lander in over 50 years — tipped over at touchdown and ended up on its side near the moon's south pole, hampering communications, Intuitive Machines officials said Friday.

TITLE: Man guilty of killing transgender woman in hate crime trial over gender identity
SUMMARY: It was the United States' first federal trial over an alleged hate crime based on gender identity. There have been hate crime prosecutions based on gender identity before, but none had reached trial.

TITLE: Here are South Carolina's 2024 Republican presidential primary results
SUMMARY: Voting concludes Saturday in South Carolina's Republican presidential primary election. Polls open at 7 a.m. ET and close at 7 p.m. ET. Follow the results live.

TITLE: 8 people killed in a head-on crash in central California farming region
SUMMARY: Seven farmworkers traveling in a van and the driver of a pickup truck were killed Friday in a head-on crash in a farming area in central California, police said.

TITLE: China is mostly quiet on Houthi attacks in the Red Sea
SUMMARY: China's charting its own course, distancing itself from the U.S. in the Middle East, refusing to condemn the Houthis and looking to capitalize on ties with regional players to help solve the crisis.

TITLE: Man guilty of killing transgender woman in hate crime trial over gender identity
SUMMARY: It was the United States' first federal trial over an alleged hate crime based on gender identity. There have been hate crime prosecutions based on gender identity before, but none had reached trial.

TITLE: A Gaza influencer built a following with feel-good videos. Now he mourns his family
SUMMARY: The Instagram influencer known as Kazanova built an audience of 440,000 followers with positive videos to lift spirits in Gaza. Most of his family was killed in an Israeli hostage rescue operation.

TITLE: After 2 years of war in Ukraine, 6 cities hold out hope under fire
SUMMARY: In the 80% of Ukraine that remains in Kyiv's hands, two years of full-scale war with Russia have brought grief, destruction and, despite all, optimism.

TITLE: In Nikki Haley's hometown, support is strong. But that doesn't mean she'll win
SUMMARY: Former South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley is struggling in her home state's Republican primary polls, but residents say she has broad support in her hometown of Bamberg.

TITLE: Voting in South Carolina's all-important Republican presidential primary ends today
SUMMARY: Former U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley faces a critical election today in her bid for the GOP presidential nomination in her home state of South Carolina.

TITLE: Flaco, the beloved New York owl, died after colliding with a building
SUMMARY: Flaco, who fled the Central Park Zoo, thrived in New York City on his own for about a year before his death.

TITLE: Alexei Navalny's body has been handed over to his mother, an aide says
SUMMARY: The director of Navalny's Anti-Corruption Foundation thanked "everyone" who had called on Russian authorities to return the Russian opposition leader's body to his mother.

TITLE: Haley calls Trump's 'disgusting' comments about Black people a 'huge warning sign'
SUMMARY: Nikki Haley says inflammatory comments Donald Trump made about Black people Friday is more proof he will hurt the GOP in the November general election.

TITLE: 'A fabulous ambassador' Flaco, the beloved New York owl, died after building collision
SUMMARY: Flaco, who fled the Central Park Zoo, thrived in New York City on his own for about a year before his death.

TITLE: Trying to eat more protein to help build strength? Share your diet tips and recipes
SUMMARY: What do you eat to support muscle strength? NPR is reporting on diet and strength-building and we'd love to hear your suggestions for protein-rich snacks and meals.

TITLE: Putin remains defiant as ever 2 years into Russia's war in Ukraine
SUMMARY: The Russian leader had a busy week, one that saw him exude confidence about Russia's military and economic resilience as Ukraine has increasingly struggled on the battlefield.

TITLE: Polls closing soon in S.C.'s GOP primary as Trump takes on Haley in her home state
SUMMARY: Former U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley faces a critical election today in her bid for the GOP presidential nomination in her home state of South Carolina.

TITLE: The U.S. and Britain carry out strikes on 18 Houthi targets in Yemen
SUMMARY: The strikes targeted eight locations in Yemen that included missile storage and air defense systems, officials said.

TITLE: Cuban cabaret artist Juana Bacallao dies at 98
SUMMARY: The legendary nightclub singer died Saturday in her hometown of Havana, according to a statement on social media from Cuba's Ministry of Culture.

TITLE: Trump wins South Carolina's GOP primary, beating Haley in her home state
SUMMARY: Former U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley faced a critical election in her bid for the GOP presidential nomination in her home state of South Carolina. The race call came moments after polls closed.

TITLE: They say you can't go home again. Nikki Haley can but it doesn't guarantee votes
SUMMARY: Former South Carolina Gov. Nikki Haley is struggling in her home state's Republican primary polls, but residents say she has broad support in her hometown of Bamberg.

TITLE: Trump wins South Carolina's GOP primary as Haley vows to stay in the race
SUMMARY: The former president has now won every contest where he was on the ballot. For Nikki Haley, the loss in her home state is a major blow to her bid for the GOP nomination.

TITLE: Oppenheimer movie dominates SAG Awards, while Streisand wins lifetime prize
SUMMARY: Oppenheimer dominated at the Screen Actors Guild (SAG) Awards on Saturday, as several winners paid tribute to last year's actors' strike. Barbra Streisand was given a lifetime achievement prize.

TITLE: What could Biden's Israel-Gaza stance mean for his campaign? Michigan is an early test
SUMMARY: Some Arab American, Muslim and young voters in the Detroit area plan to vote "uncommitted" in Tuesday's primary. They want to send a message to Biden: Call for a ceasefire or lose us in November.

TITLE: A new home for the African diaspora in Ghana stirs tensions
SUMMARY: Ghana tried to create a haven for anyone from across the African diaspora. But for some Ghanaians, the project has become a source of bitterness.

TITLE: Series of recent DOJ cases show foreign operatives plotting assassinations in U.S.
SUMMARY: State-sponsored assassination plots on U.S. soil may sound like the stuff of movies, but the Department of Justice says it has foiled four such cases since 2022.

TITLE: I'm a Ukrainian journalist. I never expected to be a war reporter in my own country
SUMMARY: Polina Lytvynova, an NPR producer in Ukraine, reflects on the changes two years of war with Russia have brought to her country — and to her work as a journalist.

TITLE: Jake Sullivan says U.S., Israel have agreed to 'basic contours' of a cease-fire deal
SUMMARY: It's unclear whether Hamas would also sign on. The White House national security adviser also called on Republicans in Congress to approve more military aid to Ukraine.

TITLE: Decade's old missing person case solved after relative uploads DNA to genealogy site
SUMMARY: Sandra Young was between 16 and 18 years old when she went missing in the late 1960s. Police in Oregon say an upload to the genealogy database GEDMatch helped them identify her remains.

TITLE: A man set himself on fire outside Israeli Embassy in D.C., now in critical condition
SUMMARY: Local police say the man has been taken to the hospital with "critical life threatening injuries."

TITLE: "De-influencers" Ring The Alarm On The Environmental Impacts Of Overconsumption
SUMMARY:
In the last few years, a new trend has emerged on social media: De-influencers.

Instead of selling, de-influencers encourage their followers to stop buying things they don't actually need. De-influencers are also using this trend as an opportunity to raise awareness about the negative impact of overconsumption on the environment.

From plastic packaging to useless gadgets that end up in landfills, over-consumption doesn't just have a negative effect on our wallets - but also on our planet and climate change.

We look at what role can de-influencers play in helping address climate change and spreading the message of sustainable living.

TITLE: 31,000 Ukrainian troops have been killed so far in the war, Zelenskyy says
SUMMARY: It's the first time Ukraine has publicly given a figure for military casualties. As Russia's war on Ukraine enters its third year, Zelenskyy says 2024 could be decisive.

TITLE: Decades-old missing person case solved after relative uploads DNA to genealogy site
SUMMARY: Sandra Young was between 16 and 18 years old when she went missing in the late 1960s. Police in Oregon say an upload to the genealogy database GEDMatch helped them identify her remains.

SUMMARY: The influential Koch network of conservative megadonors announced it will no longer be spending its resources on Haley's presidential bid, saying no outside group can "widen her path to victory."

TITLE: Haley calls Trump's 'disgusting' comments about Black people a 'huge warning sign'

TITLE: Conservative megadonors Koch not funding Haley anymore as she continues longshot bid
SUMMARY: The influential Koch network of conservative megadonors announced it will no longer be spending its resources on Haley's presidential bid, saying no outside group can "widen her path to victory."

TITLE: A man set himself on fire outside Israeli Embassy in D.C.
SUMMARY: Local police say the man has been taken to the hospital with "critical life threatening injuries." The Air Force said the man was an active duty airman.

TITLE: AT&T will give $5 to customers hit by cellphone network outage
SUMMARY: The Dallas-based company said on its website that customers will get the $5 credit on their account within two billing cycles. The credit does not apply to AT&T Business, prepaid service or Cricket.

TITLE: Vigils held nationwide for nonbinary Oklahoma teen who died following school fight
SUMMARY: Nex Benedict, a 16-year-old who identified as nonbinary, got into an altercation with three girls in an Owasso High School bathroom who were picking on Benedict and some friends.

TITLE: Tuvalu names Feleti Teo as its new prime minister
SUMMARY: The nation's former attorney general was named prime minister of the tiny South Pacific nation Monday. It was not immediately clear how the new government will affect China's influence in the country.

TITLE: Why do we leap day? We remind you (so you can forget for another 4 years)
SUMMARY: Why do we have leap years, and what are we supposed to do — or not do — with our rare extra day? NPR's <em>Morning Edition

TITLE: Why Egypt won't allow vulnerable Palestinians across its border
SUMMARY: Egypt's empty Sinai Peninsula would offer safety for Palestinian civilians. But Egypt fears refugees might never be allowed back, citing the painful history of earlier Israeli-Palestinian wars.

TITLE: This is what happens when a wind farm comes to a coal town
SUMMARY: Keyser in West Virginia represents a national shift in American energy production. And in a town that was defined by coal for generations, change can be difficult.

TITLE: What could Biden's Israel-Gaza stand mean for his campaign? Michigan is an early test
SUMMARY: Some Arab American, Muslim and young voters in the Detroit area plan to vote "uncommitted" in Tuesday's primary. They want to send a message to Biden: Call for a cease-fire or lose us in November.

TITLE: Michigan's elections chief wants to protect voters, poll workers and democracy itself
SUMMARY: Michigan Secretary of State Jocelyn Benson sat down with <em>Morning Edition

TITLE: Gaza cease-fire talks inch forward; Supreme Court hears social media censorship case
SUMMARY: Negotiators are inching toward another cease-fire deal in Gaza, even as Netanyahu vows to move troops into Rafah. The Supreme Court hears a case that could define the internet's future.

TITLE: RNC Chair Ronna McDaniel says she'll step down March 8
SUMMARY: The decision is not a surprise. McDaniel previously said she'd step down after the South Carolina primary, which was held Saturday.

TITLE: Poland's judiciary was a tool of its government. New leaders are trying to undo that
SUMMARY: Poland's far-right Law and Justice party spent eight years stacking the courts with allies, destroying the judiciary's independence. The new government is finding it's tough to undo the damage.

TITLE: Raising a child with autism in Kenya: Facing stigma, finding glimmers of hope
SUMMARY: In Africa, there is a shortage of specialists and a lack of financial support for famlies who can't afford therapy. We look at how three families are coping.

TITLE: The Supreme Court will hear challenges to Texas and Florida social media laws
SUMMARY: These cases raise a critical question for the First Amendment and the future of social media: whether states can force the platforms to carry content they find hateful or objectionable.

TITLE: U.S. airman dies after setting himself on fire outside the Israeli Embassy
SUMMARY: Police in Washington, D.C., identified the active duty member of the U.S. Air Force as 25-year-old Aaron Bushnell of San Antonio, Texas. He was rushed to the hospital Sunday with serious injuries.

TITLE: Hungary approved Sweden's bid to join NATO, the final hurdle to membership
SUMMARY: Hungary's parliament has approved Sweden's bid to join NATO, clearing the way for the Nordic nation's accession to the military alliance after two years of intense negotiations.

TITLE: FTC and 9 states sue to block Kroger-Albertsons supermarket merger
SUMMARY: The Federal Trade Commission and 9 states want to stop the deal that would combine the country's two largest grocery store chains. The companies say they have to merge to compete with Walmart.

TITLE: When is forgetting normal — and when is it worrisome? A neuroscientist weighs in
SUMMARY: Charan Ranganath recently wrote an op-ed about President Biden's memory gaffes. He says forgetting is a normal part of aging. His new book is <em>Why We Remember

TITLE: A Navalny associate says he was about to be swapped for a Russian prisoner in Germany
SUMMARY: An associate of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny says in a video statement talks were underway shortly before his death to exchange him for a Russian imprisoned in Germany.

TITLE: Photos: Humanitarian crisis grows in Gaza as mediation attempts resume
SUMMARY: In the past week, the number of people displaced in Gaza reached 1.7 million, Egypt fears a border crisis in the Sinai Peninsula and negotiators began work toward a potential pause in the fighting.

TITLE: Hungary has approved Sweden's bid to join NATO, the final hurdle to membership
SUMMARY: Hungary's parliament has approved Sweden's bid to join NATO, clearing the way for the Nordic nation's accession to the military alliance after two years of intense negotiations.

TITLE: With or without a cease-fire, Netanyahu says Israeli operation in Rafah will happen
SUMMARY: As talks over a cease-fire in Gaza continue, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu said his cabinet was reviewing military plans for Rafah, where more than a million Palestinians are sheltering.

TITLE: Navalny was about to be swapped for a Russian prisoner in Germany, an associate says
SUMMARY: An associate of Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny says in a video statement talks were underway shortly before his death to exchange him for a Russian imprisoned in Germany.

TITLE: Supreme Court justices appears skeptical of Texas and Florida social media laws
SUMMARY: These cases raise a critical question for the First Amendment and the future of social media: whether states can force the platforms to carry content they find hateful or objectionable.

TITLE: Biden says there could be a cease-fire in Gaza by Monday. Talks are still ongoing
SUMMARY: Negotiators have been trying to reach a deal on a temporary cease-fire to to move hostages held in Gaza out of the territory. President Biden says he's optimistic the cease-fire could begin in a week.

TITLE: Supreme Court justices appear skeptical of Texas and Florida social media laws
SUMMARY: These cases raise a critical question for the First Amendment and the future of social media: whether states can force the platforms to carry content they find hateful or objectionable.

TITLE: Tuition will be free at a New York City medical school thanks to a $1 billion gift
SUMMARY: Ruth Gottesman is a professor emerita of pediatrics at the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in New York City. Gottesman's late husband, David, left the money to her upon his death.

TITLE: Here are Michigan's 2024 presidential primary results
SUMMARY: Voting concludes Tuesday in Michigan's presidential primaries. Follow the results live.

TITLE: Pedestrian deaths fell modestly last year, but there's still a safety 'crisis'
SUMMARY: The number of pedestrians killed on U.S. roads declined by 4% in the first half of last year, according to preliminary estimates. But pedestrian fatality numbers are still far above their 2019 levels.

TITLE: Odysseus moon lander will cease working after sideways landing
SUMMARY: Intuitive Machines, the company that built and flew the spacecraft, said it will continue to collect data until sunlight no longer shines on the solar panels, expected to happen Tuesday morning.

TITLE: Donald Trump appeals $454 million judgment in New York civil fraud case
SUMMARY: The former president's lawyers filed notices of appeal Monday asking the state's mid-level appeals court to overturn the Feb. 16 verdict and reverse penalties that threaten Trump's cash reserves.

TITLE: On primary day, young Michigan voters are leading call to be 'uncommitted' to Biden
SUMMARY: The campaign to check "Uncommitted" on the Michigan Democratic primary ballot has gained nationwide attention. At its center are the next generation of activists, leaders and voters.

TITLE: The rate of antidepressants prescribed to young people surged during the pandemic
SUMMARY: Researchers analyzed a sample of about 221 million prescriptions from 2016 to 2022, in Americans between the ages of 12 and 25. The increase was prominent among young women and girls.

TITLE: Can a preposition be what you end a sentence with? Merriam-Webster says yes
SUMMARY: The dictionary publisher's guidance on the practice has people riled up. Grammarians say the made-up rule is one big waste of time. Not everyone is ready to let it go.

TITLE: Have you been financially impacted by a weather disaster? Tell us about it
SUMMARY: Have you experienced financial trouble after a flood, wildfire, hurricane or heat wave? NPR's Climate Desk wants to hear about it.

TITLE: Michigan Democrats and Republicans wrap up their presidential primaries today
SUMMARY: Both President Biden and former President Donald Trump are vying for their party's delegates. Neither contest is expected to be competitive even though the state will be key in the general election.

TITLE: A stranger jumped into action when a 92-year-old started to be dragged by a car
SUMMARY: When Ben Gomes got a call saying that his mother was badly injured, he feared the worst. But when he arrived at the hospital, he learned how a stranger's quick thinking had saved her.

TITLE: Alabama justice's ties with far-right Christian movement raise concern
SUMMARY: In the days after Alabama's Supreme Court deemed frozen embryos to be "extrauterine children," the chief justice's ties to a movement that experts call "Christian extremist" have come to light.

TITLE: A child's dream to 'drive' a space shuttle propels him toward a historic NASA mission
SUMMARY: Navy Capt. Victor Glover, who spent nearly six months aboard the International Space Station, will be among four astronauts to venture back to the moon for the first time since 1972.

TITLE: Debt, missed classes and anxiety: how climate-driven disasters hurt college students
SUMMARY: Floods, wildfires and hurricanes can have long-term financial consequences for college-age people. As climate change makes disasters more common, more and more students are struggling.

TITLE: Young Michigan voters are 'uncommitted' to Biden; U.S. airman dies of self-immolation
SUMMARY: Michigan voters critical of Biden's support of Israel call on people to vote "uncommitted" in the state's primary. An Oxford scholar explains the history of self-immolation as political protest.

TITLE: There's a cheap and effective way to treat childhood diarrhea. So why is it underused?
SUMMARY: A new study seeks to find the reasons that health-care personnel avoid the easy treatment for this potentially life-threatening condition.

TITLE: Merriam-Webster says you can end a sentence with a preposition. The internet goes off
SUMMARY: The dictionary publisher's guidance on the practice has people riled up. Grammarians say the made-up rule is one big waste of time. Not everyone is ready to let it go.

TITLE: A stranger jumped into action when a 92-year-old started to get dragged by a car
SUMMARY: When Ben Gomes got a call saying his mother was badly injured, he feared the worst. But when he arrived at the hospital, he learned how a stranger's quick thinking had saved her.

TITLE: Debt, missed classes and anxiety: How climate-driven disasters hurt college students
SUMMARY: Floods, wildfires and hurricanes can have long-term financial consequences for college-age people. As climate change makes disasters more common, more and more students are struggling.

TITLE: Why Macy's is closing 150 department stores
SUMMARY: The new CEO is culling "underproductive" locations, while opening more upscale Bloomingdale's and Bluemercury stores. Here's what's happening with the chain.

TITLE: Could IVF access be protected nationally? One senator has a plan
SUMMARY: Senator Tammy Duckworth has introduced a bill to protect access to IVF. She tells NPR about her own experience with fertility treatments and her attempts to build bipartisan support for her bill.

TITLE: Cameo is being used for political propaganda — by tricking the stars involved
SUMMARY: Lindsay Lohan and other celebrities were tricked into calling for the ouster of Moldova's president. It's the latest example of the Cameo app being used for an apparent political propaganda operation.

TITLE: After Alabama's ruling, this senator's bill aims to protect national access to IVF
SUMMARY: Senator Tammy Duckworth has introduced a bill to protect access to IVF. She tells NPR about her own experience with fertility treatments and her attempts to build bipartisan support for her bill.

TITLE: Congressional leaders hope to avoid a shutdown. But Ukraine aid is still unclear
SUMMARY: After tense talks in the Oval Office, congressional leaders said they were hopeful they could reach a deal to avert a partial government shutdown on Friday. But they appeared divided on Ukraine aid.

TITLE: Why self-immolation has been used by political protesters for decades
SUMMARY: Aaron Bushnell's death in Washington, D.C., is the latest example of an extreme form of protest that people have used to express their grievances and attract the attention of a global audience.

TITLE: Trying To Protect Access To IVF
SUMMARY:
The backlash to the Alabama Supreme Court ruling designating frozen embryos has been intense. Republicans at the state and national level have openly disagreed with the decision. And Democrats have used the ruling to hammer Republicans over reproductive rights.

Last month, Illinois Senator Tammy Duckworth introduced a bill to protect IVF. It hasn't gotten a lot of attention - until now.

Duckworth used IVF to build her own family, and has been warning since the Supreme Court overturned Roe v. Wade that the decision could lead to reproductive rights being challenged.

Duckworth discusses her legislation and whether she thinks republicans will support it.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: U.K. companies that tried a 4-day workweek report lasting benefits more than a year on
SUMMARY: Many of the companies are so pleased with the results — improved wellbeing, lower turnover, greater efficiency — they're making the four-day workweek permanent.

TITLE: Police suspect U.S. couple are dead after their boat was hijacked in the Caribbean
SUMMARY: The couple whose catamaran was hijacked last week by three escaped prisoners were presumed dead and likely had been thrown into the ocean, police said.

TITLE: Trump beats Nikki Haley, Joe Biden wins amid protest votes in Michigan primaries
SUMMARY: The contests in Michigan weren't expected to be competitive even though the state will be key in the general election. Biden won despite protests votes over his handling of Israel's war in Gaza.

TITLE: The push to vote 'uncommitted' to Biden in Michigan exceeds goal
SUMMARY: The group Listen to Michigan has been urging voters in the state to vote uncommitted on the Democratic ballot as a protest vote against President Biden's handling of Israel's war in Gaza.

TITLE: After 10 years of development, Apple abruptly cancels its electric car project
SUMMARY: The tech giant's sudden move took the thousands of employees working on the effort by surprise and sent a jolt to the automotive industry, which was closely watching the specter of an Apple car.

TITLE: Expanding wildfires force Texas nuclear facility to pause operations
SUMMARY: Rapidly moving Texas wildfires Tuesday prompted evacuations in small towns and shut down a nuclear facility as strong winds, dry grass and unseasonably warm temperatures fueled the blazes.

TITLE: 2 men are found guilty for the 2002 killing of Run-DMC's Jam Master Jay
SUMMARY: Jam Master Jay, one-third of the iconic hip-hop group Run-DMC, was killed in 2002 over a cocaine deal gone bad. A jury found two men guilty of the murder, including his godson.

TITLE: Idaho prepares to execute one of the longest-serving death row inmates in the U.S.
SUMMARY: Officials say Thomas Creech's spiritual advisor will be allowed to stand next to Creech with a hand on his shoulder during the scheduled Wednesday execution. Creech has been imprisoned since 1974.

TITLE: Supreme Court hears challenge to Trump-era ban on bump stocks for guns
SUMMARY: The regulation was enacted at the behest of President Trump after the shooting at a Las Vegas concert killed 60 people and injured 400 — in 11 minutes.

TITLE: In Arizona, abortion politics are already playing out on the Senate campaign trail
SUMMARY: Abortion proved to be a major issue in the 2022 midterms and again in 2023. This year, the presidential race puts extra attention on the ballot. In Arizona, that means the issue is front and center.

TITLE: A tech billionaire is quietly buying up land in Hawaii. No one knows why
SUMMARY: A mystery has been brewing in a small ranching town on Hawaii's Big Island. Word has it that Salesforce CEO Marc Benioff bought the land, stirring worries about what he plans to do with it.

TITLE: The Palestinian Authority is promising change. Many Palestinians say it's not enough
SUMMARY: The Palestinian Authority is poised for new leadership after its prime minister tendered the resignation of his cabinet. But it faces a steep climb to win back support from dissatisfied Palestinians.

TITLE: Why Taiwanese Americans are moving to Taiwan — reversing the path of their parents
SUMMARY: The 1970s-90s saw a wave of Taiwanese immigrants to the United States. Now, some of their children are moving to Taiwan — and navigating the complex feelings that go with it.

TITLE: Christian nationalism's support is strongest in rural, conservative states
SUMMARY: A new survey maps out support for Christian nationalist views state by state. Those views found most favor in conservative rural states such as Alabama and West Virginia.

TITLE: A half-century later, students at the University of Mississippi reckon with the past
SUMMARY: University of Mississippi students meet members of the school's Black Student Union from 1970. They were jailed and expelled from Ole Miss for protesting token integration.

TITLE: Michigan could help decide the presidency. But many there aren't excited to vote
SUMMARY: NPR spoke to autoworkers, college students and Black churchgoers in the Detroit area about the general election. Many aren't excited about their likely choices, with some unsure they'll vote at all.

TITLE: 'Uncommitted' voters send Biden a message on Gaza; Alabama senate moves to protect IVF
SUMMARY: Biden and Trump win Michigan's primary, but "uncommitted" voters send Biden a message about his support for Israel. Two Alabama senate bills aim to protect IVF treatments in the state.

TITLE: Many in Michigan don't know how — or whether — they'll vote in the general election
SUMMARY: NPR spoke to autoworkers, college students and Black churchgoers in the Detroit area about the general election. Many aren't excited about their likely choices, with some unsure they'll vote at all.

TITLE: How can you make the most of leap day? NPR listeners have a few ideas
SUMMARY: We get a leap day only every four years. How will you spend it? Here's some inspiration from people celebrating all sorts of personal milestones — and those who just want to enjoy their extra day.

TITLE: Biden is getting a physical. The report will be scrutinized because of his age
SUMMARY: President Biden, 81, is the oldest person ever to hold the office, and voters have expressed concern that he is too old for a second four-year term in the job.

TITLE: After months-long battle with GOP, Hunter Biden appears for impeachment testimony
SUMMARY: Hunter Biden appeared behind closed doors to provide testimony in the House GOP impeachment inquiry into his father, President Joe Biden.

TITLE: Missouri advocates gather signatures for abortion legalization, but GOP hurdle looms
SUMMARY: Missouri has one of the strictest abortion bans in the U.S. Abortion rights supporters have until May to gather over 171,000 signatures to have the issue appear before voters this fall.

TITLE: More than 330,000 Jeep Grand Cherokees are recalled to fix steering wheel issue
SUMMARY: Chrysler is recalling more than 330,00 Jeep Grand Cherokees because of a steering wheel issue that may cause drivers to lose control of their vehicles.

TITLE: No, Wendy's says it isn't planning to introduce surge pricing
SUMMARY: Questions about whether the fast food chain would hike prices during the busiest times of day came after comments made by Wendy's President and CEO Kirk Tanner during an earnings call.

TITLE: Mitch McConnell will step down as Senate minority leader in November
SUMMARY: McConnell announced his plans on the Senate floor Wednesday where he talked about waiting for a day when he would have total clarity about the end of his work. "That day arrived today."

TITLE: Florida's response to measles outbreak troubles public health experts
SUMMARY: The state has at least 10 cases of the illness to date but the state's surgeon general has not called for vaccinations or quarantining of exposed kids. This goes against science-based measures.

TITLE: Google CEO Pichai says Gemini's AI image results "offended our users"
SUMMARY: Google CEO Sundar Pichai told employees in an internal memo that the AI tool's problematic images were unacceptable. He vowed to re-release a better version of the service in the coming weeks.

TITLE: Biden just got a physical. The report will be scrutinized because of his age
SUMMARY: President Biden, 81, is the oldest person ever to hold the office, and voters have expressed concern that he is too old for a second four-year term in the job.

TITLE: The FAA gives Boeing 90 days to fix quality control issues. Critics say they run deep
SUMMARY: Boeing has 90 days to come up with a plan to fix quality control issues, the FAA said Wednesday. Critics say those problems go far beyond the door plug that blew off a 737 Max in midair last month.

TITLE: Biden just got a physical. But a cognitive test was not part of the assessment
SUMMARY: President Biden, 81, is the oldest person ever to hold the office, and voters have expressed concern that he is too old for a second four-year term in the job.

TITLE: Here's a big reason why people may be gloomy about the economy: the cost of money
SUMMARY: Former Treasury Secretary Larry Summers argues that high interest rates are contributing to people's gloomy economic mood. Sentiment may improve, though, if the Federal Reserve begins to cut rates.

TITLE: Supreme Court to hear arguments in Trump immunity case in April
SUMMARY: The order from the court Wednesday keeps Trump's prosecution in the Jan. 6 case on hold.

TITLE: Supreme Court seems torn over bump stock ban
SUMMARY: In 2018, the federal government banned bump stocks for that reason, but gun enthusiasts have challenged the regulation in court, contending that only Congress has the power to enact such a ban.

TITLE: Comedian Richard Lewis, who recently starred on 'Curb Your Enthusiasm,' dies at 76
SUMMARY: Lewis was an acclaimed comedian known for exploring his neuroses in frantic, stream-of-consciousness diatribes while dressed in all-black, leading to his nickname "The Prince of Pain."

TITLE: Congressional leaders reach a deal to avoid a government shutdown
SUMMARY: Congress will need to pass a short-term continuing resolution to extend funding deadlines in order for the longer term deal to take effect.

TITLE: Ghana's parliament passes anti-LGBTQ+ bill that could imprison people for years
SUMMARY: The bill criminalizes members of the LGBTQ+ community as well as its supporters, including promotion and funding of related activities and public displays of affection.

TITLE: Can Speaker Of The House Mike Johnson Make A Deal?
SUMMARY:
Despite a last minute agreement to push a deadline for a shutdown, Congress and the White House have to agree on how to fund the government. So far, all they've been able to do is kick the can down the road.

And conditions for making a political deal are only getting worse. Republicans can only lose two votes. And there's skepticism all around.

Finding a way out largely depends on Speaker of the House Mike Johnson, Republican of Louisiana. But Johnson has a fractious caucus, is relatively inexperienced, and shutdowns have become the political weapon of choice.

If the House leader can't find a path to a deal, the entire country could pay the price.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Older US adults should get another COVID-19 shot, health officials recommend
SUMMARY: The CDC said Americans 65 and older should get another dose of the updated vaccine that became available in September — if at least four months has passed since their last shot.

TITLE: Family Dollar is fined over $40 million due to a rodent infestation in its warehouse
SUMMARY: The Food and Drug Administration found dead and live rodents, and their feces and urine. More than 1,200 rodents were exterminated after fumigation at the warehouse, which serves more than 400 stores.

TITLE: Older U.S. adults should get another COVID-19 shot, health officials recommend
SUMMARY: The CDC said Americans 65 and older should get another dose of the updated vaccine that became available in September — if at least four months has passed since their last shot.

TITLE: Field Notes: On Reporting, the Israel-Hamas War
SUMMARY: The first in a two-part special series featuring conversations between <em>Embedded

TITLE: How genetically modified pigs could end the shortage of organs for transplants
SUMMARY: Scientists are optimistic that gene-edited animals could provide a new source of organs for transplantation. Pig organs modified to minimize rejection are now being tested in humans.

TITLE: Biden and Trump are both at the border today, staking out ground on a key 2024 issue
SUMMARY: President Biden is trying to go on the offensive on migration, an issue that is a big liability this year. He's visiting the Texas border on the same day as former President Donald Trump.

TITLE: 'Message has been received': Biden's campaign reacts to 'uncommitted' votes
SUMMARY: In Michigan, a push to encourage voters to send President Biden a message about his refusal to call for a permanent cease-fire in Gaza may have worked. Here's how his campaign moves forward.

TITLE: The Transportation Department proposes new rules for how airlines handle wheelchairs
SUMMARY: Travelers who use wheelchairs complain that airlines often damage or lose them. Now the Biden administration is proposing new standards for how airlines accommodate passengers with disabilities.

TITLE: ExxonMobil is suing investors who want faster climate action
SUMMARY: The oil and gas giant is suing investor groups that want it to slash climate pollution. Interest groups on both sides of the case say it could lead to more lawsuits against activist investors.

TITLE: Gaza's death toll now exceeds 30,000. Here's why it's an incomplete count
SUMMARY: Gaza's health ministry announced Thursday that 30,035 Palestinians have been killed in the war. A close look at how the ministry counts those killed reveals a system buckling under the weight of war.

TITLE: My daughters sold Girl Scout Cookies. Here's what I learned in the Thin Mint trenches
SUMMARY: There are no Wonka-like scenes of Tagalong rainbows and Do-si-do stools. But parents can be forgiven for feeling like Oompa Loompas — hardworking cogs in a well-oiled machine.

TITLE: SCOTUS takes on Trump immunity case; Gaza death toll surpasses 30,000
SUMMARY: The Supreme Court will hear arguments in the Trump immunity case in April. More than 30,000 people have been killed in Gaza since October.

TITLE: A story of Jewish Shanghai, told through music
SUMMARY: A fictional tale of the real-life Jewish community in Shanghai during World War II — with a cross-cultural love story at its heart — is premiering at the New York Philharmonic on Thursday.

TITLE: Virginia high school students take center stage for Black History Month celebration
SUMMARY: High school students in Alexandria, Va., honor Black history with art, dance and theater.

TITLE: Florida is releasing Jeffrey Epstein's grand jury report
SUMMARY: Jeffrey Epstein was a wealthy financier, who was charged with paying dozens of underage women over many years for sex. He died in a jail cell in 2019 while awaiting trial on sex-trafficking charges.

TITLE: Relatives in Lebanon mourn victims of Israeli strikes, including a 5-year-old girl
SUMMARY: Photographer Diego Ibarra Sánchez accompanied mourners in southern Lebanon after Israel stepped up airstrikes that claimed the lives of civilians and Hezbollah fighters.

TITLE: The human cost of climate-related disasters is acutely undercounted, new study says
SUMMARY: A new study counts the human health costs from increasingly costly and dangerous extreme weather in the U.S.

TITLE: How scientists are using facial-recognition AI to track humpback whales
SUMMARY: After being hunted for decades, humpback whales returned to the Pacific Ocean in big numbers. Now, new technology is revealing that underwater heat waves are taking a toll on that recovery.

TITLE: New York sues beef producer JBS for 'fraudulent' marketing around climate change
SUMMARY: New York state Attorney General Letitia James said the food company is misleading the public about its efforts to cut its climate pollution.

TITLE: Scores killed trying to get food from an aid convoy during a chaotic scene in Gaza
SUMMARY: Health officials in Gaza say over 100 are dead after Israeli troops fired on a crowd that was trying to pull food from the convoy. Israeli officials said the crowd had approached in a threatening way.

TITLE: Tracing the rise of Christian nationalism, from Trump to the Ala. Supreme Court
SUMMARY: Bradley Onishi is a former Christian nationalist who's now a professor of religion and the author of <em>Preparing for War,

TITLE: Jack Teixeira expected to plead guilty in documents leak case
SUMMARY: The request comes almost a year after Teixeira was arrested and charged with the illegal retention and transmission of national defense information. He originally pleaded not guilty to the charges.

TITLE: Judge skeptical of lawsuit brought by Elon Musk's X over hate speech research
SUMMARY: The nonprofit sued by Elon Musk's X says the legal tactic is an attempt to silence criticism of the company. The Center for Countering Digital Hate published reports documenting hate speech on X.

TITLE: Iowa basketball phenom Caitlin Clark plans to forgo next season and enter WNBA Draft
SUMMARY: Caitlin Clark, who is on the verge of becoming the all-time NCAA scoring leader in college basketball, announced that she will leave the Hawkeyes after this season and turn pro.

TITLE: Putin warns of nuclear war if NATO sends troops to Ukraine
SUMMARY: Russian President Vladimir Putin issued explicit nuclear threats to the West, even as he assured Russians their country could both win the war in Ukraine and thrive economically.

TITLE: McConnell Releases His Grip On Power
SUMMARY:
Here in the US, the average age of retirement is 61. Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky passed that birthday more than 20 years ago. And on Wednesday afternoon, he announced that while he still isn't ready to retire just yet, he will no longer lead Republicans in the Senate.

McConnell says he still has "enough gas" in the tank to thoroughly disappoint his critics. The soon-to-be former leader intends to serve out the rest of his term which continues through January 2027.

McConnell's Congressional career began back in 1984 when Ronald Reagan was President. The Kentucky republican has long embraced Reagan's conservatism and view of American exceptionalism.

Today's Republican party is one Mitch McConnell played a key role in shaping. Yet as he gets ready to step down from leadership, McConnell seems out of step with the direction the party is heading.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Alabama Legislature moves to protect IVF services after state court ruling
SUMMARY: Alabama lawmakers rushed to protect in vitro fertilization services after fertility clinics shut down in the wake of a ruling that frozen embryos are children under the state wrongful death law.

TITLE: Montana judge declares 3 laws restricting abortion unconstitutional
SUMMARY: The decision cited a 1999 Montana Supreme Court ruling that said the state Constitution's right to privacy includes a woman's right to abortion access.

TITLE: A fire at a shopping mall in Bangladesh's capital has killed at least 43 people
SUMMARY: The fire started late Thursday at a restaurant on the first floor of the six-story shopping mall in downtown Dhaka. Dozens of people were injured, officials said.

TITLE: As Vietnam grows ties with U.S., a secret directive seeks to gird the Communist Party
SUMMARY: A leaked document offers a window into the motivations and concerns of party leaders as they seek to deepen ties with the U.S.

TITLE: Former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney has died at 84
SUMMARY: Former Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney, who forged close ties with two Republican U.S. presidents through a free trade agreement that was once vilified but now celebrated has died. He was 84.

TITLE: Parts of the Sierra Nevada are likely to get 10 feet of snow by the weekend
SUMMARY: The most powerful Pacific storm of the season began barreling into the region Thursday. It is expected to close major highways and trigger power outages Friday afternoon into Saturday.

TITLE: A large crowd gathered for Navalny funeral as his supporters came to bid farewell
SUMMARY: Despite fears of a police crackdown, Alexei Navalny's funeral in southeast Moscow began peacefully, two weeks after his mysterious death in an Arctic penal colony.

TITLE: Why a financial regulator is going after health care debt
SUMMARY: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau, created after the Great Recession of 2007-09, has increasingly started policing the health care system.

TITLE: South Korea launches legal action to force striking doctors back to work
SUMMARY: The South Korean government is targeting a medical group, as a doctor-walkout throws the country's health care system into chaos.

TITLE: These 3 high-fliers all made the quiz this week — with a mix of joy and sadness
SUMMARY: This week's quiz sadly falls on March 1, delaying our plan for a Friday leap day-themed quiz until 2036. Thankfully, a lot else happened in the news. Were you paying attention?

TITLE: Silence of the glams: How the Oscars (usually) snubs horror movies
SUMMARY: It's been more than 30 years since a horror movie won an Academy Award for Best Picture. Should the Oscars rethink its approach?

TITLE: West Virginia Senate passes bill requiring schools show a fetal development video
SUMMARY: The video is produced by an anti-abortion rights group and has come under fire over questions of scientific accuracy.

TITLE: Sony is laying off about 900 PlayStation employees
SUMMARY: The layoffs represent about an 8% reduction in PlayStation's global workforce.

TITLE: A fire at a shopping mall in Bangladesh's capital has killed at least 46 people
SUMMARY: A six-story shopping mall that caught fire in the Bangladeshi capital of Dhaka had no fire exits, the country's prime minister said Friday. Rescuers are continuing their search for more victims.

TITLE: Navalny's funeral draws police presence; over 100 in Gaza killed while seeking aid
SUMMARY: Alexei Navalny's funeral draws crowds and a heavy police presence. Israeli troops fired on Palestinians getting aid in Gaza.

TITLE: Navalny supporters chant 'We are not afraid' as crowds gather in Moscow for funeral
SUMMARY: Despite fears of a police crackdown, Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny's funeral in southeast Moscow went on peacefully, two weeks after his mysterious death in an Arctic penal colony.

TITLE: When celebrities show up to protest, the media follows — but so does the backlash
SUMMARY: The Middle East crisis has sharply divided Hollywood. Celebrities who've spoken out have lost jobs and been harassed. But there's a long history of celebrities lending their voices to bigger causes.

TITLE: Nikki Haley raises $12 million in February as she marches toward Super Tuesday
SUMMARY: In a conversation with a few reporters Friday, Haley highlighted her background in accounting saying, "the accountant in me stretches and stretches and stretches those dollars."

TITLE: How do you feel about the state of America right now? We want to hear your thoughts
SUMMARY: President Joe Biden will make his election-year State of the Union address on Thursday amid foreign conflicts and domestic uncertainty. We want to hear what's on your mind.

TITLE: In Georgia, a bill to cut all ties with the American Library Association is advancing
SUMMARY: Several other states have made moves to disassociate from the nation's oldest library professional association. But Georgia's bill, the first of its kind in the nation, goes further than the others.

TITLE: Who cooked up butter chicken? A court seeks the answer. Plus: Madhur Jaffrey's recipe
SUMMARY: Two families are battling for bragging rights as the inventor of the wildly popular dish. Will the truth come out? Or it could be there's another origin story involving ... British tastebuds?

TITLE: Supporters chant 'We are not afraid' as Russia's Navalny is laid to rest
SUMMARY: Despite fears of a police crackdown, Russian opposition leader Alexei Navalny's funeral in southeast Moscow went on peacefully, two weeks after his mysterious death in an Arctic penal colony.

TITLE: And the Oscar for best picture doesn't go to ... horror!
SUMMARY: It's been more than 30 years since a horror movie won an Academy Award for Best Picture. Should the Oscars rethink its approach?

TITLE: There's a new 'Climate Reality Check' test — these 3 Oscar-nominated features passed
SUMMARY: Does climate change exist? And does a character know it? Barbie, Mission: Impossible — Dead Reckoning Part One and Nyad

TITLE: CVS and Walgreens to start dispensing the abortion pill in states where it's legal
SUMMARY: CVS will start filling prescriptions for mifepristone in Massachusetts and Rhode Island. Walgreens will start in New York, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, California and Illinois.

TITLE: Elon Musk sues OpenAI for choosing profits over 'the benefit of humanity'
SUMMARY: A former co-chair of OpenAI, Musk says he invested millions in the AI lab on "false promises" that it would be nonprofit and open-source. OpenAI is now backed by Microsoft.

TITLE: Health care company ties Russian-linked cybercriminals to prescriptions breach
SUMMARY: A ransomware attack targeting a UnitedHealth Group subsidiary is disrupting pharmacies and hospitals nationwide, leaving patients with problems filling prescriptions or seeking medical treatment.

TITLE: CVS and Walgreens to start dispensing abortion pill in states where it's legal
SUMMARY: CVS will start filling prescriptions for mifepristone in Massachusetts and Rhode Island. Walgreens will start in New York, Pennsylvania, Massachusetts, California and Illinois.

TITLE: Got COVID? CDC says stay home while you're sick, but drops its 5-day isolation rule
SUMMARY: The agency is replacing its COVID-specific guidance with general guidance for respiratory viruses that says people should stay home when they are sick.

TITLE: After nearly a decade, Oprah Winfrey is set to depart the board of WeightWatchers
SUMMARY: The announcement comes amid falling profits for the company. WeightWatchers has been facing declining stock prices since November as weight loss drugs, known as GLP1s, have soared in popularity.

TITLE: Three ways to think about journalism layoffs; plus, Aaron Bushnell's self-immolation
SUMMARY: The American journalism industry is in crisis - layoffs, strikes, and site shutdowns have some people talking about the potential extinction of the the news industry as we know it. Just last week, VICE Media announced their plans to layoff hundreds of employees and halt website operations. Taylor Lorenz, the Washington Post online culture and technology columnist, joins the show to unpack what is at stake with the continued media closures and layoffs.

TITLE: 'Excess deaths' in Gaza for next 6 months projected in first-of-its-kind effort
SUMMARY: A team of researchers tried something that's never been done as a conflict rages. Instead of trying to calculate the toll of war in the moment, they looked forward. What's the reaction to their study?

TITLE: Aboard Jordan's aid airdrop over Gaza, a last resort for relief to Palestinians there
SUMMARY: NPR flew along as the Jordanian air force dropped pallets of boxes of much-needed aid attached to parachutes into the Gaza Strip.

TITLE: Trump's trial over classified documents in Florida could start as soon as this summer
SUMMARY: In a hearing before U.S. District Judge Aileen Cannon, prosecutors said they want the trial to begin in July. Trump's lawyers want to postpone it until next year, after the presidential election.

TITLE: Wendy Williams' guardianship is the subject of a new documentary. Here's how it works
SUMMARY: With a court-appointed guardian in charge of her finances, the former talk show host has practically no autonomy. Here's what guardianships do — and how it impacts Williams.

TITLE: Celebrated stylemaker and self-named 'geriatric starlet' Iris Apfel dies at age 102
SUMMARY: Apfel's late-in-life emergence as a stylemaker was celebrated in magazines and museums. Her company made reproduction fabrics for the White House for decades. She became a fashion model at 97.

TITLE: Gov. Abbott says Texas wildfires may have destroyed up to 500 structures
SUMMARY: Texas officials warned that the threat was not yet over. Higher temperatures and stronger winds forecast for Saturday elevated worries that fires in the Panhandle could continue spreading.

TITLE: Here are Idaho's 2024 Republican caucus results
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump and former U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley are on the ballot. The caucus will begin at 2 p.m. ET. Follow the live results.

TITLE: Here are Missouri's 2024 Republican caucus results
SUMMARY: Caucusing begins in the first Republican caucus in Missouri on Saturday at 10 a.m. CT/11 a.m. ET. Follow the live results.

TITLE: 4 things to know about Super Tuesday, including that winning it is crucial
SUMMARY: Since 1988 when frontloading a significant number of states on a single day became popularized in the GOP primary, it has been decisive in determining the nominee.

TITLE: What Biden's been eating on the trail and what it says about his campaign
SUMMARY: As President Biden has been out on the road, where he stops for a bite to eat says a lot about his campaign, and the voters he's trying to reach.

TITLE: Major interstate closed as dangerous winter storm pummels the Sierra Nevada
SUMMARY: A storm expected to bring up to 10 feet of snow to parts of the Sierra Nevada has forced the closure of Yosemite, many Lake Tahoe ski resorts, a major interstate and disrupted power for thousands.

TITLE: What does it take to flee Gaza? Thousands of dollars, paid to an Egyptian broker
SUMMARY: Gaza's borders are tightly controlled and most Palestinians cannot escape the war. Those who can afford it are managing to cross into Egypt by paying thousands of dollars.

TITLE: Cargo ship sinks in Red Sea nearly 2 weeks after being hit by Yemen's Houthi rebels
SUMMARY: The Belize-flagged Rubymar was the first vessel to be fully destroyed as part of the rebels' campaign over Israel's war against Hamas in the Gaza Strip.

TITLE: U.S. begins airdropping food in Gaza, but it's a less-than-ideal means of aid delivery
SUMMARY: The U.S. military on Saturday began dropping food over the war-torn enclave. Costly and inefficient, delivering humanitarian aid by air is no substitute for delivering it by land, aid groups say.

TITLE: Harris to meet Israeli minister Benny Gantz to discuss temporary Gaza cease-fire
SUMMARY: The vice president seeks to reach a cease-fire deal to allow the flow of more aid into Gaza and to discuss the region's future. Gantz's trip to Washington has upset Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu.

TITLE: Sierra Nevada is expected to receive another 2 feet of snow through the weekend
SUMMARY: Some parts of the Sierra Nevada region have already amassed over 3 feet of snow. Forecasters say snow showers will continue through Sunday.

TITLE: Here are D.C.'s 2024 Republican primary results
SUMMARY: Voting concludes Sunday in Washington, D.C.'s Republican presidential primary at 7 p.m. ET. The primary is only open to registered Republicans. Follow the results live.

TITLE: Trump wins caucuses in Missouri and Idaho and sweeps Michigan GOP convention
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump continued his march toward the GOP nomination on Saturday, winning caucuses in Idaho and Missouri and sweeping the delegate haul at a party convention in Michigan.

TITLE: Shehbaz Sharif returns as Pakistan's Prime Minister, as protests hit parliament
SUMMARY: Lawmakers in Pakistan's National Assembly elected Shehbaz Sharif as the country's new prime minister for the second time, as allies of imprisoned former premier Imran Khan shouted in protest.

TITLE: Trump's trial over classified documents in Florida could start as soon as this summer
SUMMARY: In a hearing before U.S. District Judge Aileen Cannon, prosecutors said they want the trial to begin in July. Trump's lawyers want to postpone it until next year, after the presidential election.

TITLE: PHOTOS: What it's like to be 72 — the faces (and wisdom) behind the age
SUMMARY: We live in a rapidly aging world. A new global photography project captures the lives behind the statistics by documenting the lives of 72-year-olds — the world's median life expectancy today.

TITLE: This classical ensemble is tuned in to today's headlines
SUMMARY: The Apollo Chamber Players in Houston, Texas, create concerts in response to book banning, the refugee crisis, the war in Gaza and other world events. Thousands of people attend their performances.

TITLE: This diet swap can cut your carbon footprint and boost longevity
SUMMARY: A new study finds swapping half of your typical red meat intake for plant protein, reduces your diet-related carbon footprint by 25% and may also your boost lifespan.

TITLE: LeBron James becomes first NBA player to score 40,000 points
SUMMARY: Basketball star LeBron James became the first NBA player to reach 40,000 career regular-season points on Saturday.

TITLE: 'Everything is rising at a scary rate': Why car and home insurance costs are surging
SUMMARY: The cost of auto and home insurance is rising much faster than overall inflation, thanks in part to a string of billion-dollar storms. A growing number of people are going without insurance.

TITLE: Trump wins caucuses in Missouri and Idaho and sweeps Michigan GOP convention
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump continued his march toward the GOP nomination on Saturday, winning caucuses in Idaho and Missouri and sweeping the delegate haul at a party convention in Michigan.

TITLE: For people in Gaza, the war with Israel has made a simple phone call anything but
SUMMARY: Spotty internet and cell services, blackouts and the destruction of infrastructure in Gaza during Israel's war with Hamas have hampered aid and medical services and keeping in touch with loved ones.

TITLE: Haley as a holdout could still be more than a speed bump for Trump
SUMMARY: History shows that when the major party nominees for president have not cleared the field of notable challengers before summer, they tend to lose in the fall.

TITLE: Shehbaz Sharif returns as Pakistan's prime minister, as protests hit parliament
SUMMARY: Lawmakers in Pakistan's National Assembly elected Shehbaz Sharif as the country's new prime minister for the second time, as allies of imprisoned former premier Imran Khan shouted in protest.

TITLE: Germany investigates the possible Russian eavesdropping of a military conference call
SUMMARY: German officers were reportedly talking about sending weapons to Ukraine and a potential strike by Ukrainian forces on a bridge in Crimea. The German chancellor called the incident "very serious."

TITLE: Destruction from the war with Israel has cut Gaza off from the outside world
SUMMARY: Spotty internet and cell services, blackouts and the destruction of infrastructure in Gaza during Israel's war with Hamas have hampered aid and medical services and keeping in touch with loved ones.

TITLE: California blizzard slowly weakens, but a second storm is forecast for next week
SUMMARY: Northern California is expected to receive another round of rain and snow starting Monday, after days of near nonstop snow totaling several feet and wind gusts of up to 150 mph

TITLE: Caitlin Clark passes Pete Maravich to set the all-time NCAA scoring record
SUMMARY: Another game, another record for the Iowa superstar. Clark will end her college career with the record for most points by a Division I player — men's or women's

TITLE: NPR puzzlemaster Will Shortz says he is recovering from a stroke
SUMMARY: Shortz, who has been absent from NPR's Sunday Puzzle in recent weeks, announced that his absence was due to a stroke in early February.

TITLE: Harris urges a Gaza cease-fire for hostage deal, presses Israel to ease aid delivery
SUMMARY: The vice president's remarks on Sunday are some of the strongest by a senior U.S. official regarding the protection of civilians in Gaza.

TITLE: Nikki Haley wins the D.C.'s Republican primary and gets her first 2024 victory
SUMMARY: Haley's victory at least briefly halts Donald Trump's sweep of the GOP voting contests, although the former president is likely to pick up several hundred more delegates this week.

TITLE: Here are North Dakota's 2024 Republican caucus results
SUMMARY: North Dakota Republicans hold their presidential caucus on Monday, the day before Super Tuesday. Former President Donald Trump and former U.N. Ambassador Nikki Haley are on the ballot.

TITLE: Liftoff! Four people are on their way to the space station on NASA's Crew-8 mission
SUMMARY: Three NASA astronauts and a Russian cosmonaut will spend about six months on the International Space Station - conducting experiments and research. They'll relieve four people of the Crew-7 mission.

SUMMARY: The University of Florida is eliminating its chief diversity officer position, scrapping the program's staff jobs because of a new law passed last year that was pushed by Republican Gov. Ron DeSantis.

SUMMARY: Haley's victory at least briefly halts Donald Trump's sweep of the GOP voting contests, although the former president is likely to pick up several hundred more delegates this week.

SUMMARY: Fed up with what they see as their industry's tolerance of men's transgressions and predatory behavior, women are telling their stories — in person, in group chats and on LinkedIn.

SUMMARY: A mobile medical clinic offering mental health care has sought to help Palestinians dealing with war-related anxiety, especially vulnerable communities, such as Bedouin tribes.

SUMMARY: Photographer Evan Russel and fine artist James McGrew set out to capture an elusive natural phenomenon. But as they discovered, nature can be fickle.
