SUMMARY: Voters in 16 states and one territory will make their voices heard Tuesday in the biggest primary election of the 2024 cycle. Find out who is voting and what's at stake.

TITLE: France is about to enshrine abortion rights in its constitution
SUMMARY: France is holding a historic joint session of parliament to enshrine the right to an abortion in its constitution, making it the first country to do so.

TITLE: Getting off fossil fuels is hard, but this city is doing it — building by building
SUMMARY: Ithaca, N.Y., wants to eliminate greenhouse gasses by 2030 — 20 years faster than the rest of the country. But even in this liberal city meeting climate targets is harder than expected.

SUMMARY: Fed up with what they see as their industry's tolerance of men's transgressions and predatory behavior, women are telling their stories — in person, in group chats and on LinkedIn.

SUMMARY: The death toll in Gaza reached 30,000 this past week, as airstrikes continued and the U.S. conducted its first aid drop while Israel continues to consider a proposed cease-fire deal.

TITLE: A U.N. report finds 'reasonable grounds to believe' attacks in Israel included rape
SUMMARY: The report, which fell short of a full U.N. investigation, said rape likely occurred at at least three sites on Oct. 7. Some hostages held in Gaza were also subject to sexual violence, the team found.

TITLE: A U.N. report finds 'reasonable grounds to believe' attacks in Israel included rapes
SUMMARY: The report, which fell short of a full U.N. investigation, said rape likely occurred at at least three sites on Oct. 7. Some hostages held in Gaza were also subject to sexual violence, the team found.

TITLE: The EU fines Apple nearly $2 billion for hindering music streaming competition
SUMMARY: Apple muzzled streaming services from telling users about payment options on their websites, which avoids a 30% fee charged when people pay through apps downloaded with the iOS App Store, the EU said.

TITLE: Former Twitter executives sue Elon Musk for more than $128 million in severance
SUMMARY: The lawsuit says not paying severance and bills is part of a pattern for Musk. Representatives for Musk and San Francisco-based X did not immediately respond to messages for comment.

TITLE: I flew to Japan with my baby. Here's what I learned about traveling with young kids
SUMMARY: Looking to travel this spring with your little one? These tips and tricks can make the journey not just manageable, but enjoyable. Travel experts explain how to navigate packing, air travel and tourism with a kid under age 2.

TITLE: A new satellite will track climate-warming pollution. Here's why that's a big deal
SUMMARY: A satellite with a climate solutions mission blasted off on a SpaceX rocket Monday. It's on a mission to detect planet-heating methane pollution from the oil and gas sector.

TITLE: Racial disparities in voter turnout have grown since Supreme Court ruling, study says
SUMMARY: A new study finds that the gap between white and nonwhite voters is growing fastest in places that were stripped of federal civil rights-era voting protections by a 2013 Supreme Court ruling.

TITLE: 3 things to know about the current crisis in Haiti
SUMMARY: The scenes from Haiti may look familiar, as heavily armed gangs trade fire, and civilians cower in fear. But there is something different about this latest episode.

TITLE: Places across the U.S. are testing no-strings cash as part of the social safety net
SUMMARY: The idea got a boost from the pandemic, when an array of cash relief helped cut child poverty and keep people housed.  Researchers are studying how much money, for how long, may have lasting impact.

TITLE: China's leaders announce a push to jumpstart economy, but say it won't be easy
SUMMARY: The country's premier announces a round of fiscal stimulus to boost employment, but warns its legions of bureaucrats to gird themselves for a period of fiscal austerity.

TITLE: JetBlue and Spirit abandon their decision to merge after it was blocked by a judge
SUMMARY: JetBlue and Spirit said it'd be best if they remain separate companies as they don't believe they'll be able to merge by the time the agreement is up in July.

TITLE: On Super Tuesday, abortion is driving Democrats to the polls in North Carolina
SUMMARY: The Biden campaign says it sees a chance to win North Carolina in November. In the primary campaign, Democratic voters say new restrictions on abortion are motivating them to get to the polls.

SUMMARY: Yamamoto's postwar childhood in Japan shaped his interest in the interplay of architecture and community. The jury of the prestigious architecture award cited the intergenerational power of his work.

TITLE: More U.S. aid air dropped into Gaza
SUMMARY: Aid groups say air drops alone are far from sufficient given the scale of the crisis.

SUMMARY: It's the biggest primary day of this election season. Follow NPR for live updates as voters make their voices heard, ballots are tallied and race calls are made.

SUMMARY: Sixteen states and American Samoa hold primary elections today. A U.N. report finds grounds to believe Hamas raped women during the Oct. 7 attack.

SUMMARY: Black romance authors have been some of the leading advocates for change in the books industry. <em>This Could Be Us,

SUMMARY: Yes, there will be meltdowns. But there will also be joy. Tips on which baby gear to pack, how to prepare your child (and yourself) for the long journey – and how to make the trip fun for everyone.

SUMMARY: Rod Nordland was diagnosed with glioblastoma, the most lethal form of brain cancer, in 2019. He writes about facing mortality from war and cancer in his new memoir, <em>Waiting for the Monsoon.

SUMMARY: Production at Tesla's plant near Berlin ground to a halt and workers were evacuated after a power failure caused by suspected arson, drawing condemnation from Tesla CEO Elon Musk.

SUMMARY: David Franklin Slater, a retired U.S. Army officer, was accused of leaking top classified national defense information related to the Russia-Ukraine war on a foreign dating website.

TITLE: More U.S. aid airdropped into Gaza
SUMMARY: Aid groups say airdrops alone are far from sufficient given the scale of the crisis.

TITLE: Bitcoin hits a record high. Here are 4 things to know about this spectacular rally
SUMMARY: Bitcoin hit a record high, marking a remarkable comeback from a period known as the "crypto winter." A big catalyst behind the gains has been the approval of new bitcoin investment funds.

TITLE: Dartmouth men's basketball team votes to unionize, shaking up college sports
SUMMARY: The Dartmouth men's basketball team voted 13-2 to join SEIU Local 560, making it the first unionized college sports team in the country. Dartmouth believes the election should not have gone forward.

TITLE: In a first, U.S. students will take the SAT entirely online (no pencils required)
SUMMARY: Students taking the exam use their own devices, or school devices – they no longer need a  paper and pencil. More than a million students are expected to take the test.

TITLE: Independent Arizona Sen. Kyrsten Sinema will not seek reelection
SUMMARY: The Arizona seat will likely be key in determining control of the Senate.

TITLE: The U.S. sharply limits how much credit cards can charge you in late fees
SUMMARY: The Consumer Financial Protection Bureau issued a new rule Tuesday capping late fees on credit cards, a move designed to save customers an estimated $10 billion a year. Critics promised a lawsuit.

TITLE: Liberty University fined $14 million for federal crime reporting violations
SUMMARY: The university agreed to the fine as part of a settlement agreement with the U.S. Education Department, which found numerous violations of the Clery Act, a campus safety law.

TITLE: How states giving rights to fetuses could set up a national case on abortion
SUMMARY: Fetal personhood made headlines recently when the Alabama Supreme Court ruled that embryos are "extrauterine children." The ruling raised questions across the country about fetal personhood.

TITLE: Listen to NPR's special coverage of Super Tuesday
SUMMARY: Votes will be tallied in 16 states and one territory on Super Tuesday, March 5. Listen to NPR's live coverage starting at 8 p.m. ET.

SUMMARY: Sixteen states and American Samoa hold primary elections today. A U.N. report finds grounds to believe Hamas raped women during the Oct. 7 attack.

SUMMARY: The newsroom union at The New York Times

TITLE: Should the government do more to help children? This bipartisan group thinks so

SUMMARY: The new government of Prime Minister Donald Tusk has promised to introduce legislation that would legalize civil unions in Poland, one of the few nations in Europe that doesn't recognize them.

SUMMARY: A failed execution in Idaho has put a spotlight on the teams of people that prisons use to impose the ultimate penalty on condemned inmates.

SUMMARY: There is a "really grim irony" to the U.S. supplying both the bombs that are dropping on Gaza and now the food parcels that are dropping there, according to one aid expert.

SUMMARY: The outcome may have gone as expected overall, but here's what the details mean for the presidential election.

SUMMARY: Protesters broke down the door of Mexico's presidential palace with a truck on Wednesday, demanding answers for 43 college students who went missing a decade ago.

SUMMARY: The Senate Republican leader has consistently clashed with Trump, most forcefully after the Jan. 6, 2021 attack on the Capitol.

SUMMARY: Were you paying attention to the most predictable Super Tuesday ever?

SUMMARY: Haiti's embattled prime minister is in neighboring Puerto Rico, still unable to return to Port-au-Prince, as calls for him to resign grow louder by the day.

TITLE: NTSB says Boeing is withholding key details about door plug on Alaska 737 Max 9 jet

TITLE: Gabriel García Márquez's last novel is published against his wishes

TITLE: Houthi missile attack kills 2 crew members in rebels' first fatal assault on shipping
SUMMARY: An attack by Yemen's Houthi rebels on a commercial ship in the Gulf of Aden killed two of its crew members and forced survivors to abandon the vessel. Six crew members were wounded, officials said.

TITLE: President Biden would ban TikTok. But candidate Biden is using it for his campaign

TITLE: Corporate America has new climate rules to follow, but will they cut global warming?
SUMMARY: The Securities and Exchange Commission is requiring publicly-traded companies to disclose information about the risks they face from climate change. Industry is expected to sue to stop the rules.

TITLE: 'Uncommitted' movement spreads to Super Tuesday states
SUMMARY: Just a week after 100,000 Michigan voters chose uncommitted on their Democratic ballots, hundreds of thousands of Americans across the country made a similar statement on Super Tuesday.

TITLE: Chinese national arrested and charged with stealing AI trade secrets from Google

TITLE: Jason Palmer beats Biden in American Samoa, and looks to Northern Mariana Islands
SUMMARY: "Biden's chances of a second term are hurting, but not because of my campaign," the Baltimore, Md.-based entrepreneur says of his bid to win the Democratic nomination over the incumbent.

TITLE: Haley's Out: Can Trump Win Her Supporters?
SUMMARY:
Nikki Haley's announcement that she was suspending her campaign for president didn't come as a surprise. She's trailed front-runner Donald Trump in all but two Republican primary contests so far.

Haley did manage to sway some Republican voters away from Trump. She also managed to recruit independents and Democrats, too. As she ended her campaign on a stage in South Carolina, Haley did not endorse Trump. She said he would have to earn their votes.

Nikki Haley appealed to Republicans who did not want another four years of Trump. Now that she's out of the race, where will her voters go?

TITLE: Houthi missile attack kills 3 crew members in rebels' first fatal assault on shipping
SUMMARY: An attack by Yemen's Houthi rebels on a commercial ship in the Gulf of Aden killed three of its crew members and forced survivors to abandon the vessel. Four crew members were injured, officials said.

TITLE: Boeing is withholding key details about door plug on Alaska 737 Max 9 jet, NTSB says
SUMMARY: At a Senate hearing, the top federal safety investigator said Boeing has still not provided crucial details about who opened the door plug from an Alaska Airlines 737 Max jet before a midair blowout.

TITLE: 'Rust' film armorer found guilty in death of cinematographer
SUMMARY: Hannah Gutierrez-Reed is the first to stand trial in a case reexamining the movie industry's safety standards. Actor Alec Baldwin's criminal trial will start in July.

TITLE: Key moments from Biden's 2024 State of the Union address you may have missed
SUMMARY: In his State of the Union address Thursday, President Biden highlighted key achievements of his first term and made the case that voters should give him a second. Here are six highlights.

TITLE: Biden touts economic 'comeback' in election-year pitch to skeptical voters
SUMMARY: President Biden used his State of the Union speech to highlight economic gains and draw a contrast with his GOP opponents. Polls shows many voters give Biden low marks for his economic stewardship.

TITLE: Read President Biden's 2024 State of the Union address
SUMMARY: Read President Biden's 2024 State of the Union speech as prepared for delivery — and watch him give his speech on March 7.

TITLE: Alluding to Trump, Biden calls out Republicans 'bragging' about abortion bans
SUMMARY: In a likely foreshadowing of Democrats' messaging this fall, President Biden called out those who enabled the overturning of <em>Roe v. Wade

TITLE: TSA unveils a prototype self-service airport checkpoint security screening system
SUMMARY: Passengers at the Harry Reid International Airport in Las Vegas will be the first to use a new prototype airport security system, which has been compared to the self-checkout at a grocery store.

TITLE: Steve Lawrence, singer and half of popular stage duo Steve & Eydie, dies at 88
SUMMARY: Steve Lawrence, a singer and top stage act who as a solo performer and in tandem with his wife Eydie Gorme kept Tin Pan Alley alive during the rock era, died Thursday.

TITLE: Report: Audiences demand diversity in films, Hollywood can do more
SUMMARY: UCLA's annual report on Hollywood diversity finds a mixed bag. While people of color are being hired more in key categories, the study shows a film industry disinvesting in women.

TITLE: 3 escaped inmates are charged with killing missing U.S. sailing couple in Caribbean
SUMMARY: Three escaped inmates from the eastern Caribbean island of Grenada were charged in the killing of a U.S. couple whose catamaran they hijacked, police said. The couple's bodies have not been found.

TITLE: Generations After The First Nuclear Test, Those Sickened Fight For Compensation
SUMMARY:
On August 6, 1945, a stone-faced President Harry Truman appeared on television and told Americans about the atomic bomb being dropped on Hiroshima.

The attack on Hiroshima marked the first time nuclear power was used in war, but the atomic bomb was actually tested a month earlier in the Jornada del Muerto desert of New Mexico.

At least hundreds of New Mexicans were harmed by the test's fallout. Radiation creeped into the grass their cows grazed, on the food they ate, and the water they drank.

A program compensating victims of government-caused nuclear contamination has been in place since 1990, but it never included downwinders in New Mexico, the site of the very first nuclear test.

This week, the Senate voted to broaden the bi-partisan legislation that could compensate people who have suffered health consequences of radiation testing. Now, the bill will go to a House vote.

Generations after the Trinity Nuclear Test, will downwinders in New Mexico finally get compensation?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: A stingray named Charlotte got pregnant — exactly how remains a mystery
SUMMARY: The world is waiting for a stingray to give birth in the small town of Hendersonville, N.C. That's because it's not clear how she got pregrant, as there's no other stingray in the aquarium.

TITLE: 'All of Us' research project diversifies the storehouse of genetic knowledge
SUMMARY: The National Institutes of Health initiative that aims to make human genome research more inclusive reports its first results. Some 275 million new genetic variations have been identified.

TITLE: Researchers have found an amphibian that makes milk for its babies
SUMMARY: The snake-like amphibian is native to Brazil. Researchers say the milk in many ways resembles that produced by mammals.

TITLE: Biden to announce the setting up of a temporary Mediterranean port to deliver Gaza aid
SUMMARY: The temporary pier will not require U.S. troops to land in Gaza to build the pier or causeway. United Nations workers and other aid groups will distribute the aid.

TITLE: A march on Jerusalem, with freed hostages and families demanding a deal
SUMMARY: Families of the dozens of hostages still being held by Hamas in Gaza and their supporters embarked on a four-day march to Jerusalem to push officials to secure a deal for their loved ones' release.

TITLE: Sweden officially joins NATO as worries grow over Russian aggression in Europe
SUMMARY: Sweden has formally joined NATO as the 32nd member of the transatlantic military alliance, ending decades of post-World War II neutrality as concerns about Russian aggression in Europe have spiked.

TITLE: Judge denies Donald Trump's request to delay $83.3 million payment to E. Jean Carroll
SUMMARY: Judge Lewis A. Kaplan said any financial harm to the Republican front-runner for the presidency results from Trump's slow response to the late-January verdict in the defamation case.

TITLE: A decade later, parents of Chinese passengers on MH370 still ask about their children
SUMMARY: Friday is the 10th anniversary of the disappearance of flight MH370. The Boeing 777 left Malaysia bound for Beijing with 239 people on board, but took a sharp turn south and fell off the radar.

TITLE: What to know about the political debate around daylight saving time
SUMMARY: At least 29 states have considered legislation related to daylight saving time, including making it permanent year-round. But those laws won't take effect until Congress makes it legal.

TITLE: For April's eclipse, the disparity between 'meh' and 'OMG' may be driving across town
SUMMARY: Lots of urban areas will be either in or adjacent to the path of totality for the eclipse on April 8. Experts advise getting into this path, as even a 99% partial eclipse is nothing like a total one.

TITLE: Miami-Dade County moves to evict Miami Seaquarium
SUMMARY: Miami-Dade County has accused the operators of the Seaquarium of improperly caring for the grounds and animals. In August, the tourist attraction was under fire after the death of Lolita the orca.

TITLE: Meet the woman who helped libraries across the U.S. 'surf the internet'
SUMMARY: Jean Armour Polly was inducted into the Internet Hall of Fame in 2019 for evangelizing computers in public libraries, the precursor to the internet being offered as a core service in those spaces.

TITLE: Domestic violence may leave telltale damage in the brain. Scientists want to find it
SUMMARY: Traumatic brain injuries from intimate partner violence are common, and potentially more severe than those seen in sports.

TITLE: We watched the State of the Union with one undecided voter. She wasn't that impressed
SUMMARY: Karen Seagraves is the kind of independent voter President Biden's campaign hopes to win over this election year. Here's how she saw last night's State of the Union address.

TITLE: Biden spars with Republicans on border security during State of the Union
SUMMARY: The speech — as well as the response — reflect how difficult the border issue has become ahead of the 2024 presidential election.

TITLE: From rogue flooring to lactating worms, this news quiz is weird
SUMMARY: Why was the Oscars carpet champagne? Why is some subterranean worm-amphibian making milk? What's next for the American Samoa guy? Are there any records left for Caitlin Clark to break? Find out!

TITLE: 5 takeaways from President Biden's State of the Union address
SUMMARY: President Biden used the high-profile speech to draw a contrast with his 2024 likely opponent, former President Donald Trump. He hit on the economy, abortion, the Mideast and the border.

TITLE: Investigators narrow search into cause of deadly Florida condo collapse in Surfside
SUMMARY: A federal team continues to focus on construction flaws in the pool deck as it investigates the collapse of the Champlain Towers South condominium in Surfside, Fla. in 2021 which killed 98 people.

TITLE: Mexico City's long-running water problems are getting even worse
SUMMARY: Reservoirs that furnish a large part of the Mexican capital have fallen to historic lows, as low rainfall, climate change and mismanagement exacerbate the problem.

TITLE: It's time to move your clocks forward — and to check if your car is being recalled
SUMMARY: Federal regulators call the week before clocks change "Vehicle Safety Recalls Week." It's a reminder to check on NHTSA.gov or the SaferCar app to see if your car has been recalled.

TITLE: For April's eclipse, going from 'meh' to 'OMG' might mean just driving across town
SUMMARY: Lots of urban areas will be either in or adjacent to the path of totality for the eclipse on April 8. Experts advise getting into this path, as even a 99% partial eclipse is nothing like a total one.

TITLE: Takeaways from Biden's SOTU; Trump poised to take control of RNC
SUMMARY: President Biden made the case for his reelection during the State of the Union address. The Republican National Committee chooses new leadership today.

TITLE: An Israeli responder's work on Oct. 7 shows the challenges of investigating atrocities
SUMMARY: Israel says Palestinian attackers committed sexual violence on Oct. 7. Some accounts of rape were substantiated by a U.N. report, but the allegations continue to face intense scrutiny.

TITLE: George Santos, ejected from House and facing fraud trial, will run again in N.Y.
SUMMARY: George Santos, disgraced and ejected from the House, says he will seek office again on Long Island. He'll face Rep. Nick LaLota in the GOP primary.

TITLE: What's next for the Alec Baldwin 'Rust' case after film's armorer was found guilty?
SUMMARY: Special prosecutors face an uphill battle in trying to convict the actor over the tragic death of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins, a former federal prosecutor says.

TITLE: The State of 'Shrinkflation': Why Biden called out skimpy bags of potato chips
SUMMARY: The term is relatively new, but companies have long hidden price hikes in plain sight by changing package sizing. Now the debate is getting political.

TITLE: Las Vegas Aces make WNBA history as first team to sell out season tickets
SUMMARY: The two-time WNBA champion Las Vegas Aces have accomplished a first for the women's pro basketball league, selling out of season ticket memberships for 2024.

TITLE: Photos from demonstrations around the world on International Women's Day
SUMMARY: Protesters decried the wage gap, poor maternity leave and unequal access to education. And some used the occasion to call for a cease-fire in Gaza and the release of the remaining Israeli hostages.

TITLE: What to expect at the Oscars: The bomb, the bombshell, and the possible comeback
SUMMARY: The Motion Picture Academy hopes that more popular films, an earlier showtime, and increased diversity among nominees will lead to higher viewership.

TITLE: Biden spars with Republicans on border security during State of the Union
SUMMARY: The speech — as well as the response — reflect how difficult the border issue has become ahead of the 2024 presidential election.

TITLE: 5 takeaways from President Biden's State of the Union address
SUMMARY: President Biden used the high-profile speech to draw a contrast with his 2024 likely opponent, former President Donald Trump. He hit on the economy, abortion, the Mideast and the border.

TITLE: Mexico City's long-running water problems are getting even worse
SUMMARY: Reservoirs that furnish a large part of the Mexican capital have fallen to historic lows, as low rainfall, climate change and mismanagement exacerbate the problem.

TITLE: CBS is developing its first Black daytime soap opera in 35 years
SUMMARY: The series, currently titled <em>The Gates

TITLE: U.S. court convicts ex-president of Honduras of aiding drug traffickers
SUMMARY: Former President of Honduras Juan Orlando Hernández has been found guilty on charges relating to drug trafficking and weapons possession, in a trial by jury in New York.

TITLE: What's next for the Alec Baldwin 'Rust' case after film's armorer was found guilty?
SUMMARY: Special prosecutors face an uphill battle in trying to convict the actor over the tragic death of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins, a former federal prosecutor says.

TITLE: The State of 'Shrinkflation': Why Biden called out skimpy bags of potato chips
SUMMARY: The term is relatively new, but companies have long hidden price hikes in plain sight by changing package sizing. Now the debate is getting political.

TITLE: Las Vegas Aces make WNBA history as first team to sell out season tickets
SUMMARY: The two-time WNBA champion Las Vegas Aces have accomplished a first for the women's pro basketball league, selling out of season ticket memberships for 2024.

TITLE: Why 'Dragon Ball' creator Akira Toriyama was so important to the world of anime
SUMMARY: Akira Toriyama has died at 68. He was known globally for his best-selling manga series Dragon Ball, which gave rise to the popular anime series Dragon Ball Z

TITLE: Pentagon finds 'no evidence' of alien technology in new UFO report
SUMMARY: In the U.S. military's most comprehensive report addressing unconfirmed UFO sightings, defense officials concluded that most sightings dating back to 1945 were of ordinary origin.

TITLE: 10 years after Chibok, Nigeria's mass kidnappings return with a vengeance
SUMMARY: In just a week there have been two mass kidnappings in Nigeria. Hundreds of women and children have been kidnapped in recent days in Africa's most populous country.

TITLE: As a deadline approaches, Colorado River states are still far apart on water sharing
SUMMARY: Ahead of a deadline next week, the seven states that share the Colorado River have revealed competing plans for how the river should be managed in the future.

TITLE: Senate passes spending package hours ahead of shutdown deadline
SUMMARY: Senators voted 75 to 22 to approve a package of six spending bills that will last until the end of the fiscal year on September 30.

TITLE: Immigrants are less likely to commit crimes than U.S.-born Americans, studies find
SUMMARY: In last night's State of The Union, the murder of 22-year-old Laken Riley took center stage. The suspect is a migrant. Republicans say immigration leads to crime, but there's no evidence of that.

TITLE: FDA approves Wegovy for lowering heart attack and stroke risk in overweight patients
SUMMARY: The popular weight-loss drug can now be used to reduce the risk of stroke, heart attacks and other serious cardiovascular problems in patients who are overweight or who have obesity, the FDA said.

TITLE: Judge upholds program allowing 30,000 migrants from 4 countries into the US per month
SUMMARY: Led by Texas, the states who brought the lawsuit against the Biden administration argued the program is forcing them to spend millions on health care, education and public safety for the migrants.

TITLE: Five ways Israelis have changed, after 5 months of war
SUMMARY: The state of Israeli society, five months after the Oct. 7 attack, is crucial to understanding where the Israel-Hamas conflict might lead. Here are five ways Israel has been transformed.

TITLE: The pioneering women behind the invisible art of film editing
SUMMARY: There would be no film without film editing. And yet, its practitioners don't often grace the cover of magazines.

TITLE: Now that he's the presumptive nominee, Trump readies next campaign: who will be VP?
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump's vice presidential pick will say a lot about how he sees the future of the Republican Party and how much he values loyalty.

TITLE: Yemen's rebels target Singapore-flagged ship as U.S. and allies down Houthi drones
SUMMARY: An attack by Houthi rebels set off explosions ahead of a Singapore-flagged vessel in the Gulf of Aden, the latest in a campaign of assaults by the Iranian-backed group over Israel's war on Hamas.

TITLE: Mexico's female matadors return to the world's largest bullring
SUMMARY: A glimpse at the world of women bullfighters in Mexico City, as the spectacle makes its return two years after a judge banned it — generating excitement from fans and criticism over animal cruelty.

TITLE: Judge upholds program allowing 30,000 migrants from 4 nations into the U.S. per month
SUMMARY: Led by Texas, the states who brought the lawsuit against the Biden administration argued the program is forcing them to spend millions on health care, education and public safety for the migrants.

TITLE: Resilient and strong: Voices of women from Kenya's largest 'slum'
SUMMARY: International Women's Day, on March 8, celebrates the achievements of women. We share stories from women in the the Kibera community, which locals call a "slum," about their setbacks and successes.

TITLE: 2 National Guard members and Border Patrol agent are killed in Texas helicopter crash
SUMMARY: Three National Guard soldiers and a Border Patrol agent were on board when a helicopter crashed near the Mexican border. A soldier was seriously injured.

TITLE: Biden signs spending package that averts a government shutdown
SUMMARY: Senators voted 75-22 on Friday to approve the package of six spending bills that will last until the end of the fiscal year on Sept. 30.

SUMMARY: Batool Cakes, a professional bakery in Rafah, has reopened to meet the demand of displaced Palestinians seeking cakes to celebrate life even amid war.

TITLE: Boeing says it can't find documents on the door plug that blew off mid-air
SUMMARY: A Boeing top official told Congress that employees looked extensively for documents on the door plug and it's likely that such paperwork never existed.

TITLE: Sweden and Canada resume funding the U.N. aid agency for Palestinians
SUMMARY: Many countries halted funding after Israel accused 12 of UNRWA's thousands of employees of participating in the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks.

TITLE: A leading mindfulness teacher shares insights to counter tech addiction and isolation
SUMMARY: Jon Kabat-Zinn, who brought mindfulness meditation into mainstream medical settings, discusses how the centering practice can help with some of today's widespread social problems.

TITLE: Biden: Netanyahu 'hurting Israel' by not preventing more civilian deaths in Gaza
SUMMARY: President Joe Biden said Saturday that he believes Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is "hurting Israel more than helping Israel" in how he is approaching its war against Hamas in Gaza.

TITLE: The long, lonely fight of an Israeli hostage's sister, who fears time is running out
SUMMARY: On Oct. 7, Gaza militants killed Carmit Palty Katzir's father and took her mother and brother hostage. Her mother was released, but Katzir fears time is running out to get her brother back alive.

TITLE: Biden and Trump trade barbs at rival rallies in Georgia
SUMMARY: President Joe Biden and ex-President Donald Trump warned of dire consequences for the country if the other wins another term in the White House as the pair held dueling rallies in Georgia on Saturday.

TITLE: It's not easy being Colombia's 1st left-wing president
SUMMARY: Gustavo Petro faces fierce opposition from what he views as Colombia's deeply conservative deep state.

TITLE: The working class gets stubbed out in Russell Banks' posthumous 'American Spirits'
SUMMARY: The late author often wrote about the loneliness and isolation of the working class. His new short story collection puts a sharper focus on the politics of small town life.

TITLE: That spare change you donate at checkout is adding up to millions for charities
SUMMARY: So-called point-of-sale donations have sharply increased in recent years, bringing in hundreds of millions a year. But the requests to "round up" your bill for charity have really taken off.

TITLE: Georgia and Michigan could be key to keeping Black voter turnout up in 2024
SUMMARY: In the 2022 midterm elections, Black voter turnout dropped dramatically. Ahead of the presidential election in 2024, organizers warn it could happen again and political parties should pay attention.

TITLE: After facing criticism, Israel has revised its entry for the Eurovision Song Contest
SUMMARY: Eden Golan's original song, titled "October Rain," has been renamed "Hurricane" after objections that it was not politically neutral. Israel's public broadcaster will reveal the amended song Sunday.

TITLE: Q&A: Yashica Dutt on her life as part of an oppressed caste in 'Coming Out As Dalit'
SUMMARY: When Dutt was a kid, her family pretended to be rich so no one would suspect their caste identity. In her memoir, she talks of her struggles — and her decision to publicly declare she is a Dalit.

TITLE: 'Saturday Night Live' lampoons GOP Sen. Katie Britt's State of the Union response
SUMMARY: Scarlett Johansson made a surprise appearance on the NBC sketch comedy show to poke fun at the Republican rebuttal to President Biden's State of the Union address.

TITLE: Red carpet looks from the 2024 Oscars
SUMMARY: Check out this year's most memorable red carpet looks from the 2024 Oscars.

TITLE: As a U.S. aid ship heads to Gaza, Biden again warns Netanyahu on civilian deaths
SUMMARY: The U.S. ship left Virginia this weekend as part of an emergency mission to build a temporary pier in Gaza to facilitate aid. Biden criticized the Israeli prime minister over civilian deaths in Gaza.

TITLE: 'Oppenheimer' wins Oscar for best picture
SUMMARY: Christopher Nolan's <em>Oppenheimer

TITLE: Oscars 2024: A night of 'Oppenheimer,' quiet protest, and Ryan Gosling just being Ken
SUMMARY: For a night with relatively few surprises but some very enjoyable winners, it was a solid show that honored an awful lot of good movies, and movies that drew significant audiences.

TITLE: How high blood sugar, hypertension and obesity can add up to cancer risk
SUMMARY: It's known that obesity is linked to many cancers. A study shows metabolic syndrome, which includes factors like high blood pressure and insulin resistance, also drives increased risk.

TITLE: The U.S. prison population is rapidly graying. Prisons aren't built for what's coming
SUMMARY: By one measure, about a third of all prisoners will be considered geriatric by 2030. Prison systems are grappling with how to care for their elderly prisoners — and how to pay for it.

TITLE: As Ramadan begins, uncertainty and anxiety surround the Al-Aqsa mosque
SUMMARY: Questions remain about access to the main Islamic congregational mosque in the Al-Aqsa compound in Jerusalem's Old City as Palestinians see the site as essential to their identity.

TITLE: Muslims prepare for a more somber Ramadan due to the Israel-Hamas war
SUMMARY: As the holy month of Ramadan begins, Muslims are preparing for a less joyful observance this year. Fasting and charity take on a different meaning when many in Gaza are suffering.

TITLE: Harris plans to visit the Parkland school where 14 kids were killed in 2018
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris will walk through Marjory Stoneman Douglas High School in Parkland, Fla., on March 23 with the families of the victims who were killed there in a mass shooting.

TITLE: Young voters helped elect Biden in 2020. His campaign is courting them again in 2024
SUMMARY: Students for Biden Harris is focused on building a large volunteer base of young supporters through student-led groups. Recruiting young voters could be key to President Biden's reelection hopes.

TITLE: Women who do strength training live longer. How much is enough?
SUMMARY: Strength training is good for everyone. But women who train regularly, reduce their risk of death from heart disease significantly. And here are 5 other hidden benefits of building muscle.

TITLE: The new kids on campus? Toddlers, courtesy of Head Start
SUMMARY: And not <em>just

TITLE: U.K.'s Kate Middleton apologizes for 'confusion' over edited photo
SUMMARY: "Like many amateur photographers, I do occasionally experiment with editing," the princess of Wales said, acknowledging suspicions about a family photo.

TITLE: Ramadan begins without a cease-fire; 'Oppenheimer' sweeps the Oscars
SUMMARY: Ramadan begins in many countries, without the Israel-Hamas cease-fire that the U.S. hoped would be in place by the holy month. Plus, takeaways from an Oscars ceremony heavy on the Kenergy.

TITLE: Biden's proposed 2025 budget cuts costs for families and hikes taxes for the wealthy
SUMMARY: President Biden's budget proposal is unlikely to pass in a divided Congress. But it's a key statement of his values  —  and meant to put Republican lawmakers on notice, his administration says.

TITLE: Will you be celebrating the solar eclipse? NPR wants to hear from you
SUMMARY: Is this your first total solar eclipse, or did you have your glasses out in 2017, too? However you're celebrating, we want to hear from you.

TITLE: Anti-sex trafficking advocate accuses GOP Sen. Katie Britt of distorting her story
SUMMARY: The woman who appears central to an anecdote told by GOP Sen. Katie Britt, R-Ala., in the GOP response to the State of the Union called the use of her story "distorted for political purposes.

TITLE: What's behind the red pins celebrities wore at the Oscars
SUMMARY: Actors, directors and musicians at the 2024 Oscars wore the red pins to support a group called Artists4Ceasfire, which is calling for an immediate and permanent cease-fire in the Israel-Hamas war.

TITLE: Retailers howled about theft last year. Why not now?
SUMMARY: Mentions of retail theft seem to be fading, their fever pitch cooling. What's changed? And how bad was the problem in the first place?

TITLE: One reason school cyberattacks are on the rise? Schools are easy targets for hackers
SUMMARY: School systems of every size have been hit by cyberattacks. "It's not Johnny in his room trying to break in and change his grades anymore," says one superintendent.

TITLE: Wrestling with my husband's fear of getting COVID again
SUMMARY: My husband is high risk and still takes COVID precautions. I want our old life back.

TITLE: Biden unveils a budget that would cut costs for families and hike taxes for the rich
SUMMARY: President Biden's $7.3 trillion budget wish-list puts dollar figures to his pledges in the State of the Union address. But actual spending plans are up to Congress.

TITLE: What to know about the 'confusion' over Kate Middleton's edited family photo
SUMMARY: "Like many amateur photographers, I do occasionally experiment with editing," the princess of Wales said, acknowledging suspicions about a family photo.

TITLE: Photos: The 5-month mark passes as the humanitarian crisis grows in Gaza
SUMMARY: Ramadan begins as five months of war passes in Gaza. Countries including Jordan, Sweden, Canada and the U.S. continue to contribute aid to help with the growing humanitarian crisis.

TITLE: The fastest ocean liner to cross the Atlantic faces eviction from a pier
SUMMARY: The SS United States, once a luxurious ocean liner, holds the speed record for crossing the Atlantic. It's rusting away at a pier in Philadelphia and could soon be evicted and scrapped.

TITLE: Airbnb bans all indoor security cameras
SUMMARY: Starting April 30, Airbnb is prohibiting all indoor security cameras in its listings. Previously, it allowed indoor cameras in common areas that were disclosed prior to booking and visible to guests.

TITLE: U.S. Housing Secretary Marcia Fudge will step down this month
SUMMARY: Fudge, 71, is one of the few cabinet members to leave the Biden administration so far, and will return home to Ohio. She says affordable housing is a bipartisan challenge that needs more funding.

TITLE: Virginia has banned legacy admissions at its public colleges
SUMMARY: The new law, which passed unanimously in the Virginia House and Senate, will take effect July 1.

TITLE: Farmers accused of drying up the imperiled Great Salt Lake say they can help save it
SUMMARY: Environmentalists are suing Utah to force water cutbacks to farmers to save the Great Salt Lake. Farmers call the blame unfair and say that would have its own environmental and economic consequences.

TITLE: Florida teachers can discuss LGBTQ topics under 'Don't Say Gay' law, settlement says
SUMMARY: Students and teachers can discuss sexual orientation and gender identity in the classroom, provided it's not part of instruction, under a settlement between Florida officials and civil rights lawyers.

TITLE: India announces steps to implement a citizenship law that excludes Muslims
SUMMARY: Prime Minister Narendra Modi's government announced rules to implement a 2019 citizenship law that excludes Muslims, weeks before the Hindu nationalist leader seeks a third term in office.

TITLE: Here are Georgia's 2024 presidential primary results
SUMMARY: Voting concludes Tuesday in Georgia's presidential primaries. President Biden and former President Donald Trump, the front-runners, are on their party's primary ballots. Follow the live results.

TITLE: Here are Washington's 2024 presidential primary results
SUMMARY: Voting concludes Tuesday in Washington's presidential primaries. President Biden and former President Donald Trump, the front-runners, are on their party's primary ballots. Follow the live results.

TITLE: Here are key results in Mississippi's 2024 primaries
SUMMARY: Voting concludes in Mississippi's presidential, U.S. House and U.S. Senate primaries. President Biden and former President Donald Trump, the front-runners, are on their party's primary ballots.

TITLE: House GOP moves ahead with TikTok vote as Trump voices opposition to possible ban
SUMMARY: House Republicans move ahead with a bill that would require Chinese company ByteDance to sell TikTok or face a ban in the U.S. even as former President Donald Trump voices opposition to the effort.

TITLE: Haiti's prime minister says he'll resign once a transitional council is created
SUMMARY: The de-facto prime minister of Haiti agreed to resign once a transitional presidential council is installed and interim prime minister named. CARICOM, the bloc of Caribbean nations, brokered the deal.

TITLE: Hackers are targeting a surprising group of people: young public school students
SUMMARY: Districts store all kinds of sensitive student data, which means the consequences of a school cyberattack can follow pupils well into adulthood. And it's not just their credit that's at risk.

TITLE: Special counsel set to testify on Capitol Hill about Biden classified documents probe
SUMMARY: Special counsel Robert Hur is set to testify before the House Judiciary Committee on his investigation into President Biden's handling of classified documents.

TITLE: Why flying is still safe despite high-profile problems
SUMMARY: United Airlines recently had multiple flight emergencies in the span of a few days. Meanwhile, federal investigators are probing Boeing for the door plug blowout. But flying is still low-risk.

TITLE: Georgia on the mind of the Trump and Biden campaigns as the key state holds primary
SUMMARY: Georgia is an important state for both former President Donald Trump and President Biden in 2024. It's also a state with the clearest examples of the obstacles each faces in his path to victory.

TITLE: A Maui chef's lifeline: his restaurant as the island recovers from Lahaina wildfires
SUMMARY: Thousands remain displaced after last year's deadly wildfire on west Maui. Among those who lost almost everything was a chief and his family. But they're determined to keep their restaurant running.

TITLE: As they wait for a truce, Palestinians and Israeli hostage families voice their agony
SUMMARY: The prospect of a cease-fire in Gaza offers hope, but as talks drag on, Palestinians and the families of Israeli hostages say the wait for a breakthrough is bringing frustration and pain.

TITLE: Why NASA wants human guinea pigs to test out Martian living
SUMMARY: Mars is seen as the next frontier in space exploration. But given the hostile environment on the red planet, is there a good reason why?

TITLE: Aid ship sets sail from Cyprus to Gaza, where hunger is worsening 5 months into war
SUMMARY: An aid ship loaded with some 200 tons of food set sail Tuesday from Cyprus to Gaza, the international charity behind the effort said.

TITLE: After 6 months in space and a fiery return over the U.S., NASA's Crew-7 is back home
SUMMARY: The four crewmembers spent a half-year on the International Space Station conducting dozens of experiments and science research. NASA's Crew-8 mission relieved them on the orbital outpost last week.

TITLE: It's Equal Pay Day. Women earn 84 cents for every dollar men make — or even less
SUMMARY: Women working full-time, year-round jobs earn 84 cents for every dollar men make, and part-timers make even less. Women have to work well into March before they earn what men made the year before.

TITLE: Every new mom in this U.S. city is now getting cash aid for a year
SUMMARY: Flint, Mich., aims to be a model for wiping out deep poverty during a crucial time for child development. The new benefits start during pregnancy to encourage prenatal care.

TITLE: Feeling ragey? Don't bury your anger, process it. Here's how
SUMMARY: We're often taught to repress our feelings and behave nicely. But anger has a biological purpose, and psychologists say it's healthier to embrace it. Here are four steps for working with anger.

TITLE: What Biden said during classified document interviews, according to the transcript
SUMMARY: The 258-page transcript paints a more nuanced portrait of the president than was described in Robert Hur's report. The most confusing part concerned the timeline surrounding the death of his son Beau.

TITLE: Haiti's leader agrees to resign; It's primary day in Georgia
SUMMARY: Amid gang violence and international pressure, Haitian Prime Minister Ariel Henry says he will resign once a transitional council is named. Primary voting ends in the battleground state of Georgia.

TITLE: A tourist in India posted a video saying she was gang raped. A national debate ensued
SUMMARY: The woman and her husband were camping in a remote area. They posted a video describing the attack on social media, triggering a national discussion about sexual assault and justice.

TITLE: Special counsel Hur is testifying on Capitol Hill in Biden classified documents probe
SUMMARY: Special counsel Robert Hur is set to testify before the House Judiciary Committee on his investigation into President Biden's handling of classified documents.

TITLE: John Barnett, Boeing whistleblower who raised alarm over plane quality, is found dead
SUMMARY: John Barnett made international headlines when he went public with his story, saying he wouldn't trust planes made in North Charleston, S.C., to be safe and airworthy.

TITLE: Biden meets with the Teamsters today. But don't expect an endorsement any time soon
SUMMARY: The 1.3 million member union is in every battleground state. Former President Donald Trump has also met with the organization and made his pitch. But don't expect an endorsement any time soon.

TITLE: Interview transcript shows more nuance on Biden's memory than special counsel report
SUMMARY: The 258-page transcript paints a more nuanced portrait of the president than was described in Robert Hur's report. The most confusing part concerned the timeline surrounding the death of his son Beau.

TITLE: Old power lines plus climate change mean a growing risk of utilities starting fires
SUMMARY: Texas investigators say the largest wildfire in state history appears to be caused by a power line. Aging utility infrastructure ups the risk of starting wildfires as the climate heats up.

TITLE: Special counsel Hur defends Biden classified documents probe before Congress
SUMMARY: Special counsel Hur is defending his work in the Biden classified documents probe in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee;

TITLE: RNC sees major cuts to staff as new, Trump-backed leadership takes over
SUMMARY: More than 60 people were fired, including senior staff in the political data and communications departments, according to a person familiar with the layoffs.

TITLE: Boeing whistleblower John Barnett, who raised alarm over plane quality, is found dead
SUMMARY: John Barnett made international headlines when he went public with his story, saying he wouldn't trust planes made in North Charleston, S.C., to be safe and airworthy.

TITLE: A new Kobe Bryant statue has multiple errors. It's not the first memorial with typos
SUMMARY: Officials say they will correct the misspellings on a recent 19-foot bronze statue of the late Kobe Bryant at Crypto.com Arena. Several other prominent monuments have had similar issues.

TITLE: Eric Carmen, singer-songwriter of 'All By Myself' and 'Hungry Eyes,' dies at 74
SUMMARY: The pop crooner was behind some of the biggest power ballads of the 1970s and '80s. His wife said he died in his sleep.

TITLE: Special counsel Hur defended Biden classified documents probe before Congress
SUMMARY: Special counsel Hur defended his work in the Biden classified documents probe in a hearing before the House Judiciary Committee.

TITLE: Biden and Trump could clinch presidential nominations after tonight's elections
SUMMARY: President Biden and former President Donald Trump could both earn enough delegates to officially become their parties' presidential nominees after Tuesday's elections.

TITLE: Controversial influencer Andrew Tate will be extradited to U.K., after Romania trial
SUMMARY: The self-proclaimed misogynist — who faces several allegations of sexual assault in multiple jurisdictions — will be extradited to the U.K. after facing trial in Romania.

TITLE: Middle East crisis — explained
SUMMARY: The conflict between Israel and Palestinians — and other groups in the Middle East — goes back decades. These stories provide context for current developments and the history that led up to them.

TITLE: NAACP urges Black athletes to avoid Florida public universities over anti-DEI policies
SUMMARY: The storied civil rights organization accused Gov. Ron DeSantis of having "waged war on Black America" by championing legislation to dismantle diversity and inclusion efforts at public schools.

TITLE: Biden has just clinched the 2024 Democratic presidential nomination
SUMMARY: President Biden has become the 2024 Democratic nominee, following a primary win in Georgia, per AP. Former President Donald Trump could also officially secure the GOP nomination tonight.

TITLE: Trump and Biden clinch 2024 presidential nominations
SUMMARY: The general election rematch between former President Donald Trump and President Biden is now official. Both men have now secured the required delegates to be their respective party's nominee.

TITLE: What we know about long COVID — from brain fog to physical fatigue
SUMMARY:
"Long COVID has affected every part of my life," said Virginia resident Rachel Beale said at a recent Senate hearing. "I wake up every day feeling tired, nauseous and dizzy. I immediately start planning when I can lay down again."

Beale is far from alone. Many of her experiences have been echoed by others dealing with long COVID. It's a constellation of debilitating symptoms that range from brain fog and intense physical fatigue to depression and anxiety.

But there's new, promising research that sheds light onto some symptoms. NPR health correspondent Will Stone talks with Short Wave host Regina G. Barber about the state of long COVID research — what we know, what we don't and when we can expect treatments or even cures for it.

Have more COVID questions you want us to cover? Email us at shortwave@npr.org — we'd love to hear from you.

TITLE: In the world of medicine, race-based diagnoses are still very real
SUMMARY: We've probably said it a hundred times on <em>Code Switch —

TITLE: The top strategist of late Russian opposition leader Navalny is attacked in Lithuania
SUMMARY: A Navalny spokesperson said the assailant smashed a window of Leonid Volkov's car, sprayed tear gas into his eyes and started hitting him with a hammer in Lithuania's capital.

TITLE: Pentagon to give Ukraine $300 million in weapons
SUMMARY: The Pentagon will rush about $300 million in weapons to Ukraine after finding some cost savings in its contracts, even though the military remains deeply overdrawn.

TITLE: A radical Mideast proposal: What if the U.S. recognized a Palestinian state now?
SUMMARY: The formula for resolving the Israeli-Palestinian conflict has long called for negotiating a Palestinian state. What if that were reversed and a state were declared first and then negotiated later?

TITLE: Authors push back on the growing number of AI 'scam' books on Amazon
SUMMARY: Authors say that the proliferation of AI-generated books can lead customers into buying the wrong book on Amazon and that these books can harm authors' sales numbers and reputations.

TITLE: Robert F. Kennedy Jr. wants to get on the ballot in all 50 states. It won't be easy
SUMMARY: To run for president as an independent candidate, conspiracy theorist Robert F. Kennedy Jr. needs to get on ballots, a complicated and expensive state-by-state undertaking.

TITLE: Content creators blast a potential TikTok ban
SUMMARY: The House is gearing up for a Wednesday vote on legislation that could lead to a ban on one of the most widely used apps in the world, with an estimated 170 million users in the United States alone.

TITLE: C-e-a-s-e and desist: 'The New York Times' goes after Wordle spinoffs
SUMMARY: Hundreds of GitHub users were notified after the media outlet sent takedown notices to coders it believed violated its copyright on the game.

TITLE: Conservatives are warning about noncitizens voting. It's a myth with a long history
SUMMARY: The false notion that undocumented immigrants affect federal elections has a long history. But this year, due in part to rising migration at the U.S. southern border, the idea could have new potency.

TITLE: A stargazer's guide to solar eclipse glasses
SUMMARY: From why you need them to how to check if they're legit, here's a guide to everything you need to know about eclipse glasses so you can view next month's rare total solar eclipse safely.

TITLE: The lowly sea cucumber may be helping to protect coral reefs against disease
SUMMARY: The pickle-shaped bottom feeders may reduce the amount of microbes on the seafloor that could potentially sicken coral, scientists suggest

TITLE: Congress mulls another TikTok ban; An aid ship heads to Gaza as hunger worsens
SUMMARY: The House will vote on a bill that would force TikTok to divest from its Chinese parent company or else face a ban from U.S. app stores. The first ship carrying food to Gaza is on its way from Cyprus.

TITLE: House expected to approve bill forcing TikTok to either be sold or face a U.S. ban
SUMMARY: The House is set to vote Wednesday on a bill that would force parent company ByteDance to sell TikTok or face a ban of the social media app on U.S. devices.

TITLE: Why the House seems ready to ban TikTok and what could come next
SUMMARY: The House is set to vote Wednesday on a bill that would force parent company ByteDance to sell TikTok or face a ban of the social media app on U.S. devices.

TITLE: Trump and Biden clinch 2024 presidential nominations
SUMMARY: The general election rematch between former President Donald Trump and President Biden is now official. Both men have now secured the required delegates to be their respective party's nominee.

TITLE: In 'Unshrinking,' a writer argues that the medicalization of fatness leads to bias
SUMMARY: Kate Manne tried to shrink her body for years before embracing her size as part of a "natural, normal human variation." She says the fight against fat phobia must start in the doctor's office.

TITLE: Middle East crisis — explained
SUMMARY: The conflict between Israel and Palestinians — and other groups in the Middle East — goes back decades. These stories provide context for current developments and the history that led up to them.

TITLE: 68 orphans were evacuated from Gaza to the West Bank, enraging Israel's far right
SUMMARY: The children were moved out of Rafah by the charity SOS Children's Villages International with the help of the German government. But the transfer has sparked anger among some hardliners in Israel.

TITLE: Congress mulls another TikTok ban; An aid ship heads to Gaza as hunger worsens
SUMMARY: The House will vote on a bill that would force TikTok to divest from its Chinese parent company or else face a ban from U.S. app stores. The first ship carrying food to Gaza is on its way from Cyprus.

TITLE: Why the House voted to ban TikTok and what could come next
SUMMARY: The House voted overwhelmingly Wednesday to approve a bill that would force parent company ByteDance to sell TikTok or face a ban of the social media app on U.S. devices.

TITLE: Everything you need to know about solar eclipse glasses before April 8
SUMMARY: From why you need them to how to check if they're legit, here's a guide to eclipse glasses so you can view next month's rare total solar eclipse safely.

TITLE: Paul Alexander, forced into an iron lung by polio in 1952, dies at 78
SUMMARY: "More than anything, I believe he would want others to know they are capable of great things," Alexander's friend Christopher Ulmer told NPR.

TITLE: How bad is maternal mortality in the U.S.? A new study says it's been overestimated
SUMMARY: The peer-reviewed study in the American Journal of Obstetrics and Gynecology says a pregnancy checkbox on national death certificates inflates the death rate.

TITLE: Oil and gas companies emit more climate-warming methane than EPA reports
SUMMARY: Oil and gas drillers are releasing more climate-warming methane than the government estimates, a new study shows.

TITLE: 9 energizing ideas that can put a spring in your step
SUMMARY: Boost confidence, joy and add movement to your life with these creative and science-backed actions.

TITLE: The first Black pilot of a commercial airline has died at 89
SUMMARY: David E. Harris became the first Black pilot to fly for a commercial airline when American Airlines hired him in 1964. Announcing Capt. Harris' death, American's CEO called him a "trailblazer."

TITLE: The number of U.S. adults who identify as LGBTQ+ doubled in 12 years, new poll shows
SUMMARY: In 2023, 7.6% of U.S. adults said they align themselves with the LGBTQ+ community, compared to 3.5% in 2012, the first year Gallup collected such metrics. That figure has grown every year since 2012.

TITLE: Olivia Rodrigo concertgoers got a show — and free emergency contraceptives
SUMMARY: As part of an initiative for reproductive health care access, advocacy groups handed out emergency contraception pills and condoms to fans at the Olivia Rodrigo concert in St. Louis on Tuesday night.

TITLE: In 'Unshrinking,' a writer discusses coming out as fat and pushing back against bias
SUMMARY: Kate Manne tried to shrink her body for years before embracing her size as part of a "natural, normal human variation." She says the fight against fat phobia must start in the doctor's office.

TITLE: Judge in Georgia election interference case quashes some charges against Trump
SUMMARY: The judge overseeing the Georgia racketeering case against Donald Trump and his allies has quashed a number of charges related to soliciting officials to violate their oaths of office.

TITLE: With aid headed to Gaza, hurdles remain to getting food to its starving population
SUMMARY: U.N. food agency finally was able to deliver aid to northern Gaza, and efforts are afoot to bring relief by sea. But the challenges are many.

TITLE: Middle East crisis — explained
SUMMARY: The conflict between Israel and Palestinians — and other groups in the Middle East — goes back decades. These stories provide context for current developments and the history that led up to them.

TITLE: Elon Musk's giant Starship rocket is launching again. Here's what to expect
SUMMARY: The rocket is the largest ever built. It has yet to complete a full test flight, but the third time might be the charm.

TITLE: You're Not Imagining It; Shrinkflation Is Real
SUMMARY:
Here's one sign that shrinkflation is no longer just a topic for economics nerds.

Cookie Monster recently complained on social media that his favorite food was getting smaller. "Me hate shrinkflation!" the fuzzy blue monster declared. "Guess me going to have to eat double da cookies!"

President Biden promised to sign a bill banning it during his State of the Union address.

Shrinkflation isn't new.

It's been happening for years. But people seem to be paying more attention right now amidst high food prices and inflation. And the White House is clearly aware of that.

After years of rising prices, many Americans are fed up with paying more and getting less. Will the pendulum ever swing back?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Harris will visit an abortion clinic, a first for any president or vice president
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris is planning to tour a Minnesota abortion clinic during a trip to the Twin Cities on Thursday. It's believed to be a first for a vice president or president.

TITLE: Dollar Tree to close nearly 1,000 stores as it posts a fourth quarter loss
SUMMARY: Dollar Tree plans to close about 600 Family Dollar stores in the first half of this year and 370 Family Dollar and 30 Dollar Tree stores over the next several years.

TITLE: A Symphony of Resistance (Throwback)
SUMMARY:
In 2011, the world was shaken by the Arab Spring, a wave of "pro-democracy" protests that spread throughout the Middle East and North Africa. The effects of the uprisings reverberated around the world as regimes fell in some countries, and civil war began in others. This week, we revisit the years leading up to the Arab Spring and its lasting impact on three people who lived through it.

To access bonus episodes and listen to Throughline sponsor-free, subscribe to Throughline+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org/throughline.

TITLE: Waymo's robotaxi service set to expand into Los Angeles
SUMMARY: Waymo, part of Google's parent company, is responsible for the latest ride-share option. It started driving robotaxis in San Francisco last year. It also has them in Phoenix.

TITLE: Here are the concerns with artificial food dyes, as California weighs a ban in schools
SUMMARY: Six artificial food dyes and titanium dioxide would be banned in schools under a proposal in the state legislature. Critics say there isn't enough evidence to prove they're a health risk.

TITLE: After the fires, a Maui community tries a novel approach to keep homes in local hands
SUMMARY: As burned properties come up for sale in Lahaina, many worry outside developers will scoop them up. Some are turning to a tool that's helped other towns after a disaster: a community land trust.

TITLE: The House passed a TikTok ban bill. But is the app really a national security threat?
SUMMARY: National security officials have long warned about the dangers TikTok poses as long as it is owned by a Chinese company, but the threat remains theoretical.

TITLE: How 'fetal personhood' in Alabama's IVF ruling evolved from fringe to mainstream
SUMMARY: To those who have watched how certain elements of the anti-abortion campaign have gone from fringe to mainstream, the Alabama IVF decision is both validation and a warning of more shifts to come.

TITLE: Why Ireland is one of the most pro-Palestinian nations in the world
SUMMARY: One of the most pro-Palestinian nations in the world is not an Arab or Muslim country. It's not even in the Middle East. Polls show Ireland has some of the highest support for the Palestinians.

TITLE: In Portugal, an election results in uncertainty and the rise of the far right
SUMMARY: A lightly regarded Portuguese political party finds itself in a position to play kingmaker in the wake of national elections that failed to propel either of the two establishment parties into power.

TITLE: A simple blood test can detect colorectal cancer early, study finds
SUMMARY: At a time when colorectal cancer is rising, researchers say a blood test can detect 83% of people with the disease. If the FDA approves it the test would be another screening tool for early detection.

TITLE: Haiti's political transition faces challenges; EU approves AI regulation legislation
SUMMARY: Haitians describe "desolation" and "dread" as plans for a transitional government are tested. The EU has approved the first comprehensive framework for regulating AI.

TITLE: Indian judge says billion-dollar ayurvedic company has taken the public 'for a ride'
SUMMARY: The country's supreme court has temporarily banned Patanjali, a leading maker of ayurvedic products with ties to the prime minister, from advertising certain items due to a history of false claims.

TITLE: Delta-8, an unregulated form of THC, is popular among high school students
SUMMARY: Derived from hemp, it has similar effects to delta-9 THC, the main intoxicant in marijuana. It's fueling a rise in calls to poison control.

TITLE: An aid ship is en route to Gaza, in a test of a sea corridor for the war-torn enclave
SUMMARY: A humanitarian ship is piloting a new sea route to bring food to Gaza to help avert famine after five months of war and Israeli restrictions on aid.

TITLE: Former Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin says he's interested in buying TikTok
SUMMARY: Mnuchin said he's in touch with other investors to try to buy the popular social media app as lawmakers are seeking to force its Chinese owners to sell the business.

TITLE: Third time's the charm: SpaceX's massive Starship reaches space
SUMMARY: SpaceX has successfully conducted a test launch of its massive Starship rocket in a major success for company, which saw the rocket explode in two previous test flights

TITLE: Michael Knott, who changed the course of Christian rock, dies at 61
SUMMARY: An entire industry wouldn't exist without him, yet few know his name. In his songs, Knott challenged the faithful to examine their faults and hypocrisies.

TITLE: Chuck Schumer calls for new elections in Israel, breaking with Benjamin Netanyahu
SUMMARY: Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer, D-NY, called for new elections in Israel as the country continues its war with Hamas.

TITLE: 'How to Win an Information War' details fighting with — and against — propaganda
SUMMARY: Peter Pomerantsev co-founded a project recording Russian atrocities in Ukraine to combat Russian disinformation. His new book profiles a WWII propagandist who targeted the Nazi regime.

TITLE: 35 miles east of Long Island, the U.S. has its first large offshore wind farm
SUMMARY: New York Gov. Kathy Hochul went to Long Island to announce that the turbines are delivering clean power to the local electric grid, flipping a massive light switch to "turn on the future."

TITLE: Baseball-sized 'gorilla hail' hits Kansas and Missouri during severe storms
SUMMARY: Severe thunderstorms Wednesday evening produced huge chunks of hail in parts of Missouri and Kansas. "Gorilla hail" can create lots of damage and even has the potential to be fatal.

TITLE: West Point axed 'duty, honor, country' from its mission statement. Conservatives fumed
SUMMARY: The three iconic words remain the motto of the U.S. military academy. But an update to its mission statement, where the words had appeared for 26 years, has sparked outrage among conservatives online.

TITLE: Manhattan prosecutors open to a 30-day delay in Trump's criminal trial
SUMMARY: They said a delay would ensure that Trump's legal team has sufficient time to review a new tranche of materials in the case. Jury selection is scheduled to begin March 25.

TITLE: Biden opposes Nippon Steel takeover of U.S. Steel. It's an issue in some swing states
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump has already said he would block the deal between U.S. Steel and its Japanese rival. Now President Biden is speaking out about it, too.

TITLE: Pierce Brosnan is fined for leaving trail in Yellowstone National Park thermal area
SUMMARY: The James Bond actor pleaded guilty to stepping off a trail in a thermal area during a visit to Yellowstone. He was fined $500 and ordered to donate $1,000 to a nonprofit that supports the park.

TITLE: American Library Association report says book challenges soared in 2023
SUMMARY: Overall, the number of individual titles challenged in both school and public libraries spiked by 65% — the highest level ever recorded by the ALA.

TITLE: Judge denies motion to dismiss charges against Trump in documents case
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump was in court in Florida where he's seeking dismissal of criminal charges related to classified documents he allegedly withheld and concealed from investigators.

TITLE: San Francisco Symphony music director Esa-Pekka Salonen resigns
SUMMARY: Citing creative differences with the orchestra's board, the famed Finnish conductor and composer plans to leave when his contract expires at the end of the 2025 season.

TITLE: James Crumbley, father of school shooter, found guilty of involuntary manslaughter
SUMMARY: A Michigan jury found James Crumbley was criminally responsible for the four murders his son, who was 15 at the time, committed at Oxford High School in 2021.

TITLE: Colorado snowstorm knocks out power for thousands
SUMMARY: The snowstorm also forced flight cancellations and shut down a highway that connects Denver to Colorado ski resorts for much of the day, stranding some people in their cars for hours.

TITLE: Family of slain Ukrainian journalist sues Fox News, alleging a cover up
SUMMARY: Oleksandra Kuvshynova's parents say Fox News put their daughter in harm's way unnecessarily, then promoted a false account of her death. They also point blame at a reporter who was with her that day.

TITLE: A funeral home worker tracked down a family — and uncovered a decades-old secret
SUMMARY: A worker at a funeral home managed to locate the family members of an ailing woman. She didn't realize she was uncovering a family secret that went back to the 1940s.

TITLE: War has forced half of Gaza into Rafah. Palestinians there are at a breaking point
SUMMARY: Five months into the war, about half of Gaza's population has been squeezed into Rafah. The governorate was crowded before the war, but mass displacement has made it the site of a spiraling crisis.

TITLE: This week's quiz includes typos and questionable edits (please don't fire me)
SUMMARY: This week brought us an utterly predictable presidential deathmatch and reminded us to not stare directly at the sun. But there were also some surprises. Were you paying attention?

TITLE: Former LA Dodger Steve Garvey aims for the wall in U.S. Senate race
SUMMARY: When the former baseball star won a runoff spot for California's open senate seat, he reminded supporters that his primary victory was only "the first game of a doubleheader."

TITLE: What to know about Russia's election, sure to hand Putin another term
SUMMARY: Putin forever? Russia's president goes into this week's election with no serious contenders, cementing his already quarter-century hold on the Kremlin through at least 2030.

TITLE: They were injured at the Super Bowl parade. A month later, they feel forgotten
SUMMARY: A Kansas family remembers Valentine's Day as the start of panic attacks, life-altering trauma and waking to nightmares of gunfire. They wonder how they'll recover from the Kansas City parade shooting.

TITLE: Police in Ohio confirm 2 dead from storm system that damaged homes and businesses
SUMMARY: A fierce storm system unleashed suspected twisters and damaged homes and businesses in parts of Ohio and Kentucky on Thursday. Indiana State Police said there are "many significant injuries" there.

TITLE: Family of slain Ukrainian journalist sues Fox News, alleging a cover-up
SUMMARY: Oleksandra Kuvshynova's parents say Fox News put their daughter in harm's way unnecessarily, then promoted a false account of her death. They also point blame at a reporter who was with her that day.

TITLE: Her insurer stopped approving her medicine that worked. Will a new state law help?
SUMMARY: When a law passed this January takes effect next year, health insurance companies will have three days — or sometimes 24 hours — to decide on prior authorization.

TITLE: A glimpse of the chaos in Haiti, a country reeling with effectively no leader
SUMMARY: NPR reports from inside Haiti, as gangs unleash another day of violence in the country's capital. It comes as political groups try to form a transitional council.

TITLE: Putin all but certain to win Russia's election; Chicago to begin evicting migrants
SUMMARY: Russians are voting in a three-day election Putin is almost certain to win. Chicago will begin evicting migrants from shelters tomorrow when a 60-day shelter limit goes into effect.

TITLE: This week's quiz has no shady edits (unlike a certain royal photo)
SUMMARY: This week brought us an utterly predictable presidential deathmatch and reminded us to not stare directly at the sun. But there were also some surprises. Were you paying attention?

TITLE: Suspected tornadoes kill at least 3 in Ohio as severe storms tear through central U.S.
SUMMARY: Severe storms with probable tornadoes tore through several states, damaging homes and businesses and killing at least three people, with more bodies likely to be discovered, authorities said.

TITLE: Pierce Brosnan is fined for leaving trail in Yellowstone National Park thermal area
SUMMARY: The James Bond actor pleaded guilty to stepping off a trail in a thermal area during a visit to Yellowstone. He was fined $500 and ordered to donate $1,000 to a nonprofit that supports the park.

TITLE: 'Games made by soulless machines': Tech sparks debate over AI stories in video games
SUMMARY: Is the future of artificial intelligence in video games playing out in a cyberpunk ramen bar? Tech companies would like you to think so, but game writers aren't so sure.

TITLE: Gov. Ron DeSantis' war on 'woke' appears to be losing steam in Florida
SUMMARY: A federal court recently blocked most of a key DeSantis measure, the Stop WOKE Act. Courts have ruled against a number of the governor's conservative initiatives.

TITLE: As Trump continues to remake RNC in his image, new memo outlines what that looks like
SUMMARY: Chair Michael Whatley sent a memo to staff emphasizing the initiatives he wants to see bolstered at the GOP's main campaigning operation now that Trump secured the delegates to receive the nomination.

TITLE: Georgia judge rules that Fani Willis can remain on Trump case if Wade steps aside
SUMMARY: The decision bolsters the chances that 15 defendants including former President Donald Trump will face trial this year for attempting to overturn the 2020 election result.

TITLE: Her insurer stopped approving her medicine that worked. Will a new state law help?
SUMMARY: When a law passed this January takes effect next year, health insurance companies will have three days — or sometimes 24 hours — to decide on prior authorization.

TITLE: Percival Everett gives Mark Twain's classic story about Huck a new voice in 'James'
SUMMARY: Prolific writer Percival Everett often skewers different corners of American society. His latest novel James is written from the point of view of the character Jim, from Mark Twain's Huckleberry Finn

TITLE: Remembering longtime magazine editor William Whitworth
SUMMARY: Whitworth, who died March 8, worked at The New Yorker from 1966 to 1980, as both a writer and editor, and later served as editor-in-chief of The Atlantic Monthly. Originally broadcast in 2001.

TITLE: A major settlement could spell an end to 6% real estate commissions
SUMMARY: The National Association of Realtors has reached a national settlement that could change the way real estate agents are paid. Critics say the current system keeps commissions artificially high.

TITLE: What is the breast cancer calculator actor Olivia Munn suggested after her mastectomy?
SUMMARY: The questionnaire on the National Cancer Institute's website estimates lifetime risk and five-year risk based on factors known to increase the likelihood of a woman developing breast cancer.

TITLE: Wade resigns after judge makes it a condition for Fani Willis to remain on Trump case
SUMMARY: The decision bolsters the chances that 15 defendants including former President Donald Trump will face trial this year for attempting to overturn the 2020 election result.

TITLE: Trump's New York trial is delayed until mid-April
SUMMARY: The delay in the hush money case would allow the former president's legal team to review new records that could be related to the case.

TITLE: Mike Pence ran with Donald Trump in 2016 and 2020. In 2024, he won't even endorse him
SUMMARY: The former vice president ran against Trump for the 2024 Republican nomination before dropping out ahead of any primary contests. He said Trump has moved too far away from conservative values.

TITLE: What happened to Nex Benedict?
SUMMARY: Benedict was attacked at their Oklahoma high school, and found dead at home the next day. The medical examiner's office says the nonbinary 16-year-old died by suicide. Their family has questions.

TITLE: NATO Positions Itself For War
SUMMARY:
When Russia's war in Ukraine began over two years ago, neighboring countries feared that they could be next.

And NATO asked itself - was it prepared to defend its territory if war arrived on its doorstep?

The answer was no.

So, its military chief decided it was time to ramp up NATO's strategy and revive its military headquarters.

And for the first time this spring, NATO will exercise brand new war plans to prepare for the worst.

The plan comes as Donald Trump makes another run at the White House, and expresses skepticism about NATO along the way. Can NATO take on Russia if American support for the alliance doesn't hold?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Karaoke inventor Shigeichi Negishi dies at 100
SUMMARY: Negishi was in his 40s when he came up with the idea of prototyping a mass-produced, coin-operated karaoke machine, branded "Sparko Box" in 1967.

TITLE: Is a United Ireland on the Horizon?
SUMMARY: The island of Ireland is divided into the Northern part, which is part of the UK and the independent Republic of Ireland to the south. But a political party is poised to take power in both places and it has pledged to make the border disappear.

TITLE: 'This is not a time to get sick,' says a doctor in Haiti on the health-care crisis
