SUMMARY: The unrest has dealt a devastating blow to health care. Staff face the possibility of attack and abduction. Patients could lose their lives en route — or in a hospital where services are curtailed.

TITLE: Flanked by Fat Joe, Harris urges DEA to 'get to it' on its marijuana review
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris framed marijuana reform as a racial justice issue. It's also something that polls well with young voters.

TITLE: Supreme Court again refuses to intervene in drag show controversy
SUMMARY: It was the second time the court has refused to step into a drag controversy this term.

TITLE: Supreme Court issues first of many expected decisions on social media
SUMMARY: The court laid down guidelines for the lower courts to use in assessing the facts in similar cases.

TITLE: Uber and Lyft threaten to halt operations in Minneapolis over minimum wage law
SUMMARY: After a minimum wage law gets passed for a second time in the Twin Cities, the ride-hail companies vow to put up a fight.

TITLE: Wendy Williams' dementia was blatantly exploited by the docuseries, a complaint says
SUMMARY: A newly unsealed complaint filed in New York by Williams' guardian, Sabrina Morrissey, argues that the former TV talk show host was "incapable" of agreeing to the Lifetime documentary.

TITLE: RBG's family condemns the selection of recipients of an award named in her honor
SUMMARY: The Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Leadership Award was created to honor women who have created positive change in society. RBG's family says this year's change in selection criteria betrays her legacy.

TITLE: An older Boeing plane found with missing panel after landing in Oregon
SUMMARY: A post-flight inspection revealed a missing panel on an Boeing 737-800 that had just arrived at its destination in southern Oregon on Friday after flying from San Francisco, officials said.

TITLE: Hong Kong jails 12 people for storming the legislature during 2019 protests
SUMMARY: Hundreds of protesters swarmed into the legislature the night of July 1, 2019 at the height of the anti-government protests.

TITLE: This medieval astrolabe has both Arabic and Hebrew markings. Here's what it means
SUMMARY: This discovery sheds new light on the rich history of scholarship and intellectual exchange between Muslims, Jews and Christians during a time of Muslim rule in medieval Spain.

TITLE: How IVF is complicating Republicans' abortion messaging
SUMMARY: For years, Republicans pushed "life at conception." IVF is complicating that message as GOP lawmakers struggle to agree on a path forward.

TITLE: Bolsonaro presented plan to reverse 2022 election, Brazilian military leaders say
SUMMARY: Testimonies of two former military commanders to police include the first direct mentions of Jair Bolsonaro as actively participating in a conspiracy to ignore the results of the 2022 election.

TITLE: The eclipse gives astronomy clubs an opportunity to shine
SUMMARY: From Texas to Maine, they're teaching people how to enjoy the spectacle safely. Some will hand out glasses or answer questions at events. Others plan to take their own advice — and get outta town.

TITLE: Haitians have learned to persevere through the worst crises, often with humor
SUMMARY: Haiti is coming back to life after violent gangs took over most of the capital and the prime minister became stranded abroad. Some are even laughing it off.

TITLE: Who is Mohammad Mustafa, the new prime minister of the Palestinian Authority?
SUMMARY: Mustafa was appointed by Palestinian President Mahmoud Abbas in a move seen as an attempt to appease U.S. demands for reform.

TITLE: Caitlin Clark, Connecticut, cowboy hats: Here's what to watch for on Selection Sunday
SUMMARY: Can the Iowa sensation finally win a ring? Will UConn repeat? Who could be this year's Cinderella? With March Madness around the corner, here's a preview of what to watch for on Selection Sunday.

TITLE: A Florida man who refused to sell his home to a developer now lives in the shadows
SUMMARY: Orlando Capote has been engaged in a two-decade struggle against developers and the city of Coral Gables to save his family's home. But his success comes with a price.

TITLE: Haiti's prime minister steps down, leaving a power vacuum amid mounting violence
SUMMARY: The Haitian prime minister has agreed to step down in an attempt to quell violence there. But several obstacles remain to ensure a peaceful transition of power to new leadership.

TITLE: At least 3 people dead in Pennsylvania suburb shootings, suspect sought
SUMMARY: The shootings took place on Saturday morning in two sections of Falls Township. A manhunt is currently underway.

TITLE: 'Quiet on Set' explores allegations of abuse, toxic behavior at Nickelodeon
SUMMARY: A new documentary series reveals the disturbing shadows behind the bright cheeriness of children's television.

TITLE: Suspect in Pennsylvania suburb shootings has barricaded himself in a Trenton home
SUMMARY: Officials said the 26-year-old suspect killed three people and assaulted one other woman in Falls Township, Pa. before fleeing to Trenton, N.J.

TITLE: Suspect in Pennsylvania suburb shootings is arrested in Trenton, police say
SUMMARY: Officials said the 26-year-old suspect killed three people and assaulted one other woman in Falls Township, Pa., before fleeing to Trenton, N.J.

TITLE: Trump says some migrants are 'not people', and warns of 'bloodbath' if he loses
SUMMARY: Former President Trump claimed he will protect Social Security and warned of a "bloodbath" in the auto industry if he loses the election at a rally for Senate candidate Bernie Moreno in Ohio.

TITLE: Photographer David Johnson, who chronicled San Francisco's Black culture, dies at 97
SUMMARY: Johnson studied with Ansel Adams in the 1940s and became known as one of the foremost photographers of San Francisco's Black urban culture.

TITLE: Russians cast final ballots in election preordained to extend Vladimir Putin's rule
SUMMARY: Russian President Vladimir Putin is poised to extend nearly a quarter century of rule for six more years on Sunday after wrapping up an election that gave voters no real alternatives.

TITLE: A volcano in Iceland is erupting for the fourth time in 3 months
SUMMARY: A volcano in Iceland erupted Saturday evening for the fourth time in three months, sending orange jets of lava into the night sky.

TITLE: Biden jokes that one presidential candidate is mentally unfit — and it's not him
SUMMARY: President Biden was speaking at the annual Gridiron Club and Foundation Dinner, the first time he has attended during his presidency. President Kamala Harris and many other big names were there too.

TITLE: Plan to watch the eclipse from a wild mountain summit? Be ready for harsh conditions
SUMMARY: Outdoor groups and state and local officials in northern parts of the northeastern US worry that a surge of eclipse-watchers could overwhelm backcountry first responders.

TITLE: Q&A: Author of 'Bottled: How Coca-Cola Became African' on Coke's surprising history
SUMMARY: How did the soda giant from America come to be seen as "local" in Africa? And what has the impact been on the continent for worse and for better?

TITLE: The 'devil comet' is visible in the night sky, and is sticking around for the eclipse
SUMMARY: Known as 12P/Pons-Brooks, the rarely seen comet prone to colorful outbursts could soon be viewed without a telescope or binoculars.

TITLE: Russians crowded polling places in an apparent protest as Putin is set to extend rule
SUMMARY: Russian President Vladimir Putin is poised to extend nearly a quarter century of rule for six more years on Sunday after wrapping up an election that gave voters no real alternatives.

TITLE: Jessie Diggins is a U.S. cross-country ski powerhouse after 2nd World Cup win
SUMMARY: Jessie Diggins, age 32, won her first Olympic gold medal in 2018 in South Korea and has now captured two World Cup titles, blowing past European skiers who typically dominate cross-country skiing.

TITLE: A family found centuries-old Japanese art stolen during WWII in their attic
SUMMARY: Troves of artifacts were stolen from Japan during the Battle of Okinawa in World War II. Over 20 pieces of looted items were found in the attic of a Massachusetts home.

TITLE: Putin extends his rule in highly orchestrated vote even as Russians quietly protest
SUMMARY: Russian President Vladimir Putin is poised to extend nearly a quarter century of rule for six more years on Sunday after wrapping up an election that gave voters no real alternatives.

TITLE: Putin basks in election win that was never in doubt even as Russians quietly protest
SUMMARY: Russian President Vladimir Putin will extend nearly a quarter century of rule for six more years after wrapping up an election that gave voters no real alternatives.

TITLE: First charter flight with U.S. citizens fleeing Haiti lands in Miami
SUMMARY: More than 30 U.S. citizens were on the government-chartered flight, officials said in a statement. It later arrived at the Miami International Airport.

TITLE: Let the madness begin: 3 things to watch at the NCAA basketball tournaments
SUMMARY: With NCAA brackets formed, the college basketball tournaments dubbed March Madness because of its drama begin this week. Here are some highlights to watch for as the men's and women's games begin.

TITLE: Christine Blasey Ford aims to own her story with 'One Way Back'
SUMMARY: In an interview with NPR, Ford says it was only a couple of years ago that she felt ready to revisit how her life was upended by Brett Kavanaugh's rise to a position on the U.S. Supreme Court.

TITLE: From anxiety to cancer, the evidence against ultra-processed food piles up
SUMMARY: Americans consume more than half their daily calories from ultra-processed food. A new study finds consuming lots of this food is linked to a higher risk of many diseases.

TITLE: Watching a solar eclipse without the right filters can cause eye damage. Here's why
SUMMARY: When the April 8 solar eclipse draws eyes upward, having proper solar filters and solar eclipse glasses is essential to avoid potentially permanent eye damage, doctors say.

TITLE: In Tuesday's 'primary', Arizona's independent voters don't get much of a say
SUMMARY: Arizona holds a presidential preference election to choose how its delegates will be awarded. That means independents don't get to vote - in a state where they are a third of the electorate.

TITLE: Supreme Court examines whether government can combat disinformation online
SUMMARY: The plaintiffs in the lawsuit are Missouri, Louisiana and five individuals who were either banned from social media during the pandemic or whose posts, they say, were not prominently featured.

TITLE: What to know as India sets elections for April
SUMMARY: India goes to polls in a month in the world's largest elections. Here are three things to know about the contest that could see Prime Minister Narendra Modi winning a third term.

TITLE: Israel's military launched an overnight raid on Gaza's largest hospital
SUMMARY: The Israeli military said it was "operating to thwart terrorist activity" at Al-Shifa Hospital. The Gaza Ministry of Health says the raid violates humanitarian law.

TITLE: After a quarter century in power, Russian President Putin isn't going anywhere
SUMMARY: Vladimir Putin won a landslide reelection victory, taking some 87% of all ballots following three days of voting derided by Russia's opposition and the West as neither free nor fair.

TITLE: Putin wins Russian election; Supreme Court tackles misinformation, censorship case
SUMMARY: Putin hails his victory in a Russian election with no real opposition. The Supreme Court will hear arguments in a case that examines whether the government can combat misinformation online.

TITLE: The improbable victory over smallpox holds lessons for health threats in 2024
SUMMARY: Physician Céline Gounder traveled to India and Bangladesh to bring back unheard stories from the eradication of smallpox,, many from health workers whose voices have been missing from the record.

TITLE: In Havana syndrome patients, NIH scientists find no physical trace of harm
SUMMARY: The mysterious ailments that became known as Havana syndrome left no physical evidence of injury or disease, according to two government studies.

TITLE: NASA astronaut Tom Stafford, famed for U.S.-Soviet orbital handshake, has died at 93
SUMMARY: Tom Stafford commanded the first Apollo mission to dock with a Soviet craft in space. He also served as commander of Apollo 10 - the dress rehearsal before NASA's first landing on the moon in 1969.

TITLE: An 'exvangelical' on loving, leaving and reporting on the culture of Christianity
SUMMARY: NPR correspondent Sarah McCammon grew up in a white evangelical church that taught her to never question her faith. She was later surprised by the community's overwhelming support for Donald Trump.

TITLE: The arts and crafts giant Joann files for bankruptcy, but stores will remain open
SUMMARY: Joann expects to receive $132 million in new financing as part of the bankruptcy<strong>

TITLE: Trump unable to post $450M bond in New York fraud case, his lawyers say
SUMMARY: Trump's lawyers say they've approached 30 companies through four brokers and none will accept his real estate holdings as a guarantee on the bond and argue the judgment is unconstitutionally high.

TITLE: 'James' revisits Huck Finn's traveling companion, giving rise to a new classic
SUMMARY: In a fever dream of a retelling, America's new reigning king of satire has turned a loved classic, <em>Adventures of Huckleberry Finn,

TITLE: Pregnant stingray Charlotte brings in traffic, business to North Carolina town
SUMMARY: Charlotte the stingray in a small North Carolina aquarium has been attracting visitors since she got pregnant without a mate. Businesses in Hendersonville are delighted by the influx.

TITLE: The U.S. bans most common form of asbestos, after decades of pushback from industry
SUMMARY: More than 50 other countries have already banned the substance, which has been known to lead to lung and ovarian cancer, mesothelioma and other deadly illnesses.

TITLE: Supreme Court seems wary of barring government contacts with social media
SUMMARY: At issue was a sweeping Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals decision that barred government officials from having contacts with social media platforms.

TITLE: RBG award ceremony canceled amid controversy over recipients
SUMMARY: Rupert Murdoch, Elon Musk and junk bond creator Michael Milken were among the recipients of the 2024 Ruth Bader Ginsburg Leadership Award.

TITLE: Despite bans in some states, more than a million abortions were provided in 2023
SUMMARY: That's the highest number in more than a decade, according to new research. Medication abortion made up a larger share of the total than in 2020.

TITLE: Pro-Trump attorney arrested after hearing over leaking Dominion documents
SUMMARY: Stefanie Lambert was arrested by U.S. Marshals after a hearing over possible sanctions against her for disseminating confidential emails from Dominion Voting Systems.

TITLE: United Airlines CEO tries to reassure customers that the airline is safe
SUMMARY: In a memo to customers, CEO Scott Kirby tried to reassure travelers that safety is the airline's top priority. He said the airline was already planning an extra day of training for pilots.

TITLE: Sports Illustrated will continue its print edition under a new publisher
SUMMARY: Minute Media took over on Monday after reaching a licensing agreement with Authentic Brands Group. What this means for the writers and others who produce Sports Illustrated remains to be seen.

TITLE: Rents are high and housing vouchers are hard to get. So Philly is giving renters cash
SUMMARY: The pilot program chose people on the city's long waitlist for housing vouchers to test how much direct cash payments can help. HUD, the federal housing agency, is interested in the possibility.

TITLE: Standard pregnancy care is now dangerously disrupted in Louisiana, report reveals
SUMMARY: A troubling new report from Louisiana shows how the state's abortion ban from 2022 is forcing doctors to delay or withhold medical care in ways that make pregnancy more dangerous.

TITLE: A 2024 March Madness vocabulary: How to sound like you know what you're talking about
SUMMARY: The NCAA basketball tournaments can be onslaught of unfamiliar names and terms enough to make any casual viewer nervous. We're here to help. (Except for NET. We can't explain NET.)

TITLE: New data shows it's gotten easier to vote in the U.S. since 2000
SUMMARY: Nearly 97% of voting-age U.S. citizens now live in a state with some form of early voting, according to a new report.

TITLE: A refugee family was going hungry — until a fast food manager risked his job to help
SUMMARY: After fleeing to the U.S. from the Soviet Union, River Adams was struggling to survive. Then a kind gesture changed everything.

TITLE: For the 68 orphans saved from Rafah, the road to recovery is likely to be a long one
SUMMARY: The 68 children without parental care are getting a reprieve from war, but children who experience armed conflict often face long-lasting impacts when it comes to their mental health and development.

TITLE: Young conservatives have grown up in Trump's Republican Party. Now, it's time to vote
SUMMARY: With nearly a decade on the national political stage, for some of the youngest eligible conservative voters this year, former President Donald Trump has been pivotal in their political upbringing.

TITLE: Hong Kong passes a new security law that toughens punishment of dissent
SUMMARY: Pro-Beijing lawmakers fast-tracked the legislation, with tough punishment for acts considered "external interference," insurrection and other offenses.

TITLE: In a pandemic milestone, the NIH ends guidance on COVID treatment
SUMMARY: The National Institutes of Health is sunsetting its influential COVID-19 treatment guidelines, used by millions of doctors to guide care during the pandemic.

TITLE: Famine in Gaza is 'imminent;' how Louisana's abortion ban changed maternal care
SUMMARY: People in Gaza are suffering from "catastrophic levels of hunger," according to a group of global experts. Doctors say Louisiana's abortion ban has led to big deviations in maternal care.

TITLE: Famine in northern Gaza is 'imminent,' warns the world's leading authority on hunger
SUMMARY: The Integrated Food Security Phase Classification issued a new report that concluded that the entire population in the Gaza Strip, more than 2 million, face serious food insecurity as war continues.

TITLE: Negotiators reach spending deal but timeline is tight to avoid shutdown
SUMMARY: The deal between negotiators from he House and the White House would fund the government until the end of the fiscal year, Sept. 30.

TITLE: So long, Stumpy. More than 150 of D.C.'s cherry trees have to go as water rises
SUMMARY: Washington, D.C.'s famous cherry blossoms hit peak bloom this week. This will be the last season for about 150 of the famous flowering trees — they'll soon be cut down to adjust to sea-level rise.

TITLE: Threats, debt and Trump's advances: 'Stormy' doc examines the life of Stormy Daniels
SUMMARY: A new documentary chronicles Stormy Daniels' legal battle with former President Donald Trump, and how it has changed her and her family.

TITLE: Reddit and YouTube must face a lawsuit over the radicalization of the Buffalo shooter
SUMMARY: The sites' algorithms served the 18-year-old with increasingly extremist content and led to the attack, the suit claims. On Monday, a judge rejected the companies' request to have the suit dismissed.

TITLE: After Laken Riley killing, a Georgia bill prompts fears of an immigration crackdown
SUMMARY: After the death of a nursing student, Georgia lawmakers are advancing a bill that would require local police to take on immigration enforcement. Opponents worry it will lead to profiling.

TITLE: Can a picture make you happy? We asked photographers and here's what they sent us
SUMMARY: For International Day of Happiness, photographers sent us pictures of a Syrian boy who finds joy caring for farm animals, Ukrainian girls on a trampoline, music lovers grooving to the blues and more,

TITLE: China Increasing Its Regional Power
SUMMARY: We go to two places where China has been exerting control. In Hong Kong, the government finally passed national security laws that are seen by critics as eroding civil liberties. In the Philippines, China's attempts to expand its territorial waters are being met with increasingly fiery rhetoric from senior officials.

TITLE: This senator tells NPR why he's leading a charge against TikTok — and what comes next
SUMMARY: The House has voted overwhelmingly to ban TikTok if its Chinese owners don't sell it. So now the future of the wildly popular social media platform is in the hands of the Senate.

TITLE: Here's what happens if Trump can't pay his $454 million bond
SUMMARY: The former president needs to arrange the money to comply with a New York Court ruling in less than a week, but says he can't find a company to put up the bond.

TITLE: Alabama lawmakers have approved a sweeping anti-diversity, equity and inclusion bill
SUMMARY: Republicans said they are guarding against programs that "deepen divisions," but Black Democrats called it an effort to roll back affirmative action programs that welcome and encourage diversity.

TITLE: Beyoncé's new album is inspired by backlash to her entering the country music genre
SUMMARY: With less than 10 days until the release of her new album, <em>Cowboy Carter,

TITLE: 2 Mississippi 'Goon Squad' deputies get yearslong sentences for torturing 2 Black men
SUMMARY: Hunter Elward was sentenced to about 20 years in prison, while Jeffrey Middleton was given a 17.5-year prison sentence. Four other ex-law enforcement officers will be sentenced later this week.

TITLE: Syphilis cases are rising in babies. Illinois has a potential solution
SUMMARY:
The number of newborns born with syphilis – a serious sexually transmitted infection – has skyrocketed 755% in the decade from 2012 to 2022. These babies have congenital syphilis, which is when the infection is passed from mother to baby during pregnancy. It can have dire consequences if left untreated.

The surge has left medical professionals and public health leaders scrambling for solutions to stop the spread. Today on the show, Chicago based journalist Indira Khera talks to Emily Kwong

TITLE: Trump-endorsed Senate candidate Bernie Moreno wins Ohio's GOP Primary
SUMMARY: The former car dealership owner beat out other primary challengers in a three-way race that tested former President Donald Trump's influence over Ohio GOP voters.

TITLE: Native Hawaiians aim to bring cultural sensitivity to Maui wildfire cleanup
SUMMARY: A delicate cleanup is underway in historic Lahaina on Maui. Cultural monitors are working closely with federal officials to assure the process protects cultural and archeological artifacts.

TITLE: People in Gaza are starving to death. 5 things to know about efforts to feed them
SUMMARY: Family clans in Gaza are being called on to help distribute aid to a starving population. Here's why it matters and how it could shape postwar security.

TITLE: Scientists studied how cicadas pee. Their insights could shed light on fluid dynamics
SUMMARY: Cicadas, and the way they urinate, offer a 'perfect' lab for understanding fluid dynamics at very small scales, researchers say

TITLE: Biden is giving Intel $8.5 billion for big semiconductor projects in 4 states
SUMMARY: President Biden is in the battleground state of Arizona to make the biggest announcement yet in his plan to bring semiconductor manufacturing back to America.

TITLE: Taxpayer-funded petrochemical plants are polluting communities, report finds
SUMMARY: A fleet of new plastics plants in the U.S. often release illegal levels of air pollution, even while receiving big tax breaks from state and local governments, the report found.

TITLE: How bad is Boeing's 2024 so far? Here's a timeline
SUMMARY: The aircraft-maker has faced renewed scrutiny this year, mostly going back to an incident when a rear door plug tore off a 737 Max 9. Things have compounded from there.

TITLE: They lampoon American corporate culture — and the internet is here for it
SUMMARY: The have been dubbed "cubicle comedians" — and some of the top creators raking in the views and likes are Black. For Black humor experts, that's no coincidence.

TITLE: U.S. drops in new global happiness ranking. One age group bucks the trend
SUMMARY: A new happiness report finds sharp declines in well-being among adolescents and young adults in the U.S. But the picture is better for people aged 60 and older, marking a striking generational divide.

TITLE: A divided town and politics vs. science: Michael Imperioli on why his play resonates
SUMMARY: Actor Michael Imperioli talks about his Broadway debut in <em>An Enemy of the People

TITLE: Texas immigration law put on hold; Mississippi cops who tortured 2 men sentenced
SUMMARY: A federal appeals court put a controversial Texas immigration law on hold hours after the Supreme Court allowed it to take effect. Six former Mississippi officers are sentenced for torturing two men.

TITLE: Ireland's prime minister, Leo Varadkar, has resigned
SUMMARY: Leo Varadkar announced he will step down as taoiseach, or prime minister, within weeks as soon as his Fine Gael party chooses a successor.

TITLE: A North Dakota ballot question could be a legal test case for political age limits
SUMMARY: Voters will decide whether to cap the age of candidates for the U.S. House or Senate, but the measure could face an uphill battle in court.

TITLE: What to know about SB 4, the Texas immigration law in the courts now
SUMMARY: The controversial new law would allow Texas law enforcement officers and judges to arrest and deport people in the country illegally, powers that have traditionally belonged to the federal government.

TITLE: Alabama's ban on DEI funding would restrict 'divisive concepts': What to know
SUMMARY: "Nothing in this act," the legislation states, ".... May be construed to inhibit or violate the First Amendment rights of any student or employee." But its opponents say it does just that.

TITLE: Jonathan Majors sued by ex-girlfriend Grace Jabbari for assault, battery, defamation
SUMMARY: The civil suit alleges that Majors was physically abusive towards Jabbari during incidents in Los Angeles, London and New York. The New York incident led to a criminal conviction for Majors.

TITLE: Vietnam's president resigns amid an intense anti-corruption campaign
SUMMARY: Vo Van Thuong is the second president to resign in two years, a worrying sign for political stability in Vietnam, a country that plays a key role in the middle of U.S.-China competition, analysts say.

TITLE: Federal Reserve holds interest rates steady, projects three rate cuts later this year
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady Wednesday, but policymakers signaled they still expect to start cutting rates later this year.

TITLE: Alabama governor signs ban on DEI funds that restricts 'divisive concepts' in schools
SUMMARY: "Nothing in this act," the legislation states, ".... May be construed to inhibit or violate the First Amendment rights of any student or employee." But its opponents say it does just that.

TITLE: A New York man's pet alligator was seized after 30 years. Now, he wants Albert back
SUMMARY: The owner of a 12-foot alligator recently seized by conservation officers is fighting for its return, saying the reptile he has shared a home with is a gentle giant that's no danger to anyone.

TITLE: Protesters in Cuba demand food and electricity as shortages bring hardship
SUMMARY: Hundreds of people have taken to the streets in recent days in the city of Santiago.

TITLE: 2 more former Mississippi 'Goon Squad' deputies sentenced in torture of 2 Black men
SUMMARY: Two more white ex-deputies were given significant yearslong prison sentences for their role in the 2023 racist torture of Michael Corey Jenkins and Eddie Parker during a no-warrant house raid.

TITLE: Protests in Cuba; Results of the World Happiness Report
SUMMARY:
In Cuba, protests over the weekend revealed frustrations over shortages of food and electricity as the country confronts a serious economic crisis. And the World Happiness Report tells of interesting differences in happiness between generations.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists around the world. Visit plus.npr.org

TITLE: What the collapse of salmon populations means for one Alaska family
SUMMARY: For Alaska Native communities along the Yukon River, fishing for salmon has always been a central part of life. But climate change is driving a massive collapse in salmon populations.

TITLE: M. Emmet Walsh, character actor from 'Blood Simple' and 'Blade Runner,' dies at 88
SUMMARY: Walsh died from cardiac arrest on Tuesday at a hospital in St. Albans, Vermont, his longtime manager Sandy Joseph said.

TITLE: California voters pass Proposition 1 to tackle the state's homelessness crisis
SUMMARY: Counties are now required to spend about two-thirds of the money from a news tax enacted on housing and programs for the homeless with serious mental illnesses or substance abuse problems.

TITLE: Idaho police search for escaped inmate and accomplice after ambush at Boise hospital
SUMMARY: A white supremacist Idaho prison gang member and an accomplice were on the loose after the accomplice staged an overnight attack to free the inmate as he was being moved from a hospital, police said.

TITLE: U.S. life expectancy rebounded in 2022 but COVID and drug overdoses were still deadly
SUMMARY: As the COVID pandemic faded in 2022, U.S. life expectancy rose by more than a year.  But the virus and drug overdoses spurred by fentanyl still took nearly 300,000 lives.

TITLE: These 4 stars are poised for a deep run in March Madness. Here's who to watch
SUMMARY: It's been a banner year for women's college basketball. Now, with March Madness upon us, we've talked with some of the star players ready to go big in the NCAA tournament.

TITLE: AI images and conspiracy theories are driving a push for media literacy education
SUMMARY: One of the nation's best-known media literacy events for high school students is expanding as demand grows for skills to identify deepfake images and online conspiracy theories.

TITLE: With a federal menthol ban looming, tobacco companies push 'non-menthol' substitutes
SUMMARY: The alternatives have a similar taste, packaging and marketing.  Anti-smoking activists say this is a way to get around state and federal bans.

TITLE: Rupert Murdoch and new 'Washington Post' CEO accused of cover-up in hacking scandal
SUMMARY: For the first time, the media titan was accused in court of knowing about a massive British tabloid-hacking scandal and helping to cover it up. The new leader of <em>The Washington Post

TITLE: Senators push to declassify TikTok intel and hold a public hearing ahead of ban vote
SUMMARY: Senators who attended a classified intelligence briefing focused on TikTok's influence say the public should get the same information. There's bipartisan support for a vote on a House bill on the app.

TITLE: This year it's a slow crawl to financial aid packages for students
SUMMARY: Colleges are just beginning to receive long-overdue FAFSA data. Meanwhile, students who've been accepted to college still face weeks before they receive aid offers.

TITLE: Alabama bans DEI initiatives; why users don't want Reddit to go public
SUMMARY: Alabama's governor signed into law a ban on DEI iniatives. Reddit debuts on the New York Stock Exchange this morning, and many users are not happy

TITLE: Congress unveils final spending package, as Friday midnight deadline looms
SUMMARY: The text accounting for about three-quarters of all federal discretionary spending was released early Thursday. Now, lawmakers are racing against the clock to vote before a Friday midnight deadline.

TITLE: Native Americans are hardest hit by syphilis surge
SUMMARY: Rates are so bad in Native American communities that public health experts have asked the federal government to declare an emergency. Inadequate prenatal care may be partly to blame.

TITLE: Reddit stock slated to start trading on NYSE
SUMMARY: Reddit, the San Francisco social media site that describes itself as "the front page of the internet," is debuting as a public stock on Thursday.

TITLE: The U.S. sues Apple, saying it abuses its power to monopolize the smartphone market
SUMMARY: The federal government accuses Apple of using its monopoly power to stomp out competitors and keep customers from switching phones.

TITLE: Meet Europe's first Black head of government — in Wales
SUMMARY: "I have the honor of becoming the first Black leader in any European country," he said upon taking office.

TITLE: First human transplant of a genetically modified pig kidney performed
SUMMARY: Surgeons at Massachusetts General Hospital said they transplanted a genetically edited pig kidney into a living human for the first time. The 62-year-old recipient has end-stage kidney disease.

TITLE: DeSantis is prepping for a wave of Haitian migrants. Advocates say he's grandstanding
SUMMARY: Florida's governor is deploying troops and law enforcement officers to intercept any migrants coming by boat from Haiti. Some Haitian-American leaders say it's more about politics than being prepared.

TITLE: The French bulldog sits, stays at the top of U.S. dog owners' hearts
SUMMARY: The dog popularly known as the Frenchie has held its crown as America's most popular dog breed for the second year in a row, according to the American Kennel Club.

TITLE: How the Chinese mafia came to control much of the illicit marijuana trade in the U.S.
SUMMARY: Marijuana has been legalized in some states, but ProPublica's

TITLE: Speaker Johnson to invite Israeli Prime Minister Netanyahu to address Congress
SUMMARY: Johnson's invitation comes as the debate about U.S. policy toward Israel has shifted since the war. GOP leaders are emphasizing their support for Netanyahu, and highlighting a divide among Democrats.

TITLE: Reddit stock starts trading 38% above initial public offering price
SUMMARY: Reddit, the San Francisco social media site that describes itself as "the front page of the internet," is debuting as a public stock on Thursday.

TITLE: Can America Win The Chips Manufacturing Race?
SUMMARY:
President Biden just awarded $8.5 billion dollars to the company Intel to help fund semiconductor factories in Arizona, Ohio, New Mexico, and Oregon.

At a visit to Intel's campus outside Phoenix this week, Biden said the money will help semiconductor manufacturing make a comeback in the US after 40 years.

The money for Intel comes from the CHIPS and Science Act, which was signed in 2022 to boost domestic semiconductor manufacturing. The administration's goal? For 20% of the world's leading-edge semiconductor chips to be made on American soil by 2030.

The US currently makes zero of the world's leading-edge semiconductor chips. By 2030, the Biden administration wants to make a fifth of them. So how will America get there?

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: More than 440,000 Starbucks mugs recalled after reports of a dozen injuries
SUMMARY: The holiday-inspired mugs were sold online and in stores such as Target and Walmart from November 2023 through January 2024. The injuries included severe burns, blisters and cuts on hands and fingers.

TITLE: Blinken will visit Israel at a moment of mounting tension over the war in Gaza
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Antony Blinken is expected to meet with Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu when he arrives in Israel on Friday. The White House wants Israel to pause plans for an attack on Rafah.

TITLE: Theft in translation? Dodgers fire Shohei Ohtani's interpreter over gambling scandal
SUMMARY: The Los Angeles Dodgers have fired Ippei Mizuhara. He gave conflicting accounts about paying large gambling debts, ESPN's Tisha Thompson tells NPR.

TITLE: Biden cancels nearly $6 billion in student debt for public service workers
SUMMARY: Because of past administrative failures, the some 78,000 affected public service workers such as nurses and teachers never got the relief they were entitled to under the law, Biden said.

TITLE: After decades of secrecy, the 'Ghost Army' is honored for saving U.S. lives in WWII
SUMMARY: The Ghost Army is credited with saving thousands of American lives and helping end WWII in Europe. But its contributions were kept secret for half a century. On Thursday, it won Congress' top honor.

TITLE: Carlee Russell pleads guilty, avoids jail after falsely reporting her own kidnapping
SUMMARY: During the sentencing, Judge David Carpenter suspended Russell's two six-month sentences, saying it would be a "waste of government resources" to put her in jail for her crime.

TITLE: A warm, dry spring has U.S. forecasters worried about the upcoming wildfire season
SUMMARY: States in the southern High Plains will be "quite vulnerable to high wildfire risk, especially during high wind events," said Jon  Gottschalck of the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration.

TITLE: A Window Into Life in Northern Gaza
SUMMARY:
We hear what life is like for three families in northern Gaza where finding food and water is a struggle and hundreds of thousands of people are facing starvation.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Hermès accused of antitrust violations by customers who tried to buy a Birkin bag
SUMMARY: Shoppers who tried to get their hands on the status satchel claim the French luxury house will only sell its coveted Birkin bag to customers with "a sufficient purchase history."

TITLE: Sen. Menendez, who is facing corruption charges, won't seek reelection as a Democrat
SUMMARY: But the New Jersey Democrat said he hopes to be exonerated and "pursue my candidacy as an independent Democrat in a general election."

TITLE: Oklahoma prosecutors will not press charges in Nex Benedict case
SUMMARY: Nex, a nonbinary teen, died by suicide after a high school fight. The Tulsa County District Attorney says the fight was mutual and there's not enough evidence to press charges.

TITLE: Friday's Mega Millions jackpot soars to nearly $1 billion. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Since three months have passed without a winner, the Mega Millions jackpot has grown to an estimated $977 million. The jackpot ranks as the 10th largest in U.S. lottery history

TITLE: Most animals don't go through menopause. So why do these whales?
SUMMARY:
Across the animal kingdom, menopause is something of an evolutionary blip. We humans are one of the few animals to experience it. But Sam Ellis, a researcher in animal behavior, argues that this isn't so surprising. "The best way to propagate your genes is to get as many offspring as possible into the next generation," says Ellis. "The best way to do that is almost always to reproduce your whole life."

So how did menopause evolve? The answer may lie in whales. Ellis and his team at the University of Exeter recently published a study in the journal Nature that studies the evolution of menopause in the undersea animals most known for it. What they uncovered may even help explain menopause in humans.

Curious about other animal behavior mysteries? Email us at shortwave@npr.org.

TITLE: Despite church prohibitions, Catholics still choose IVF to have children
SUMMARY: Religions hold a variety of views toward IVF. Catholicism has one of the strongest negative judgments against the practice. Yet many in the church still use the procedure in order to have children.

TITLE: As the DOJ investigates Boeing, crash victims' families wonder why it's taken so long
SUMMARY: Boeing made big promises to the Justice Department to avoid prosecution after two fatal crashes of 737 Max jets. That deal now faces heightened scrutiny after a door plug blew off a jet in midair.

TITLE: This week's quiz has happiness and happy dogs. You're welcome
SUMMARY: Last year's most popular dog is still top, and the happiest nation is still the most contented. March is still madness and shutdowns still loom.

TITLE: Senegal heads to the polls after delayed elections - here's what you need to know
SUMMARY: Senegal will finally  go to the polls this weekend, in a vote that was delayed, then reinstated. A beacon of relative stability in a restless region, its democratic resilience has been sorely tested.

TITLE: Supporters of arrested Indian opposition politician protest in New Delhi
SUMMARY: Arvind Kejriwal, New Delhi's top elected official, was arrested Thursday amid accusations his party and ministers accepted bribes. Opposition parties say it's part of a crackdown by Modi's government.

TITLE: Russia attacks Ukrainian electrical power facilities, causing widespread outages
SUMMARY: The Ukrainian energy minister said the nighttime drone and rocket attacks were "the largest attack on the Ukrainian energy sector in recent times." At least three people were killed, officials said.

TITLE: Tennessee becomes the first state to protect musicians and other artists against AI
SUMMARY: The Ensuring Likeness Voice and Image Security Act, or ELVIS Act, is an updated version of the state's right of publicity law. The new legislation includes AI-specific protections.

TITLE: Buying or selling a home? How the real estate fee structure impacts you
SUMMARY: A settlement by the National Realtors Association promises to change the way real estate agents are compensated. It could spell an end to 6% commissions, which are higher than people pay elsewhere.

TITLE: Blinken meets with Netanyahu in Israel as Gaza cease-fire resolution fails at the U.N.
SUMMARY: Blinken's sixth time in the region since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks on Israel comes as cease-fire and hostage release talks continue in Doha, Qatar, and Russia and China veto U.S. cease-fire resolution.

TITLE: The ultimate green burial? Human composting lets you replenish the earth after death
SUMMARY: Only seven states have legalized human composting as a burial practice. That's why 29 percent of the bodies brought to Recompose, a composting facility in Seattle, come from out of state.

TITLE: Trump is on the verge of a windfall of billions of dollars. Here are 3 things to know
SUMMARY: The company behind Trump's Truth Social is on the verge of going public. It could earn the former president billions of dollars at a time when he faces mounting legal problems.

TITLE: Blinken visits Israel amid tensions over Rafah invasion plan; DOJ sues Apple
SUMMARY: Secretary of State Antony Blinken makes his sixth visit to Israel since the war in Gaza began. The DOJ is suing Apple, alleging the tech giant is abusing its power as a monopoly.

TITLE: A push is underway for voters to make Florida the next state to expand Medicaid
SUMMARY: For a decade, Florida lawmakers have debated whether to expand Medicaid under the Affordable Care Act. Advocates are trying to circumvent the legislature and take the issue directly to voters.

TITLE: Medicare plans can now cover Wegovy for patients at risk of heart disease
SUMMARY: This change follows the recent FDA approval of the weight-loss drug for preventing heart attack and stroke in people with overweight or obesity.

TITLE: Catherine, Princess of Wales, announces cancer diagnosis
SUMMARY: The former Kate Middleton said she was in the early stages of treatment in a video announcement Friday. Her health has been subject to public speculation in recent months.

TITLE: An American reporter offers a first-hand account of Japan's toughest crime bosses
SUMMARY: Reporter Jake Adelstein's memoir about covering the organized crime beat in Japan is the basis of the Max series Tokyo Vice, now in its second season. Originally broadcast Nov. 9, 2009.

TITLE: FBI letter tells Alaska Airlines passengers they are 'a possible victim of a crime'
SUMMARY: "We want answers, accountability, and safer planes" — and a federal investigation will help, an attorney representing passengers who were on the plane that lost its door plug tells NPR.

TITLE: Catherine, Princess of Wales, announces she is undergoing treatment for cancer
SUMMARY: The former Kate Middleton said she was in the early stages of preventative chemotherapy treatment in a video announcement Friday. Her health has been subject to public speculation in recent months.

TITLE: If you recently sold your home, you might get part of your realtor fee back
SUMMARY: A settlement by the National Realtors Association promises to change the way real estate agents are compensated. It could spell an end to 6% commissions, which are higher than people pay elsewhere.

TITLE: Blinken urges Netanyahu not to attack Rafah as cease-fire resolution fails at the U.N.
SUMMARY: Blinken's sixth time in the region since the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks on Israel comes as talks continue in Doha, Qatar, and Russia and China veto U.S. Gaza cease-fire resolution.

TITLE: A Visit to a Town Under Fire in Eastern Ukraine
SUMMARY: We go to a town in Eastern Ukraine that is close to the front lines and under constant fire. Russians are advancing in Eastern Ukraine as Ukrainian forces run low on ammunition and weapons.

TITLE: A State Department official warns Israel of 'major' reputational damage in Gaza war
SUMMARY: Assistant Secretary of State Bill Russo told Israeli officials last week the Gaza war is damaging Israel's global reputation, potentially lasting a generation, according to a readout obtained by NPR.

TITLE: New Indiana law requires professors to promote 'intellectual diversity' to keep tenure
SUMMARY: A new Indiana law requires professors to promote "intellectual diversity" to receive tenure. Critics worry the measure will dissuade academics from staying in the state.

TITLE: Deaths and injuries are reported after an attack on a concert hall outside Moscow
SUMMARY: Reports from Moscow say two to five gunmen attacked a concert hall outside the capital. A fire broke out after the attack. According to Tass news agency, some people remain trapped in the building.

TITLE: House appropriations bill would increase border enforcement capacity
SUMMARY: The budget approved by the Republican-led House includes over $9.5 billion for Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

TITLE: Dozens are dead and even more injured after an attack on a Moscow concert hall
SUMMARY: At least 60 people have been killed and 145 others injured after several gunmen wearing camouflage burst into a concert venue.

TITLE: Here are Louisiana's 2024 presidential primary results
SUMMARY: Voting concludes Saturday in Louisiana's presidential primaries. President Biden and former President Donald Trump, the presumptive nominees, are on their party's primary ballots. View live results.

TITLE: United Airlines says federal regulators will increase oversight of the company
SUMMARY: The move follows a series of recent issues at the airline, including a piece of the outer fuselage falling off one jet, an engine fire and a plane losing a tire during takeoff.

TITLE: What is the foundation behind the Ruth Bader Ginsburg award controversy?
SUMMARY: No awards will be given this year, the foundation told NPR, after a controversy exploded over changes to what was once called the Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg Woman of Leadership Award.

TITLE: Purim-a festive Jewish holiday with an ending often ignored
SUMMARY: The joyous Jewish holiday celebrates Jews' escape from annihilation as told in the Book of Esther. A lesser-known end to the story takes on new meaning during this time of war in the Middle East.

TITLE: Ohio has been a bellwether and a battleground: What is it telling us now?
SUMMARY: Ohio was the model bellwether state until 2020. In that year, Ohio gave a solid majority of its vote to then-incumbent President Donald Trump, but he still lost the White House to Joe Biden.

TITLE: In Parkland, Harris will urge more use of red flag laws to prevent shootings
SUMMARY: Florida passed a red flag law after the 2018 school shooting in Parkland. Today, during a visit to that site, Vice President Harris will urge more use of these laws to prevent shootings.

TITLE: Israeli settlers step up attacks on Palestinian farms, expanding West Bank outposts
SUMMARY: NPR visits one West Bank town where Israelis are grazing sheep, in a place where a Palestinian school once stood.

TITLE: Virtual reality offers a chilling 3D look inside Venezuela's spiraling prison
SUMMARY: A former Venezuelan political prisoner got the idea to create a virtual reality tour from the Anne Frank museum.

TITLE: Purim — a festive Jewish holiday with an ending often ignored
SUMMARY: The joyous Jewish holiday celebrates Jews' escape from annihilation as told in the Book of Esther. A lesser-known end to the story takes on new meaning during this time of war in the Middle East.

TITLE: Like a Phish concert but with more grievance, this is what it's like at a Trump rally
SUMMARY: Many Americans won't experience a rally for former President Donald Trump in person, instead witnessing these events through viral clips. But for the faithful, a Trump rally is so much more than that.

TITLE: My patients think Ozempic is a wonder drug. But it can't fix fat phobia
SUMMARY: Yes, as Oprah enthused, the drugs help people shrink their bodies. But the psychological damage of weight stigma can't be so easily cured, a doctor writes.

TITLE: So your NCAA bracket is busted. Should you have just chosen all the top seeds?
SUMMARY: As the dust settles from the early rounds of the NCAA Tournament, we bid farewell to the would-be Cinderellas who couldn't pull off the upset and take stock of your tattered bracket.

TITLE: Princess Kate's cancer triggers public shock, sympathy — and shame on the tabloids
SUMMARY: "It has been an incredibly tough couple of months for our entire family," the Princess of Wales said in a video filmed in secret and released Friday.

TITLE: Death toll from Moscow concert hall attack rises to 133 as Putin addresses the nation
SUMMARY: The Russian president described the violent shooting as "a bloody, barbaric terrorist act" after a group linked to the Islamic State claimed responsibility for the event.

TITLE: Nearly 300 abducted Nigerian schoolchildren freed after over two weeks in captivity
SUMMARY: Nearly 300 kidnapped Nigerian schoolchildren have been released, more than two weeks after the children were seized from their school in the northwestern state of Kaduna and marched into the forests.

TITLE: Korean food gets a Michelin-starred makeover in Seoul restaurants
SUMMARY: South Korea's restaurants are fine-tuning traditional dishes and adding the taste of culinary success to the trophy chest of Korean cultural power.

TITLE: It's easy to tune out politics. Biden's campaign is using an app to get around that
SUMMARY: Biden volunteers will still knock on doors and try to get voters on the phone. But they're also using an app to connect with hard-to reach voters this year.

TITLE: What is ISIS-K, the group that claims it carried out the Moscow concert attack?
SUMMARY: ISIS-K is one of the most militant jihadist groups in the world, often mounting attacks against other Islamist groups, while also targeting Russia and the U.S.

TITLE: How Two Recent Cases Of Violence Illustrate The Lives of LGBTQ People
SUMMARY:
Suicide rates for queer and trans people are disproportionately high. They're also routinely targets of violence and hate crimes.

While some states have protections for queer and trans people, many other states have passed laws that restrict the rights and visibility of transgender individuals.

The stories of Nex Benedict and Dime Doe illustrate both those trends.

Benedict died by suicide the day after a physical altercation in their school bathroom. Benedict had been bullied by other students for more than a year.

Dime Doe, a Black trans woman, was killed in 2019. Last month a man who had been in a relationship with Doe was found guilty of killing her. It's the first time a hate crime against a trans person was brought to trial.

What do these cases tell us about the lives of trans and queer people in America?

If you or someone you know needs help, call or text 988 to reach the Suicide and Crisis Lifeline.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: The IRS touts improved customer service and a hassle free filing option
SUMMARY: With less than a month before the tax filing deadline, the IRS says tax season is going smoothly. The agency is investing billions of dollars to improve service and beef up tax enforcement.

TITLE: Ed Department error may delay student financial aid further
SUMMARY: Students may have to wait even longer for their financial aid award letters due to an Education Department error

TITLE: Russia marks a national day of mourning for victims of the concert hall attack
SUMMARY: Russia paused for a day of mourning Sunday for the more than 130 people killed at a Moscow concert. The attack, claimed by an affiliate of the Islamic State, is the deadliest on Russian soil in years.

TITLE: An Arizona church known for feeding migrants now says the city is blocking its work
SUMMARY: Gethsemani Baptist Church in San Luis has been organizing food drives for nearly 25 years. But in a new lawsuit, the church alleges that the city has started to push back against this work.

TITLE: 4 men charged in Moscow attack as Russia marks a national day of mourning
SUMMARY: Four men accused of staging the Russia concert hall attack that killed more than 130 people appeared before a Moscow court Sunday showing signs of beatings as they faced formal terrorism charges.

TITLE: New England and New York dig out as a new storm will bring snow to the Midwest
SUMMARY: Police across the Northeast reported hundreds of traffic accidents over the weekend. Meanwhile, a separate storm will continue Monday across much of the Rockies, Plains and upper Midwest.

TITLE: How an Indianapolis teacher is using the solar eclipse to inspire her students
SUMMARY: Indianapolis is one of several U.S. cities in the path of totality. For many students there, it's a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity to witness – and be inspired by – a total solar eclipse.

TITLE: On eclipse day, hundreds of students will send up balloons for science
SUMMARY: The NASA-backed Nationwide Eclipse Ballooning Project puts students in charge of a bold scientific endeavor to study the April 8 total solar eclipse.

TITLE: A mom's $97,000 question: How was an air-ambulance ride not medically necessary?
SUMMARY: There are legal safeguards to protect patients from big bills like out-of-network air-ambulance rides. But insurers may not pay if they decide the ride wasn't medically necessary.

TITLE: What one horticulturist has to say about pesticide residue on produce
SUMMARY: It can be confusing for shoppers to wade through the bounty of information about the differences between organic and conventional produce. An expert clears the air on some common questions.

TITLE: Kevin Hart takes home his Mark Twain Prize for American humor
SUMMARY: Kevin Hart received the 25th annual Mark Twain Prize for American Humor at The Kennedy Center Sunday night. Fellow comedians Chris Rock, Jerry Seinfeld and Chelsea Handler were there to roast him.

TITLE: 'This is garbage': Step aside, influencers — we're now in the era of de-influencing
SUMMARY: A new movement has emerged in recent years: de-influencing. What started as a backlash to advertising could now have a surprising and real-world impact on the environment.

TITLE: Trump faces a crucial day in his hush-money trial, and a deadline to post bond
SUMMARY: This, as Trump, the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, is running against the man who defeated him in 2020, President Biden.

TITLE: Chick-fil-A will begin using some antibiotics in its chicken again
SUMMARY: The fast food company said it will now use "no antibiotics important to human medicine" beginning in spring of this year. The company first said it would stop using antibiotics in 2014.

TITLE: How to talk to kids about a cancer diagnosis in the family
SUMMARY: Kate Middleton said she took time to explain her cancer diagnosis to her children. What does an ideal version of that conversation look like?

TITLE: Israeli defense chief visits U.S.; 4 men charged in Moscow concert hall attack
SUMMARY: Israel's defense minister meets with U.S. officials today amid rising tensions between the allies. Russia charged four men with terrorism in connection to the Moscow attack that killed more than 130.

TITLE: Boeing CEO Dave Calhoun to step down, part of a shakeup after 737 Max problems
SUMMARY: After several difficult months, Boeing announced its embattled chief executive will step down at the end of this year. In January, an Alaska Airlines 737 Max had an in-flight door plug blowout.

TITLE: What's at stake in the Supreme Court mifepristone case
SUMMARY: The case could affect not just abortion access but oversight of the drug industry and the authority of federal agencies. The court hears arguments Tuesday.

TITLE: The U.N. Security Council has approved a cease-fire resolution for Gaza
SUMMARY: The Security Council voted 14-0 in favor of a resolution demanding a cease-fire through the end of Ramadan in two weeks. The United States abstained from the vote, allowing the measure to pass.

TITLE: Judge dismisses Elon Musk's suit against hate speech researchers
SUMMARY: The billionaire sued the Center for Countering Digital Hate after the group published a series of reports detailing an uptick of hate speech on X, the platform formerly known as Twitter.

TITLE: Hurry up and wait: Servers speed-walk through Paris, reviving a century-old race
SUMMARY: Some 200 servers speed-walked through Paris balancing trays of beverages and croissants on Sunday. Paris hasn't held a waiters race since 2011, but brought it back ahead of the Olympics.

TITLE: Israel cancels high-level talks in Washington after cease-fire vote clears the U.N.
SUMMARY: The Security Council voted 14-0 in favor of a resolution demanding a cease-fire through the end of Ramadan in two weeks. The United States abstained from the vote, allowing the measure to pass.

TITLE: What to know about the Moscow concert attack and what's next in the case
SUMMARY: Russia is still reeling from Friday's attack. Authorities have confirmed at least 137 dead. Suspects, some showing signs of torture, have been charged. Here are other key developments.

TITLE: Truth Social will start trading on Tuesday. Trump stands to earn a fortune
SUMMARY: Trump Media and Technology Group will trade on the Nasdaq exchange under the stock symbol DJT. The listing comes as the former president is mired in a slew of legal cases.

TITLE: On eclipse day, hundreds of students will send up balloons for science
SUMMARY: The NASA-backed Nationwide Eclipse Ballooning Project puts students in charge of a bold scientific endeavor to study the April 8 total solar eclipse.

TITLE: Shohei Ohtani will speak about Mazuhara and gambling and theft allegations
SUMMARY: The Los Angeles Dodgers fired Ippei Mizuhara last week. Three months earlier, the team called Mizuhara "Shohei's best buddy."

TITLE: The Booming Business of Kidnapping in Nigeria
SUMMARY: Islamic insurgents and other heavily armed groups have increasingly turned to kidnapping to get money. They abduct individuals, families and even large groups and then demand to be paid to let them go. We hear the story of one family, whose life has been turned upside down by a kidnapping.

TITLE: Shohei Ohtani says he's sad, shocked over Mizuhara's gambling and theft allegations
SUMMARY: The Los Angeles Dodgers fired Ippei Mizuhara last week. Three months earlier, the team called Mizuhara "Shohei's best buddy."

TITLE: Homes linked to Sean "Diddy" Combs raided by law enforcement
SUMMARY: Homeland Security officials said the raids are part of an ongoing investigation with law enforcement in New York, Miami and Los Angeles.

TITLE: Homes linked to Sean 'Diddy' Combs raided by law enforcement
SUMMARY: Homeland Security officials said the raids are part of an ongoing investigation with law enforcement in New York, Miami and Los Angeles.

TITLE: The IRS has 940,000 unclaimed tax refunds from 2020 that are about to expire
SUMMARY: The average median refund is $932 for 2020. Texas (93,400), California (88,200), Florida (53,200) and New York (51,400) have the largest amount of people potentially eligible for these refunds.

TITLE: Powerball jackpot climbs to $865 million as long winless drought continues
SUMMARY: The Powerball jackpot increased to an estimated $865 million after no one won Monday night's drawing, continuing a winless streak that dates to New Year's Day.

TITLE: What is the new etiquette for tipping?
SUMMARY: Tipping requests are on the rise. Businesses that never seemed to ask for a tip, like fast food joints, are now asking for one. Here's how to deal with unexpected requests and more.

TITLE: The Francis Scott Key bridge in Baltimore collapses after a ship crashed into it
SUMMARY: A part of the Francis Scott Key bridge in Baltimore has collapsed after a ship crashed into it early Tuesday morning, closing traffic on a major commuter arterial, local officials said.

TITLE: For patients with disabilities, this doctor prioritizes independence — and fun
SUMMARY: Sometimes health care means being able to go out and watch a wrestling match, according to Dr. Clarissa Kripke. She's pioneering a new kind of care for people with disabilities.

TITLE: How do we halt the next pandemic? Be kind to critters like bats, says a new paper
SUMMARY: A team of scientists argue that new vaccines and treatments wouldn't be critical if humans could figure out how to stop viruses from spilling over from animals in the first place.

TITLE: Meta is limiting how much political content users see. Here's how to opt out of that
SUMMARY: Meta is now limiting the amount of political content it recommends to Instagram and Threads users. Here's why it made the change — and how to opt out of it.

TITLE: With war in Gaza, Israel faces new pressure to draft the ultra-Orthodox into service
SUMMARY: Religious scholars have broad exemption from military service. But critics say that's no longer sustainable, given their fast-growing population and the war in Gaza.

TITLE: An egg exploded in her face. The ride to the hospital made her feel safe
SUMMARY: After Kathryn Fumie burned her face in a kitchen accident, the EMT on the ride to the hospital helped her feel like everything was going to be OK.

TITLE: Trump has embraced Jan. 6. The extremist message may alienate — or resonate
SUMMARY: He praises defendants who are charged with rioting that day. His campaign's launch site has connections to extremist violence. Experts worry he's tapping into anger that motivated domestic terrorism.

TITLE: She reads the newspaper on TikTok — and her videos are going viral
SUMMARY: Newspapers are losing the battle against smartphones as the place to learn the news, but one woman has found a way to bridge the divide and bring the print to the people.

TITLE: A Supreme Court abortion pill case with potential consequences for every other drug
SUMMARY: At issue is the FDA's regulatory power to approve drugs and continually evaluate their safety — a system that until now has been widely viewed as the gold standard for both safety and innovation

TITLE: Baltimore's Francis Scott Key Bridge collapses; SCOTUS takes on abortion pill case
SUMMARY: A vital Baltimore bridge collapsed overnight after a ship crashed into it. How the Supreme Court's ruling in the abortion pill case could affect other drugs.

TITLE: A U.K. court delays extradition of WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange to the U.S.
SUMMARY: He spent seven years in the Ecuadorian Embassy and five years in prison, both in London. U.S. prosecutors want his next move to be to the U.S. But the High Court has delayed that.

TITLE: Trump's social media company surges in trading debut in a big boost to Trump's wealth
SUMMARY: Trump Media and Technology Group surged in its trading debut, substantially boosting the former president's wealth — at least on paper.

TITLE: NBC's newest contributor is receiving backlash — even from the network's own talent
SUMMARY: Following the 2020 election, McDaniel, a Trump ally, said that she believed that the position was stolen from the former president by President Biden — which has been proven to be false.

TITLE: Justices seem skeptical of challenge to restrict access to abortion pill
SUMMARY: At issue in the case is more than abortion rights. It's the entire structure of the FDA's regulatory power to approve drugs and continually evaluate their safety.

TITLE: Robert Kennedy Jr. taps a wealthy California attorney as his running mate
SUMMARY: Kennedy, who's known for anti-vaccine advocacy and as a promoter of conspiracy theories, picked Nicole Shanahan, a political novice, as his running mate for his independent presidential campaign.

TITLE: How climate-driven migration could change the face of the U.S.
SUMMARY: ProPublica reporter Abrahm Lustgarten says millions of Americans are likely to move in the coming decades to escape wildfires, rising seas, oppressive heat and drought. His new book is On the Move.

TITLE: What to do if your vehicle is submerged in water
SUMMARY: The best way to survive a vehicle submersion is to escape through the windows before the car is fully submerged, experts agree.

TITLE: Mercedes, GM, Stellantis scramble; Port jobs are at risk after Baltimore disaster
SUMMARY: Baltimore's port isn't one of the nation's largest, and some goods can be rerouted. But some auto companies are having to scramble, and the bridge disaster could spell trouble for local jobs.

TITLE: N.Y. judge issues a limited gag order on Trump ahead of hush money trial
SUMMARY: The new gag order on former President Donald Trump specifically bars him from making public statements about witnesses, prosecutors or jurors in his first criminal trial.

TITLE: Conditions in Gaza and Tense Israel-US Relations
SUMMARY:
We hear from a U.N. spokesperson about the conditions for civilians he saw in Gaza. We also speak to an Israeli government minister about the level of humanitarian aid entering Gaza and about why a delegation to the U.S. was cancelled over a vote at the U.N.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Former RNC Chair Ronna McDaniel dropped as an NBC contributor following outcry
SUMMARY: Ronna McDaniel — former head of the RNC and Trump ally — has been dropped by NBC following both internal and public pushback after the network hired her as a paid contributor.

TITLE: Supreme Court seems doubtful of challenge to abortion pill
SUMMARY: At issue in the case is more than abortion rights. It's the entire structure of the FDA's regulatory power to approve drugs and continually evaluate their safety.

TITLE: Police investigating racial harassment of NCAA women's basketball team in Idaho
SUMMARY: Police are investigating reported harassment of the University of Utah women's basketball team while staying in Coeur D'Alene, Idaho for the NCAA tournament in nearby Spokane, Washington.

TITLE: Famed American sculptor Richard Serra, the 'poet of iron,' has died at 85
SUMMARY: Serra, known for his iconic large-scale pieces of outdoor artwork, died at the age of 85 on Tuesday at his home in Long Island, New York.

TITLE: Diddy's lawyers say feds used 'military-level force' in home raids
SUMMARY: A day after Homeland Security Investigations officials descended on Sean Combs' Miami and Los Angeles residences, his lawyers are calling it an "unprecedented ambush."

TITLE: The winless lottery streak ends. Someone wins the $1.12 billion Mega Millions jackpot
SUMMARY: Someone in New Jersey overcame the odds Tuesday night and won the $1.12 billion Mega Millions jackpot, breaking a winless streak that dated to last December.

TITLE: Visa, Mastercard settle long-running antitrust suit over swipe fees with merchants
SUMMARY: Visa and Mastercard announced a major settlement with U.S. merchants, potentially ending years of litigation over the fees charged every time a credit or debit card is used in a store or restaurant.

TITLE: In Lakota Nation, people are asking: Who does a language belong to?
SUMMARY: Many Lakota people agree: It's imperative to revitalize the Lakota language. But how exactly to do that is a matter of broader debate. Should Lakota be codified and standardized to make learning it easier? Or should the language stay as it always has been, defined by many different ways of writing and speaking? We explore this complex, multi-generational fight that's been unfolding in the Lakota Nation, from Standing Rock to Pine Ridge.

TITLE: In Pennsylvania, she wants to hand out new syringes to save lives. But is it legal?
SUMMARY: As billions from opioid settlements pour into states, Pennsylvania's efforts against addiction could be hamstrung because clean syringes could be considered illegal drug paraphernalia.

TITLE: What we know and don't know about Baltimore's Key bridge collapse
SUMMARY: Eight construction workers are thought to have fallen into the bridge at the time of the collision. Six are still unaccounted for and presumed to be dead, authorties said.

TITLE: Why VP Harris is seen as critical to Biden's reelection campaign
SUMMARY: The vice president has been traveling across the country, giving increasingly higher-profile remarks to key voting groups.

TITLE: People say they're leaving religion due to anti-LGBTQ teachings and sexual abuse
SUMMARY: People in the U.S. are switching religions and leaving religion altogether in large numbers. A new survey from the Public Religion Research Institute shows a high level of "religious churning."

TITLE: Loss of ship's power and stiff current may have led to bridge collision, experts say
SUMMARY: A momentary loss of propulsion or electricity aboard the massive cargo vessel as it maneuvered in a tight channel in Baltimore may have triggered a cascade of events leading to the bridge collision.

TITLE: The Baltimore bridge collapse gave conspiracy theorists a chance to boost themselves
SUMMARY: One researcher says it has become "standard" for any unexpected event "to be run through a filter of conspiracy theories based on the personal brand of the person spreading the theory."

TITLE: Why the mpox outbreak in the Democratic Republic of Congo is worrying disease docs
SUMMARY: With a dramatic jump in cases — and a strain of mpox that is deadlier than the virus that went global in 2022 — specialists are scrambling to reign it in.

TITLE: 6 presumed dead in Baltimore bridge collapse; former RNC chair dropped from NBC
SUMMARY: Recovery efforts are underway for six people presumed dead in the Baltimore bridge collapse. NBC has dropped a former RNC chair as a contributor after backlash from the public and its network stars.

TITLE: Baltimore's Key Bridge was built in the '70s, but has a deep and patriotic history
SUMMARY: The bridge was built mere yards from where Francis Scott Key watched the British bombardment of Fort McHenry in 1814, inspiring him to write the song that would become the U.S. national anthem.

TITLE: Ukraine's Kharkiv moves classrooms underground so kids survive Russian attacks
SUMMARY: With Russian troops on the offensive, Ukraine's second-largest city is taking the drastic step of moving classrooms for primary and secondary education underground.

TITLE: Baltimore's bridge collapse is expected to disrupt supply chains
SUMMARY: The Port of Baltimore handles high volumes of auto imports, so while it's at a standstill, some cars and trucks will have to be diverted to other ports, which could raise costs.

TITLE: 1 in 10 Asian Americans live in poverty. Their experiences vary widely, research says
SUMMARY: Pew Research Center found that poverty rates range greatly among Asian American groups. While 6% of Indian Americans live in poverty, the rate is 19% for Burmese Americans.

TITLE: As theaters scramble to reach new audiences, three get $1 million each
SUMMARY: The Mellon Foundation announced grants of $1 million to three theaters: Actors Theatre of Louisville, Long Wharf in New Haven and Portland Center Stage.

TITLE: What we know and don't know about Baltimore's Key Bridge collapse
SUMMARY: Rescue efforts have turned to recovery after the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore. A federal investigation is underway as the region braces for a long and costly reconstruction.

TITLE: Here's what to know about dengue, as Puerto Rico declares a public health emergency
SUMMARY: Most people with dengue will show no signs of infection or experience only mild symptoms, but in rare cases infections can become severe and potentially fatal.

TITLE: Kickoffs will look radically different in the NFL next year. Here's how and why
SUMMARY: For years, the NFL has tweaked kickoff rules to reduce injuries, resulting in kickoffs that were safer but more boring. The changes aim to re-introduce excitement while keeping injuries low.

TITLE: Life Without a Government in Haiti
SUMMARY: Haiti is the middle of a crisis and is without a government as gangs in Port-au-Prince prevent one. But some parts of Haiti have lived without a functioning government for so long they cannot remember what it's like to have one. Our reporter in Haiti takes us to one such village.

TITLE: Best-selling psychologist of 'Thinking, Fast and Slow,' dies at 90
SUMMARY: One of the founders of behavioral economics, who incorporated human quirks into the study of how people make economic decisions, has died. Daniel Kahneman was 90.

TITLE: Cash-strapped Trump is now selling $60 Bibles, U.S. Constitution included
SUMMARY: The "God Bless The USA" Bible is inspired by the Lee Greenwood anthem and includes copies of the nation's founding documents. Trump launched it ahead of Easter<strong>

TITLE: Centrist former Sen. Joseph Lieberman has died at 82
SUMMARY: As Al Gore's running mate in 2000, Lieberman became the first Jewish candidate on a presidential ticket of one of the two major parties. He later became an independent and was a leader of No Labels.

TITLE: An Arizona Lawmaker announced she was getting an abortion. Here's what happened next.
SUMMARY: State Sen. Eva Burch hopes her experiences will convince her colleagues to leave abortion access up doctors- and Arizona voters this fall.

TITLE: An appeals court says 'undated' Pennsylvania ballots don't count
SUMMARY: A federal appeals panel says mailed ballots arriving on time but in envelopes without dates handwritten by Pennsylvania voters shouldn't be counted. This case is expected to reach the Supreme Court.

TITLE: An Arizona lawmaker announced she was getting an abortion. Here's what happened next
SUMMARY: State Sen. Eva Burch hopes her experiences will convince her colleagues to leave abortion access up to doctors — and Arizona voters — this fall.

TITLE: California judge recommends disbarment of pro-Trump attorney John Eastman
SUMMARY: A California judge found that attorney John Eastman committed "exceptionally serious ethical violations" in his efforts to overturn the results of the 2020 election and recommended disbarment.

TITLE: Chevron owns this city's news site. Many stories aren't told
SUMMARY: Chevron operates a major refinery in Richmond, Calif. It also owns the city's dominant news site, putting its own spin on events, and runs similar sites in Texas and Ecuador.

TITLE: Sam Bankman-Fried is about to get sentenced for his FTX crimes. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Prosecutors are asking for 40 to 50 years, citing the severity of Bankman-Fried's crimes. Lawyers of the disgraced former head of FTX are asking for far less.

TITLE: Why a town on the front line of America's energy transition isn't letting go of coal
SUMMARY: Kemmerer, Wyo., is on the front line of America's energy transition, with its coal plant slated to close and a nuclear plant in the works. But some think the rush to quit fossil fuels is impractical.

TITLE: 'Struggle, struggle, struggle.' What new and expecting mothers are facing in Gaza
SUMMARY: Women who are pregnant or who have recently given birth in Gaza face serious challenges amid daily airstrikes, continued ground fighting, high rates of disease and a growing lack of food and water.

TITLE: For Baltimore-area residents, bridge collapse means longer commutes and uncertain prospects
SUMMARY: The Key Bridge collapse is upending life for countless people in the Chesapeake region. Residents say it's not just infrastructure — it's their identity as people who live close to the water.

TITLE: 'Worry' is a disturbing and honest picture of what it's like to be in your 20s
SUMMARY: Alexandra Tanner's debut novel, <em>Worry

TITLE: Some foreign-made cars might be delayed as auto companies figure out port deliveries
SUMMARY: The deadly Francis Scott Key Bridge collapse blocked off much of Baltimore's harbor, which handles more cars and trucks than any other U.S. port. Companies have some options to keep imports coming.

TITLE: In Florida, there's détente in the battle between Disney and Gov. Ron DeSantis
SUMMARY: Disney and a board appointed by Florida Gov. Ron DeSantis have settled lawsuits over who controls development in the 40-square-mile district that's home to its Orlando theme parks.

TITLE: Can grief make us accident-prone? A writer learns how it destabilizes and remakes us
SUMMARY: After a fall near the first anniversary of her beloved aunt's death, a writer explored why grief can make us less sure-footed. She found answers, climbing a precarious staircase in Italy.

TITLE: Legal experts worry about presidential abuse of the Insurrection Act. Here's why
SUMMARY: Experts say the Insurrection Act gives a president too much sweeping power to deploy troops on American soil without guard rails or proper oversight from Congress.

TITLE: A Baltimore bridge collapse timeline; Disney and DeSantis settle legal battle
SUMMARY: Two bodies were recovered from the Baltimore bridge collapse and investigators released a timeline of events. The Walt Disney Company and Gov. Ron DeSantis have settled their lawsuits.

TITLE: Fractures in the Grand Alliance between Black and Jewish Americans
SUMMARY: The Grand Alliance between Black and Jewish leaders, known largely for shared work on Civil Rights in the 1960s, has a complicated legacy--and an uncertain future between these communities.

TITLE: Next U.S. census will have new boxes for 'Middle Eastern or North African,' 'Latino'
SUMMARY: Biden officials approved proposals for the U.S. census and federal surveys to change how Latinos are asked about their race and ethnicity and to add a checkbox for "Middle Eastern or North African."

TITLE: The piece of wood that saved (only) Rose in 'Titanic' was auctioned off for $718k
SUMMARY: The debris that saved Rose's life in <em>Titanic

TITLE: Sam Bankman-Fried sentenced to 25 years in prison for his FTX crimes
SUMMARY: The sentence marks a stunning fall for the 32-year old former crypto executive who was once seen as the future of finance.

TITLE: Life Kit's tips of the month: On seafood labels, eye strain and sibling relationships
SUMMARY: Our most memorable and useful expert advice from Life Kit's March episodes, hand-picked by the editors.

TITLE: Here's how to set your reading goals and read more books in 2024
