SUMMARY: Experts say it's better to set a goal you can stick to and make reading more of a community affair.

TITLE: House will send impeachment articles against Mayorkas to Senate on April 10
SUMMARY: The House passed the two articles along party lines in February, but proceedings stalled amid government funding negotiations.

TITLE: Grief made me lose my balance. Here's how I learned to walk forward again
SUMMARY: After a fall near the first anniversary of her beloved aunt's death, a writer explored why grief can make us less sure-footed. She found answers, climbing a precarious staircase in Italy.

TITLE: Milky Way black hole has 'strong, twisted' magnetic field in mesmerizing new image
SUMMARY: The polarized light image gives us a "new view of the monster lurking at the heart of the Milky Way galaxy," according to the European Southern Observatory.

TITLE: The Story of an Israeli Man Taken Hostage By Hamas, Now Free
SUMMARY:
We hear the story of an Israeli man taken captive by Hamas on October 7th. He was freed by Israeli special forces 129 days later and talks about his ordeal.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Families in Honduras, Mexico mourn victims of bridge collapse in Baltimore
SUMMARY: 38-year-old Maynor Yassir Suazo Sandoval came to the U.S. to make something of himself and to help his family in Honduras. He was one the workers on the Francis Scott Key Bridge when it collapsed.

TITLE: Port workers in Baltimore face uncertain future
SUMMARY: Since the Francis Scott Key Bridge was struck by a cargo ship and collapsed early Tuesday. Questions continue about what's ahead.

TITLE: Biden administration restores threatened species protections dropped by Trump
SUMMARY: Among the changes, the U.S. Fish and Wildlife Service will reinstate a decades-old regulation that mandates blanket protections for species newly classified as threatened.

TITLE: 'Green bubble shaming' at play in DOJ suit against Apple
SUMMARY: Android users have long complained that texting someone with an iPhone on iMessage is an unpleasant experience. The Justice Department argues it is also an example of anti-competitive behavior.

TITLE: 'A generous man': Baltimore bridge worker helped family, community in Honduras
SUMMARY: 38-year-old Maynor Yassir Suazo Sandoval came to the U.S. to make something of himself and to help his family in Honduras. He was one the workers on the Francis Scott Key Bridge when it collapsed.

TITLE: A bus plunges off a bridge in South Africa, killing 45 people
SUMMARY: An 8-year-old child is only survivor. The passengers were headed to an Easter festival before the bus plunged off a bridge on a mountain pass and burst into flames.

TITLE: Biden touts a $25M haul from fundraiser featuring Barack Obama and Bill Clinton
SUMMARY: A star-studded cast appeared with the former presidents and Biden, including Mindy Kaling, Ben Platt and Stephen Colbert hosting the event.

TITLE: Georgia lawmakers pass new election rules that could impact 2024 presidential contest
SUMMARY: Republicans in Georgia have repeatedly floated election changes in the wake of false claims by former President Donald Trump and other Republicans that he lost Georgia in 2020 because of fraud.

TITLE: The Texas attorney general is investigating a supplier of Boeing 737 parts
SUMMARY: In January, a door plug flew off a Boeing 737 Max 9 plane during a flight, leaving a hole in the fuselage, some of which are produced by Spirit AeroSystems Holdings, Inc.

TITLE: 'Oppenheimer' finally premieres in Japan to mixed reactions and high emotions
SUMMARY: The film's release in Japan, more than eight months after it opened in the U.S., had been watched with trepidation because of the sensitivity of the subject matter.

TITLE: The White House issued new rules on how government can use AI. Here's what they do
SUMMARY: The memo outlines how government agencies can implement artificial intelligence and requires that agencies have a chief AI officer.

TITLE: Boiling weeds, eating animal feed: People in Gaza stave off hunger any way they can
SUMMARY: Palestinians in Gaza tell NPR they've resorted to boiling weeds in seawater, eating animal feed and grinding date pits. "If the bombs don't kill us, the hunger will," a teenage girl says.

TITLE: Bad news, chocolate lovers: Cocoa prices have risen faster than bitcoin
SUMMARY: It's been a wild historic ride: The price of cocoa topped the all-time record before Valentine's Day and has almost doubled since then, in time for Easter. The culprit is the weather.

TITLE: Looking for Cinderella? Here's the biggest underdog left in March Madness
SUMMARY: North Carolina State isn't a prototypical Cinderella — they're from a major conference, and they won it all in the 1970s and '80s — but they're the only double-digit seed left. Learn to love them.

TITLE: Your muscles keep time too. How circadian rhythms affect your workout and your health
SUMMARY: Scientists think the timing of exercise might matter for performance — and for your overall health. Here's what to know about their latest findings.

TITLE: A comedian, a pug and a politician walk into the quiz. Do you know the punchline?
SUMMARY: Is Kevin Hart funny? Are pugs cute? Is Donald Trump a good politician? Thankfully, the quiz doesn't need to answer these questions — we'll just stick to the facts, thanks.

TITLE: U.S. reporter Evan Gershkovich has now spent a whole year jailed in Russia
SUMMARY: It's been a year since Russia detained <em>Wall Street Journal

TITLE: Baltimore bridge collapse threatens jobs; Sam Bankman-Fried gets 25-year sentence
SUMMARY: Cleaning up the Baltimore bridge collapse won't be quick, easy or inexpensive. Disgraced FTX CEO Sam Bankman-Fried is sentenced to 24 years for fraud.

TITLE: EPA's new rules to clean up heavy trucking met with support and criticism
SUMMARY: The EPA has finalized the strictest-ever limits on greenhouse gas emissions from heavy-duty trucks, a category that includes everything from buses to garbage trucks.

TITLE: Why the University of Idaho marching band are now heroes in Connecticut
SUMMARY: When Yale's marching band wasn't able to make it to March Madness, the Sound of Idaho stepped in — and went viral. A week later, Connecticut's governor proclaimed a "University of Idaho Day."

TITLE: Pricier Easter bunnies and eggs. Half-dipped Kit Kats. What's up with chocolate?
SUMMARY: The price of cocoa is on a wild historic ride: It topped the all-time record before Valentine's Day and almost doubled since then, in time for Easter. The culprit is the weather.

TITLE: Louis Gossett Jr., the 1st Black man to win a supporting actor Oscar, dies at 87
SUMMARY: Gossett won the award for An Officer And A Gentleman, and also got an Emmy for Roots. More recent prominent roles for the Broadway star and civil rights activist were in The Color Purple and Watchmen

TITLE: 'A generous man': Baltimore bridge worker helped family, community in Honduras
SUMMARY: Maynor Suazo Sandoval left Honduras when he was 20 and built a new life in the U.S. He is one of the missing workers from the collapsed Francis Scott Key Bridge.

TITLE: Social media companies made changes to comply with U.K. rules to safeguard kids
SUMMARY: A new report by Children and Screens rounds up the changes spurred by the United Kingdom's Age Appropriate Design Code, which went into effect in 2020.

TITLE: Mercy me: Photos show what humans have done to the planet in the Anthropocene age
SUMMARY: Anthropocene refers to the age of humans — the things we've done to Earth. Geologists just rejected a proposal to declare an official "Anthropocene epoch." But everyone agrees: Damage has been done.

TITLE: Texas appeals court acquits Crystal Mason's illegal voting conviction
SUMMARY: The court said the state did not have enough evidence to prove that Mason knew she was ineligible to vote when she cast a ballot in the 2016 election. She was facing a five-year prison sentence.

TITLE: Why the University of Idaho marching band members are heroes in Connecticut
SUMMARY: When Yale's marching band wasn't able to make it to March Madness, the Sound of Idaho stepped in — and went viral. A week later, Connecticut's governor proclaimed a "University of Idaho Day."

TITLE: Clearing Baltimore's shipping channel won't be easy, will take at least weeks
SUMMARY: The likely first step will likely be securing the massive container ship that brought the bridge down on Tuesday. Then, clearing debris from the shipping channel.

TITLE: TikTok and others change platforms to protect kids. Advocates say it's just a start
SUMMARY: A new report by Children and Screens rounds up the changes spurred by the U.K.'s Age Appropriate Design Code, which went into effect in 2020. Similar laws are being considered in the U.S.

TITLE: What a Hit Chinese TV Show Tells Us About China Today
SUMMARY: "Blossoms Shanghai" is A 30-part TV series directed by acclaimed Hong Kong filmmaker Wong Kar-wai, set in the 1990's that has become a huge hit in China. Our China correspondent tells us the nostalgia unleashed by the show tells us a lot about how people in China are feeling these days.

TITLE: A giant crane arrives in Baltimore, but leaders see a 'daunting' cleanup job ahead
SUMMARY: Federal money and resources are flowing to Maryland as authorities scramble to remove the wreckage of the Francis Scott Key Bridge. But they acknowledge the effort will not be easy, cheap or quick.

TITLE: Radio Free Asia closes its Hong Kong operation over safety concerns for its staff
SUMMARY: U.S. government-funded Radio Free Asia is closing its Hong Kong operation after the city enacted a tough new national security law known locally as Article 23.

TITLE: 21 years after her death in Gaza, Palestinians remember U.S. activist Rachel Corrie
SUMMARY: The 23-year-old was crushed by an Israeli army bulldozer as she protested the demolition of homes in Gaza in 2003. Her memory remains cherished among Palestinians, including the family she lived with.

TITLE: RFK Jr. may have missed a major opportunity with his VP pick
SUMMARY: Until his running mate Nicole Shanahan can prove herself an asset, Kennedy will seem to have missed an opportunity to capture the imagination of the nation — or at least a meaningful segment of it.

TITLE: Baltimore bridge collapse has put the spotlight on Maryland's young Black governor
SUMMARY: Since before the political newcomer was inaugurated, there has been speculation that Maryland Gov. Wes Moore wants to run for higher office. The bridge collapse could be his first major test.

TITLE: Climate change is delaying world clocks' need for a 'negative leap second'
SUMMARY: We're nearing a year when a negative leap second could be needed to shave time — an unprecedented step that would have unpredictable effects, a new study says.

TITLE: Trans Day of Visibility began 15 years ago. The founder is still moved by its success
SUMMARY: Rachel Crandall-Crocker, the founder of International Transgender Day of Visibility, said organizing has taught her one invaluable lesson: "You do not have to be perfect to change the world."

TITLE: From longshoremen to charter boats, Baltimore's port closure means lost work
SUMMARY: The Port of Baltimore, normally one of the country's busiest, is in limbo due to the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge. For those who work on the water, business is far from usual.

TITLE: A cancer diagnosis is a shock. Here's advice on how to share the news
SUMMARY: The secrecy that shrouded Princess Kate's cancer diagnosis is something that any new cancer patient can understand. It's daunting to decide when to share, whom to tell and how much to say.

TITLE: Sikhs in California vote on independence from India
SUMMARY: Sikhs in California will vote in a referendum to push for their own independent state in India

TITLE: California fast-food workers will get $20 minimum wage, starting Monday
SUMMARY: Debate is hot about the impact of a higher minimum wage. Half a million Californians work in fast-food, where wages had stagnated for decades. Restaurant owners warn of higher prices and fewer hours.

TITLE: 8 decades later, remains of a Virginia sailor killed in Pearl Harbor are identified
SUMMARY: David Walker from Norfolk, Va., was 19 years old when Japanese torpedoes sunk his battleship, the USS California, during the surprise attack on the Hawaii naval base in 1941.

TITLE: Millions of customers' data found on dark web in latest AT&T data breach
SUMMARY: The provider says it has reset the passcodes of the current account holders whose data was compromised as it investigates the leak, the latest in a string of telecommunications company data breaches.

TITLE: Powerball jackpot jumps to $975 million after another drawing without a big winner
SUMMARY: The Powerball jackpot climbed to an estimated $975 million after no one matched the six numbers drawn Saturday night, continuing a nearly three-month stretch without a big winner.

TITLE: Government agents raid Peruvian President Boluarte's residence
SUMMARY: Peruvian president Dina Boluarte is being investigated for allegedly acquiring an undisclosed collection of luxury watches since becoming vice president in 2021, and then president in 2022.

TITLE: Former U.S. Rep. William Delahunt of Massachusetts has died at age 82
SUMMARY: Longtime U.S. Rep. William D. Delahunt of Massachusetts, a Democratic stalwart, has died following a long-term illness, his family announced.

TITLE: Las Vegas' famed Tropicana resort will close next week to make way for a new ballpark
SUMMARY: When the Tropicana opened in 1957, it was the "Tiffany of the Strip," complete with showgirl revues, mob deals and James Bond. It will be demolished in October to build a new home for the Oakland A's.

TITLE: Pope overcomes health concerns to preside over blustery Easter Sunday Mass
SUMMARY: Pope Francis overcame concerns about his health to preside over Easter Sunday Mass, leading tens of thousands of people in a flower-decked St. Peter's Square.

TITLE: A Florida activist creates safe spaces as laws and rhetoric turn against trans rights
SUMMARY: In founding Capital Tea, Janel Diaz sought to provide the kind of services that she had needed after her transition.

TITLE: Las Vegas' famed Tropicana resort will close this week to make way for a new ballpark
SUMMARY: When the Tropicana opened in 1957, it was the "Tiffany of the Strip," complete with showgirl revues, mob deals and James Bond. It will be demolished in October to build a new home for the Oakland A's.

TITLE: A Billionaire's Land Purchases In Rural Hawaii Have Locals Worried
SUMMARY:
Hawaii is no stranger to extravagant homes owned by the super-rich. But when a tech billionaire started buying up land in Waimea, a small, rural town on the Big Island, the community got curious - and worried.

Locals fear it will become even more difficult for Native Hawaiians to afford to live in Waimea and buy property. In Hawaii, the average home price is close to a million dollars.

Who's purchasing all this land in rural Hawaii and how will it affect the already high cost of housing in Waimea?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: 'SNL' sends up the NPR Tiny Desk with an intern who pleads, 'keep the ruckus down'
SUMMARY: Saturday Night Live poked fun at NPR's Tiny Desk this weekend, with Bowen Yang playing the part of an aggravated intern who just wants the band to keep it down so he can get back to work.

TITLE: For the first time, U.S. dairy cows have tested positive for bird flu
SUMMARY: Livestock in Texas, Kansas and Michigan are confirmed to have the virus, and herds in New Mexico and Idaho have also tested positive. The threat to the public is low, federal officials say.

TITLE: 'No timeline' to recover 4 bodies after Baltimore bridge collapse, as cleanup begins
SUMMARY: Maryland Gov. Wes Moore called the recovery operation "complex" after a ship smashed into the Francis Scott Key Bridge. Officials have not given estimates on when the river will reopen to traffic.

TITLE: Basketball superstars Caitlin Clark and Angel Reese meet again on Monday
SUMMARY: Monday's game won't end with a championship ring, but the stakes are still high. The matchup between two of college basketball's biggest stars will determine who will advance to the Final Four.

TITLE: Pope Francis appeals for peace in Gaza and Ukraine at Easter Mass
SUMMARY: Pope Francis overcame concerns about his health to preside over Easter Sunday Mass, leading tens of thousands of people in a flower-decked St. Peter's Square.

TITLE: In a setback to Turkey's Erdogan, opposition makes huge gains in local election
SUMMARY: Turkey's main opposition party retained its control over key cities and made huge gains elsewhere in Sunday's local elections, in a major upset to President Recep Tayyip Erdogan.

TITLE: Kia recalls over 427,000 Telluride SUVs because they might roll away while parked
SUMMARY: According to documents published by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration, the intermediate shaft and right front driveshaft of certain 2020-2024 Tellurides may not be fully engaged.

TITLE: Israelis stage largest protest since war began to increase pressure on Netanyahu
SUMMARY: Tens of thousands of Israelis thronged central Jerusalem on Sunday in the largest anti-government protest since the country went to war in October.

TITLE: Dairy cows test positive for bird flu, but officials say risk to public is low
SUMMARY: Bird flu has been detected in cattle in several states. Its believed to be the first time the disease has infected dairy cows.

TITLE: Dystopias are so 2020. Meet the new protopias that show a hopeful future
SUMMARY: <em>A Brief History of the Future

TITLE: 5 tips for not getting tricked online this April Fools' Day — and beyond
SUMMARY: It's always smart to keep your guard up online, especially on April Fools' Day. Experts in misinformation and news literacy offer steps you can take to avoid getting fooled, and not just on Monday.

TITLE: ACA health insurance plans are being switched without enrollees' OK
SUMMARY: Rogue insurance agents access consumer information on the Affordable Care Act federal marketplace and make the changes. Policyholders can lose their doctors and end up owing back taxes.

TITLE: How anti-vaccine activists and the far right are trying to build a parallel economy
SUMMARY: Due to fears of "cancellation," alternative technology and financial platforms are being built for the so-called freedom economy by figures on the far right, including those with antisemitic beliefs.

TITLE: Johannesburg's water crisis is the latest blow to South Africa's 'world-class city'
SUMMARY: It bills itself as a "world-class African city" but these days residents say it's anything but — with the collapse of the water system and frequent power outages.

TITLE: Conservative Oregon county attempts criminal prosecution of federal employee
SUMMARY: A US Forest Service burn boss was due before a Grant County, Oregon court Monday on charges stemming from a controlled burn that spread onto private land in the Fall of 2022.

TITLE: Biden is using his cash advantage to address vulnerabilities against Trump
SUMMARY: The Biden campaign is running ads in states expected to be competitive this election, targeting Black and Latino voters in particular.

TITLE: Lead in the drinking water is still a problem in the U.S. — especially in Chicago
SUMMARY: The Windy City has the most lead pipes of any U.S. city. A study estimates that more than two-thirds of children there are exposed to lead in their home tap water.

TITLE: Half a million California workers will get $20 minimum wage, starting today
SUMMARY: It's a big win for cooks, cashiers and other fast-food employees, among the least paid in the workforce. Restaurant owners and franchisees warn of higher prices and cuts to workers' hours.

TITLE: Israel withdraws from a Gaza hospital, AT&T data breach affects millions of users
SUMMARY: Israeli forces have withdrawn from a Gaza hospital after a two-week assault, AT&T says a data breach has compromised the personal data of current and former users.

TITLE: 'I was broken and needed help': After her father died, a stranger stepped in
SUMMARY: When Roxanne Olson found herself in the middle of a security scare at Chicago's O'Hare airport, a woman walked up to her and said: "I'm here to help people like you."

TITLE: Three presidents and not a necktie in sight. Are ties out of fashion?
SUMMARY: Prompted by a recent photo of three U.S. presidents in suits without neckwear, fashion historian Kimberly Chrisman-Campbell details about how popular ties are — or aren't.

TITLE: The White House is planning a scaled-down iftar dinner to mark Ramadan this year
SUMMARY: White House officials appear to be trying to hold an event that will both reflect the somber mood in the Muslim community because of the war and also curb the possibility of protests.

TITLE: Why Oregon schools' pandemic recovery lags behind much of the nation
SUMMARY: Oregon schools are struggling more than others across the country to recover academic learning losses. Experts say one likely reason is a lack of statewide consistency in tutoring interventions.

TITLE: White House hosts a soggy, education-themed Easter egg roll
SUMMARY: It's one of the few days of the year where the executive branch becomes a child's playground — and this year, the White House Easter Egg Roll drew kids to the South Lawn despite some light rain.

TITLE: Israelis Return to a City that was Attacked
SUMMARY:
Sderot, Israel, near the border with Gaza, was the biggest city attack by Hamas on October 7th. At the beginning of the war, Israel evacuated nearly everyone. Our correspondent visits Sderot and finds that people are returning.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Trump's social media stock tumbles, erasing early gains
SUMMARY: Stock in the parent company of former president Donald Trump's social media platform sank on Monday, after the company reported losing $58 million last year.  That erased last week's market gains.

TITLE: United asks pilots to take unpaid leave in May because of delivery delays at Boeing
SUMMARY: United Airlines says it's trying to reduce pilot staffing levels next month because it's not receiving as many new 737 Max planes as expected, the latest fallout from manufacturing problems at Boeing.

TITLE: Iranian officials accuse Israel of a deadly attack on Iran's consulate in Syria
SUMMARY: An Israeli airstrike on Iran's consulate in Damascus killed two Iranian generals and five others, Iranian state media said Monday. Israel has not yet commented on the attack.

TITLE: Trump posts bond in civil fraud case; has gag order expanded in hush-money trial
SUMMARY: A court filing said the bond was provided by Knight Insurance, a California-based company. The move ensures that New York Attorney General Letitia James can't seize Trump's assets related to the case.

TITLE: An Israeli airstrike has killed World Central Kitchen workers in Gaza, founder says
SUMMARY: José Andrés, the founder of the organization that feeds people in war and disaster zones, said Monday that "several"  international volunteers were killed in an Israeli airstrike in the Gaza Strip.

TITLE: The White House plans a smaller Ramadan gathering as the war in Gaza continues
SUMMARY: White House officials appear to be trying to hold an event that will both reflect the somber mood in the Muslim community because of the war and also curb the possibility of protests.

TITLE: Powerball jackpot rises to $1.09 billion after 3-month-long losing streak continues
SUMMARY: The Powerball jackpot climbed to an estimated $1.09 billion after no one matched the game's six numbers Monday night and won the top prize, continuing a three-month-long winless streak.

TITLE: New York inmates sue to watch the solar eclipse after prisons ordered locked down
SUMMARY: The suit filed in federal court argues the April 8 lockdown violates inmates' constitutional rights to practice their faiths by preventing them from taking part in a religiously significant event.

TITLE: After years of trying, the U.S. government may finally mandate safer table saws
SUMMARY: After years of false starts, the Consumer Product Safety Commission looks poised to mandate a blade safety brake on all new table saws sold in the United States.

TITLE: Gold mining reduced this Amazon rainforest to a moonscape. Now miners are restoring it
SUMMARY: Illegal gold mining has ravaged the Peruvian Amazon, leaving behind pollution and denuded landscapes. A group of miners are working with a U.S. charity to restore the forest.

TITLE: Anti-Muslim bias reports skyrocket after Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel
SUMMARY: The Council on American-Islamic Relations releases its annual Civil Right Report. It details record-high instances of anti-Muslim hate in the wake of the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel.

TITLE: At the heart of this cozy coffee shop lies a big sister's love for her little brother
SUMMARY: Having siblings can mean shared family and childhood experiences — and also shared bedrooms and rivalries. A growing body of research shows us that sibling relationships can shape us for life.

TITLE: The women's NCAA Final Four is set after Iowa wins its rematch against LSU
SUMMARY: Caitlin Clark, the all-time NCAA Division 1 basketball scoring leader, led the Iowa Hawkeyes to victory Monday night, scoring 41 of the team's 94 points in their rematch against LSU.

TITLE: What to know as Chad Daybell jury selection begins in 'zombie' murder trial in Idaho
SUMMARY: Daybell could potentially face the death penalty over the deaths of two children and his former wife. His current wife, Lori Vallow Daybell, was found guilty of similar charges last year.

TITLE: Why there's a long-standing voter registration gap for Latinos and Asian Americans
SUMMARY: The two fastest-growing groups of eligible U.S. voters — Latinos and Asian Americans — also have the lowest voter registration rates. Advocates are trying to boost sign-ups for a healthier democracy.

TITLE: Protest vote over Biden's handling of Gaza lands in Wisconsin
SUMMARY: Following campaigns in other states, Wisconsin primary voters who feel Biden has been too supportive of Israeli military actions in Gaza are using a choice on their ballots to voice their discontent.

TITLE: New ad campaign from Democrats targets vulnerable Republicans over IVF
SUMMARY: The DCCC is placing billboards in eight swing districts where Republicans supported the Life At Conception Act, NPR has exclusively learned.

TITLE: Florida adds abortion to November ballot; Iran blames Israel for embassy bombing
SUMMARY: Florida voters will have the chance to enshrine abortion rights into their constitution. Iran blames Israel for an embassy bombing that killed a top military commander.

TITLE: What to know as Chad Daybell's 'zombie' murder trial begins in Idaho
SUMMARY: Daybell could potentially face the death penalty over the deaths of two children and his former wife. His current wife, Lori Vallow Daybell, was found guilty of similar charges last year.

TITLE: What The Beatles' and Beyoncé's 'Blackbird' means to this Little Rock Nine member
SUMMARY: A fan of both The Beatles and Beyoncé, 82-year-old Melba Pattillo Beals says the song is more special to her than ever. She is one of the Black students who helped desegregate U.S. public schools.

TITLE: What The Beatles and Beyoncé's 'Blackbird' means to this Little Rock Nine member
SUMMARY: A fan of both The Beatles and Beyoncé, 82-year-old Melba Pattillo Beals says the song is more special to her than ever. She is one of the Black students who helped desegregate U.S. public schools.

TITLE: This isn't the first time the U.S. and Israel have disagreed over Gaza
SUMMARY: The U.S. and Israel are close allies, but they've had sharp disagreements. Are the current differences over the war in Gaza a short-term dispute or a fundamental change in the relationship?

TITLE: You'll need more than $100,000 in income to afford a typical home, studies show
SUMMARY: Two recent studies suggest that prospective homeowners will have to earn more than $100,000 annually to afford a typical home in much of the U.S.

TITLE: World Central Kitchen, led by a humanitarian chef, has fed crisis zones for years
SUMMARY: World Central Kitchen has long brought food to war zones and disaster areas around the world. The deaths of seven of its workers in Gaza come on top of the loss of six workers in Ukraine.

TITLE: Biden and China's Xi make first contact since November with a 'check-in' call
SUMMARY: Tuesday's call between the two leaders followed through on a pledge they made in November for more frequent contact to try to help stabilize the U.S.-China relationship.

TITLE: 'SCTV' star and comedian Joe Flaherty dies at 82
SUMMARY: The Emmy winner starred with John Candy and Catherine O'Hara in "SCTV,″ about a fictional TV station. Flaherty's characters included network boss Guy Caballero and the vampiric TV host Count Floyd.

TITLE: Caitlin Clark once dreamed of going to UConn. Now, she'll face them in the Final Four
SUMMARY: Clark's freshman year at Iowa ended with a Sweet 16 loss to UConn. Now, with her aim on Iowa's first-ever championship to cap off her final season, a Final Four win over the Huskies must come first.

TITLE: A strong earthquake rocks Taiwan, collapsing buildings and causing a tsunami
SUMMARY: Taiwan's earthquake monitoring agency gave the magnitude as 7.2. The earthquake collapsed buildings in a southern city and created a tsunami that washed ashore on southern Japanese islands.

TITLE: Strong earthquake rocks Taiwan, collapsing buildings and triggering tsunami warnings
SUMMARY: The U.S. Geological Survey gave the magnitude as 7.4. The earthquake collapsed buildings and created a tsunami that washed ashore on southern Japanese islands.

TITLE: Taiwan's strongest earthquake in nearly 25 years damages buildings, leaving 4 dead
SUMMARY: The U.S. Geological Survey gave the magnitude as 7.4. The quake collapsed buildings and created a tsunami that washed ashore on southern Japanese islands. At least one person died, officials said.

TITLE: Amazon says it is removing Just Walk Out technology from its Fresh grocery stores
SUMMARY: Amazon says the technology will now be replaced by smart carts that allow customers to skip the checkout line but also see their spending in real time.

TITLE: Bird flu has been detected at the largest chicken egg manufacturer in the U.S.
SUMMARY: Cal-Maine Foods lost about 1.9 million chickens, or 3.6% of its flock, as a result of an outbreak at a Texas plant. However, the CDC says a person is unlikely to get bird flu from eggs.

TITLE: Taiwan is hit by its strongest earthquake in nearly 25 years
SUMMARY: The U.S. Geological Survey gave the magnitude as 7.4. The quake collapsed buildings and created a tsunami that washed ashore on southern Japanese islands. At least seven people died, officials said.

TITLE: Deadly severe weather roars through several states, spawning potential tornadoes
SUMMARY: Parts of Ohio, Pennsylvania, Kentucky, Mississippi, Alabama, Tennessee, West Virginia, Virginia and Georgia were under tornado watches, while Wisconsin was experiencing a spring snowstorm.

TITLE: April nor'easter could unload more than a foot of snow on much of New England
SUMMARY: New Englanders are bracing for high winds, treacherous roads and power outages. Southern New England and the coastline will get mostly rain, and maybe a few inches of snow.

TITLE: Ivan Fedotov was drafted by the Flyers 9 years ago. He just debuted this week
SUMMARY: The Philadelphia Flyers signed Fedotov in May 2022. But when Fedotov tried to leave Russia, he was detained on allegations of avoiding his duty to serve in the Russian military and forced to enlist.

TITLE: It's time to stop downsizing health care, the Pentagon says. This couple can't wait
SUMMARY: After a decade of outsourcing military health care, the Pentagon now plans to do the opposite, an about-face Matt and Helen Perry hope means they'll get the care they were promised after going to war.

TITLE: Florida's abortion fight is headed to voters after court allows for a 6-week ban
SUMMARY: Florida is at the center of the fight over abortion. As the state faces new restrictions and a November ballot question on abortion rights, Democrats see potential where they haven't in years.

TITLE: Most Americans say criminalizing abortion is wrong — and are divided on deportation
SUMMARY: A new NPR/PBS <em>NewsHour

TITLE: Taiwan holds steady in massive earthquake; Discontented voters show up in Wisconsin
SUMMARY: Taiwan holds steady after a massive earthquake shakes the region. Biden and Trump won their Wisconsin primaries, but discontented voters made their voices heard.

TITLE: Lou Conter, last survivor of the USS Arizona in Pearl Harbor, dies at 102
SUMMARY: The seaman had a storied career in the Navy. Over 27 years he served, he survived the surprise attack by Japan, was shot down over the Pacific and was uninjured in the Korean War.

TITLE: Photos: See the aftermath of the Taiwan earthquake
SUMMARY: Taiwan has been hit by the strongest earthquake in a quarter of a century.

TITLE: Tony-winning playwright Christopher Durang dies at 75
SUMMARY: Durang was a master of satire and black comedy who won a Tony Award for "Vanya and Sonia and Masha and Spike" and was a Pulitzer Prize finalist with "Miss Witherspoon."

TITLE: John Barth, innovative postmodernist novelist, dies at 93
SUMMARY: John Barth, the playfully erudite author whose darkly comic and complicated novels revolved around the art of literature and launched countless debates over the art of fiction, died Tuesday.

TITLE: Simple tips to safely photograph the eclipse with your cellphone
SUMMARY: Some people with expensive photo equipment are hoping to get the perfect shot during Monday's total solar eclipse. But for the rest of us, a cellphone camera is what we have to work with.

TITLE: Caitlin Clark and Angel Reese's LSU-Iowa rematch nets a record audience for ESPN
SUMMARY: Iowa and LSU attracted the second-largest audience for any basketball game on ESPN — college or pro — since 2012, the network said. The college basketball feast continues this Friday.

TITLE: The Aftermath of a Major Battle in Gaza
SUMMARY:
Israel's military laid siege to Gaza's largest medical complex for two weeks because, they said, Hamas fighters had regrouped inside. Following the Israeli withdrawal from the hospital, Palestinians were able to get a glimpse of the results of the raid.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Indiana lawmakers ban cellphones in class. Now it's up to schools to figure out how
SUMMARY: Many schools — but not all — in the state and around the U.S. already ban phones in class. This requires it now in Indiana.

TITLE: Biden met with a small group of Muslims yesterday. This doctor walked out
SUMMARY: The relationship between the White House and Arab-Americans and Muslims is fraught because of President Biden's support for Israel's war in Gaza,

TITLE: Glasses aren't just good for your eyes. They can be a boon to income, too
SUMMARY: That's the finding of a new study in Bangladesh, which gave reading glasses to hundreds of people and then measured their earnings.

TITLE: These are the World Central Kitchen aid workers killed by Israeli airstrike in Gaza
SUMMARY: Three of those killed by an Israeli airstrike were British and the others were Australian, Palestinian, Polish and a dual citizen of the U.S. and Canada.

TITLE: What the CDC is doing to monitor and protect against bird flu
SUMMARY: CDC director Dr. Mandy Cohen tells NPR that while the risk of bird flu spreading to humans is low, the U.S. government is taking precautions to avoid spread of the virus.

TITLE: Police haven't spoken with 'potentially involved' people in Rashee Rice-linked crash
SUMMARY: Saturday's hit-and-run crash involved two speeding cars on a Dallas highway. One of the cars that triggered the collision is believed to be registered under the Kansas City Chiefs player's name.

TITLE: April nor'easter is walloping New England with wind, rain and snow
SUMMARY: New Englanders are expecting treacherous roads and power outages. Southern New England and the coastline will get mostly rain, and maybe a few inches of snow, with most snow further north.

TITLE: Taiwan earthquake briefly halts chip factories that power the global economy
SUMMARY: The Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co., which makes more than 90% of world's most advanced chips, also halted production, but it plans to resume chipmaking overnight.

TITLE: Dallas police say they've now spoken with Rashee Rice about a hit-and-run crash
SUMMARY: Saturday's hit-and-run crash involved two speeding cars on a Dallas highway. One of the cars that triggered the collision is believed to be registered under the Kansas City Chiefs player's name.

TITLE: No more 'just walk out' at Amazon grocery stores. The new bet is smart shopping carts
SUMMARY: The retailer banked big on the cashier-less tech. It's now out at Amazon Fresh stores in the U.S. But Amazon's grocery ambitions are only shapeshifting.

TITLE: Amazon is cutting hundreds of jobs in its cloud computing unit AWS
SUMMARY: The AWS layoffs follow other layoffs that happened at Amazon and its subsidiaries this year, including at Prime Video, the MGM Studios unit and Twitch, the social media platform owned by Amazon.

TITLE: Powerball jackpot jumps to $1.23 billion after another drawing without a big winner
SUMMARY: The jackpot, which now ranks as the eighth-largest in U.S. lottery history, has been growing for more than three months, reflecting the long odds of 1 in 292.2 million of winning the top prize.

TITLE: Virginia lawmakers have voted to raise the marriage age to 18. Most states haven't
SUMMARY: The bill awaits action by the governor and would bar minors from getting married — something activists say leads to abuses.

TITLE: DOJ takes a stand against war crimes in Ukraine. In Gaza war, it's been nearly silent
SUMMARY: The Justice Department has taken an active — and public --stand against alleged Russian war crimes in Ukraine. But it's been nearly silent on possible war crimes in the Israel-Hamas war.

TITLE: Concrete structures meant to protect Baltimore bridge appear unchanged for decades
SUMMARY: Experts said if the Baltimore bridge had been outfitted with more robust collision-prevention structures, the collapse might have been avoided. Records indicate a lack of investment by the state.

TITLE: California colleges provide abortion pills but many fail to make students aware
SUMMARY: Despite a law mandating that they offer the pills, many campus health clinics don't publicize that they have them, leaving students struggling to track them down off-campus.

TITLE: Taiwan emerges remarkably unscathed after massive earthquake
SUMMARY: The day after what was the worst quake to hit the Asian island in a quarter century, most residents cannot stop talking about how much worse it could have been.

TITLE: What to know about the risks of the bird flu outbreak
SUMMARY: Cattle are getting sick with H5N1, and one person got sick in Texas. How bad could this be for dairy farms? Could it spread among people? Here's what scientists are learning.

TITLE: These twin brothers are identical, but their autism isn't
SUMMARY: Sam and John Fetters are identical twins with autism. But Sam is in college, while John still struggles to form sentences. Their experience may shed light on the disorder's mix of nature and nurture.

TITLE: A mayor in Ukraine aids his town's few remaining people, as Russia closes in
SUMMARY: Russian attacks have driven out most of Chasiv Yar's residents. NPR accompanies the mayor on a routine visit to check on those who remain.

TITLE: How does avian flu affect your breakfast; NATO solemnly celebrates 75th anniversary
SUMMARY: Cases of bird flu have been found in dairy cattle, but the risk to humans remains low. Ukraine is front and center today as NATO celebrates its 75th anniversary.

TITLE: Fish out of water story ends with 77,000 young salmon in the wrong water
SUMMARY: The Chinook got shook when their truck got cooked. Now the salmon are swimming — but in the wrong brook.

TITLE: Baltimore bridge's collapse is the target of anti-DEI rhetoric
SUMMARY: Mayor Brandon Scott has come under attack as a "DEI" hire in the wake of the deadly bridge collapse.

TITLE: A professor worried no one would read an algae study. So she had it put to music
SUMMARY: Professors and students at the University of South Florida mapped pitch, rhythm and duration to data about algae blooms and depletion of coral reefs to create an original composition.

TITLE: Biden warns Netanyahu that U.S. policy on Gaza hinges on improved conditions there
SUMMARY: President Biden spoke to Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu after seven aid workers with World Central Kitchen were killed in Israeli strikes. He said a ceasefire is needed so aid can get in.

TITLE: Why a majority of Britons want the U.K. to halt arms exports to Israel
SUMMARY: Countries including Canada, the Netherlands and Spain say they're suspending arms sales to Israel. After an Israeli strike killed British World Central Kitchen workers in Gaza, will the U.K. too?

TITLE: No Labels, which sought to challenge Biden and Trump, ends its 2024 presidential bid
SUMMARY: The organization had emerged earlier this year as a potentially well-funded force in the election. However, No Labels said Thursday that finding the right candidates proved difficult.

TITLE: Abortion opponents push for 'fetal personhood' laws, giving rights to embryos
SUMMARY: <em>The Guardian

TITLE: The work and legacy of photographer Anja Niedringhaus endure 10 years after her death
SUMMARY: A new exhibition and book honor the memory of the Pulitzer Prize-winning German photojournalist who was killed on April 4, 2014, while on assignment for The Associated Press in Afghanistan.

TITLE: What you need to know to watch Monday's total solar eclipse
SUMMARY: Over 30 million people will be within the path of totality for Monday's solar eclipse as it crosses the U.S. from Texas to Maine. Here's what you need to know to safely enjoy the celestial spectacle.

TITLE: Investigative journalists track suspected cartel boss using his google reviews
SUMMARY: NPR's Mary Louise Kelly speaks with open source researcher Connor Plunkett, about his report with Bellingcat titled "Kinahan Cartel: Wanted Narco Boss Exposes Whereabouts by Posting Google Reviews."

TITLE: A Milestone for a Major International Alliance and an Olympic Music Controversy
SUMMARY: NATO, the alliance formed to protect Europe from the Soviet Union is marking 75 years. It the focus is still on Russia.

TITLE: Judge rules Trump's Mar-a-Lago classified documents case can proceed
SUMMARY: The former president's lawyers cited the Presidential Records Act in asking that the government's case be dismissed. Judge Aileen Cannon denied the motion — clearing the way for it to proceed.

TITLE: Baltimore mayor faces racist attacks after bridge collapse
SUMMARY: Baltimore Mayor Brandon Scott has been the target of racist attacks following last week's Key Bridge collapse.

TITLE: Where are you going to view the solar eclipse? NPR wants to know.
SUMMARY: Tell NPR where you plan to watch the total solar eclipse on April 8.

TITLE: ATF: 68,000 guns were illegally trafficked through unlicensed dealers over 5 years
SUMMARY: The more than 68,000 illegally trafficked firearms represents 54% of such weapons in the U.S. between 2017 and 2021, Justice Department officials said.

TITLE: McDonald's says it is buying back all of its franchises in Israel
SUMMARY: Alonyal Limited owns 225 McDonald's locations. McDonald's has recently faced boycotts after its Israel branch donated meals to the Israeli military.

TITLE: Using AI to detect AI-generated deepfakes can work for audio — but not always
SUMMARY: Now that people can easily create real-sounding voices with artificial intelligence, detection technologies are racing to catch deepfake audio, but it's a tough game of whack-a-mole.

TITLE: Black market cannabis thrives in California despite legalization
SUMMARY: Marijuana legalization was expected to bring the industry out of the shadows. But in some states, the black market is alive and well.

TITLE: 'We want to help': Why climate activists are trying something new
SUMMARY: A recent disruption at <em>An Enemy of the People

TITLE: 'I don't hear the sound of bullets': At this camp in Rwanda, people find some peace
SUMMARY: The Nkamira Transit Center is home to thousands of refugees who fled violence in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. The decades-long conflict is a legacy of the 1994 Rwandan genocide.

TITLE: U.S.-Israel politics set to roil Democratic primaries
SUMMARY: Republican donors and pro-Israel Democrats are working to defeat some of the most liberal members of the House for their criticism of Israel in its handling of the ongoing war with Hamas.

TITLE: From a secret CIA mission to clearing the Baltimore bridge — meet 'Chessy' the crane
SUMMARY: There aren't many cranes that have a storied history like the Chesapeake 1000 — nicknamed "Chessy" — which has been brought in to clear Baltimore's Francis Scott Key Bridge.

TITLE: Tournament darling DJ Burns and N.C. State head to the Final 4, smiles, skips and all
SUMMARY: North Carolina State's unlikely run in this year's NCAA tournament has been propelled by their charming star DJ Burns Jr., whose big size and big personality have made him a fan favorite this March.

TITLE: Thinking of taking a last-minute drive to see the eclipse? Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Experts say you should gas up before you go, and plan to stay for a while afterward.

TITLE: Who posted Donald Trump's $175 million bond this week? Find out in the quiz
SUMMARY: This week, the April 8 total solar eclipse inspired <em>Barbie

TITLE: This L.A. heist sounds like a thriller novel. Thieves stole $30 million in cash
SUMMARY: Thieves got away with $30 million in cash from a money storage facility in Los Angeles by breaking into the building on Easter and cracking the safe. Now detectives are seeking to unravel the heist.

TITLE: This LA heist sounds like a thriller novel. Thieves stole $30 million in cash
SUMMARY: Thieves got away with $30 million in cash from a money storage facility in Los Angeles by breaking into the building on Easter and cracking the safe. Now detectives are seeking to unravel the heist.

TITLE: Biden orders Israel to change course on Gaza aid; No Labels backs out of 2024 race
SUMMARY: Israel will let aid into northern Gaza after Biden warned that U.S. support would depend on how Israel addresses civilian suffering. No Labels has backed out of the 2024 presidential election.

TITLE: UN human rights body calls for halt to weapons shipments to Israel
SUMMARY: While non-binding, the resolution passed Friday is bound to raise international pressure on Israel as a sign of widespread concern about its military campaign in Gaza.

TITLE: Israel's military dismisses officers over World Central Kitchen airstrike
SUMMARY: An investigation by the Israeli military's general staff concluded the airstrike, which killed seven aid workers, violated its standards and "should not have occurred."

TITLE: Violence in eastern Congo has displaced millions. Some end up at this camp
SUMMARY: The Nkamira Transit Center is home to thousands of refugees who fled violence in the eastern Democratic Republic of Congo. The decades-long conflict is a legacy of the 1994 Rwandan genocide.

TITLE: Here's what time the eclipse will be visible in your region
SUMMARY: This tool from NASA allows you to get your exact window to see Monday's eclipse; all you need is your zip code.

TITLE: Seeking to defy history, the UAW is coming closer to unionizing in the South
SUMMARY: Autoworkers at Volkswagen's plant in Chattanooga, Tenn., will vote in mid-April on whether to join the United Auto Workers union. Mercedes workers in Tuscaloosa County, Ala., will soon follow.

TITLE: This year, colleges must choose between fast financial aid offers, or accurate ones
SUMMARY: Colleges don't yet trust the FAFSA data the U.S. Education Department is sending them, but there's pressure to get aid offers out to students as soon as possible.

TITLE: The banjo is a star of Beyoncé's new album. Turns out it has African roots
SUMMARY: In "Texas Hold 'Em," the singer is accompanied by a banjo. It's often thought of as a quintessential Americana instrument. But the history of the banjo tells a different story.

TITLE: 129 days: How one Israeli hostage in Gaza told stories to endure captivity
SUMMARY: Luis Har, 71, was taken hostage on Oct. 7 with his family. The accountant, actor and dancer drew on a lifetime of memories to help comfort them in captivity in Gaza. He was freed in an Israeli raid.

TITLE: How to keep pets safe during the solar eclipse, whether at home or on the road
SUMMARY: Experts say pets are unlikely to be impacted by the eclipse itself — but there are steps their humans should take to help them deal with the crowds, traffic and stress.

TITLE: Construction boom helps fuel job gains in March
SUMMARY: U.S. employers added 303,000 jobs last month, and the unemployment rate dipped to 3.8%. Construction companies added 39,000 jobs, despite high interest rates.

TITLE: 99 Cents stores to close down all 371 locations
SUMMARY: The discount chain is winding down operations at its stores across California, Texas, Arizona and Nevada, as dollar stores nationwide buckle under inflation, shoplifting and other factors.

TITLE: Is DEI a slur now? Plus, control & basketball
SUMMARY:
Following the collapse of the Francis Scott Key Bridge in Baltimore last week, the city's 39 year old mayor, Brandon Scott, a Black man, stepped out to address the crisis. Hours later, a tweet went viral calling Scott a "DEI Mayor." To which Brittany and her guests, NPR's Gene Demby and Alana Wise, say "wait what?" The three dig into the racism lurking under the surface of this kind of rhetoric.

Then, as March Madness reaches its final nail-biting stages, Brittany takes a look at the reality of "student-athletes." What may feel like an accurate descriptor of these players is actually a legal classification that bars them from asking for worker's compensation and other benefits - benefits usually given to employees

TITLE: Many 911 call centers are understaffed, and the job has gotten harder
SUMMARY: More cities are adopting alternative response models, where mental health clinicians respond instead of police. The question of who to send usually rests with 911 workers, who are often overworked and overstressed.

TITLE: Biden wants union labor to rebuild the Baltimore bridge. That could touch off a fight
SUMMARY: The House Freedom Caucus has said environmental and union wage regulations should be waived if federal money is used to rebuild Baltimore's Francis Scott Key Bridge.

TITLE: Ticket prices for the women's Final Four games rival the men's
SUMMARY: Call it the Caitlin Clark effect: The average sales price for a ticket to the women's college basketball semifinal was nearly double that of the men's event, the ticketing company Logitix reported.

TITLE: Police shot Nakala Murry's young son. Now, she could lose custody of her kids.
SUMMARY: Nakala Murry spoke exclusively to NPR about a petition that references the May 2023 shooting of Aderrien Murry. She said the move "caught her off guard."

TITLE: Trump demands a new judge just days before the start of his hush-money criminal trial
SUMMARY: Trump's lawyers urged Manhattan Judge Juan M. Merchan to step aside from the case, alleging bias and a conflict of interest because his daughter is a Democratic political consultant.

TITLE: Mexico's president says country will break diplomatic ties with Ecuador
SUMMARY: The announcement came after Ecuadorian police officers forcibly broke into the Mexican embassy in Quito, detaining former Ecuadorian Vice President Jorge Glas, who was seeking political asylum there.

TITLE: Powerball jackpot climbs to $1.3B ahead of Saturday night's drawing
SUMMARY: There have been 40 consecutive drawings since the last time someone won Powerball's top prize on New Year's Day. The jackpot ranks as the eighth largest in U.S. lottery history.

TITLE: Clouds and rain? Here's how to still enjoy the total solar eclipse
SUMMARY: Rain, thunderstorms and gray skies over large swaths of the path of totality are threatening to block views on April 8. Here's how to make the most of the rare event.

TITLE: Here's what we found after Israel's raid on Al-Shifa, Gaza's biggest hospital
SUMMARY: NPR photos show the Gaza Strip's biggest hospital in ruins after an Israeli raid. Israel says the siege only targeted militants. Palestinians recount a different story.

TITLE: Want to see how a solar eclipse alters colors? Wear red and green on Monday
SUMMARY: Eclipses change the light around us, leading to unusual sights. Monday's solar eclipse also brings a chance to see crescent shapes in shadows and pinholes, as the moon moves in front of the sun.

TITLE: Blended families are common. Here are tips to help stepsiblings get along
SUMMARY: Researchers have learned a lot about blended families since the 1970s — when <em>The Brady Bunch

TITLE: A lot of kids got to see the last total eclipse. What they remember may surprise you
SUMMARY: Total solar eclipse chasers say that seeing the moon block out the sun, revealing the corona, is a life-changing experience. Kids, on the other hand, remember eating moon pies.

TITLE: Can't make it to the total eclipse? 5 fun ways to bring wonder and awe into your life
SUMMARY: Yes, viewing a total solar eclipse can be beautiful and life-altering. But so can many other things in life.

TITLE: March fundraising numbers show Biden significantly outpacing Trump
SUMMARY: The Biden reelection campaign and Democratic National Committee significantly outraised former President Donald Trump and the Republican Party last month, new fundraising numbers show.

TITLE: How 6 months of Israel's war in Gaza have upended the Middle East
SUMMARY: Three NPR correspondents look at how the Israel-Hamas war is reshaping the region, and what might come next.

TITLE: Photos: Israel and Gaza, 6 months into the war
SUMMARY: It's been six months since Hamas-led militants attacked Israel, prompting Israel's assault on the Gaza Strip. NPR photographers have covered the war's effects on Israelis, Palestinians and the region.

TITLE: Israel says it has recovered the body of Israeli hostage Elad Katzir in Gaza
SUMMARY: Elad Katzir, 47, was from Nir Oz, a kibbutz near the Gaza border. The small community of 400 residents was among the hardest hit in Israel by Hamas-led attackers on Oct. 7.

TITLE: Some Walmart shoppers could get up to $500 in cash from a class-action settlement
SUMMARY: Customers who bought certain grocery products at Walmart stores nationwide between October 2018 and January 2024 have until early June to file for payments, whether or not they kept their receipts.

TITLE: ABBA fans celebrate 'Waterloo' Eurovision victory, 50 years on
SUMMARY: The song's win at Eurovision Song Contest on April 6, 1974 launched the Swedish supergroup on its path to success.

TITLE: Authorities investigate suspected arson at Sen. Bernie Sanders' Vermont office
SUMMARY: Burlington police say a male suspect set a door on fire Friday morning, trapping people inside and damaging the building. No injuries were reported, and Sanders wasn't in the state at the time.

TITLE: Iowa-UConn women's Final Four game is the most-watched hoops game in ESPN history
SUMMARY: Friday's semifinal averaged 14.2 million viewers, making it the most-viewed women's basketball game on record and the largest audience for an ESPN basketball broadcast.

TITLE: Yellen says US-China relationship on 'more stable footing' but more can be done
SUMMARY: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen met Sunday in Beijing with Chinese Premier Li Qiang and sent a message of mutual cooperation despite the nations' differences.

TITLE: Powerball draws numbers for estimated $1.3B jackpot after over 3 hour delay
SUMMARY: Powerball drew the numbers early Sunday morning for an estimated $1.3 billion jackpot after a delay of more than three hours.

TITLE: Pro-Russia candidate Peter Pellegrini elected Slovakia president
SUMMARY: A close ally of populist Prime Minister Robert Fico beat a pro-Western career diplomat to become Slovakia's new president, and succeed Zuzana Čaputová, the country's first female head of state.

TITLE: Bill Clinton and other leaders join Rwandans in marking 30 years since their genocide
SUMMARY: Rwandans are commemorating 30 years since the genocide in which an estimated 800,000 people were killed by government-backed extremists, shattering the small East African country.

TITLE: Yes, Biden is really running in November. But a lot of voters say they doubt it
SUMMARY: Some people feel he's too old. Others think there's a plan afoot to swap in a more popular Democrat. There's a swirl of reasons why some people don't accept that Biden will be on the ballot this year.

TITLE: Key voting groups are shifting in the race between Biden and Trump
SUMMARY: President Biden and former President Donald Trump are still very close in polling on the 2024 presidential election. But below the surface, so key demographic groups appear to be shifting loyalty.

TITLE: How people across the U.S. are making the most of the solar eclipse
SUMMARY: NPR asked listeners to share what they're doing for the eclipse. Here are some memorable answers, from the new parents planning a themed baby shower to the mayor waving tourists off his small city.

TITLE: Powerball player wins $1.3 billion jackpot, after over 3 months without a grand prize
SUMMARY: A Powerball player has won a $1.3 billion jackpot, ending a winless streak that had stretched more than three months.

TITLE: Using your phone to pay is convenient, but it can also mean you spend more
SUMMARY: Consumers tend to spend about 10% more when they adopt mobile contactless payment methods, according to research from Assistant Professor Yuqian Xu at UNC-Chapel Hill.

TITLE: Israel pulls some troops from southern Gaza, 6 months after Oct. 7 attacks
SUMMARY: Israel withdraws troops from Khan Younis six months after the Hamas-led Oct. 7 attacks, as tens of thousands of Israelis hold anti-government protests.

TITLE: South Carolina defeats Iowa to win the women's national basketball championship
SUMMARY: The undefeated Gamecocks won their third NCAA title, and stole Iowa star Caitlin Clark's first and last chance at the ring.

TITLE: South Carolina defeats Iowa to win the women's NCAA basketball championship
SUMMARY: The undefeated Gamecocks won their third NCAA title, and stole Iowa star Caitlin Clark's first and last chance at the ring.

TITLE: The winning Powerball ticket worth $1.3 billion was sold in Oregon
SUMMARY: A Powerball player in Portland, Ore., has won a $1.3 billion jackpot, ending a winless streak that stretched more than three months.

TITLE: Attacks on Zaporizhzhia nuclear plant increases accident risk, IAEA head says
SUMMARY: The head of the U.N.'s atomic watchdog agency on Sunday condemned a Ukrainian drone strike on one of six nuclear reactors at the Russian-controlled Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant in Ukraine.

TITLE: Yellen says U.S.-China relationship on 'more stable footing' but more can be done
SUMMARY: U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen met Sunday in Beijing with Chinese Premier Li Qiang and sent a message of mutual cooperation despite the nations' differences.

TITLE: Isabel Allende tells a story of impossible love in 'Lovers at the Museum'
SUMMARY: We spoke with the prolific, 81-year-old author about her new short story — a powerful allegory of the human condition and the mystery of love — and also AI and what's she's working on now.

TITLE: Biden seeks student debt relief for millions
SUMMARY: The sweeping new proposals, if enacted, could ease student loan debt for millions of borrowers.

TITLE: Unauthorized ACA plan switches drives call for action against rogue agents
SUMMARY: Federal and state regulators are mulling what they can do to thwart the growing problem. Rogue health insurance brokers are switching consumers' plans without permission and collecting the commission.

TITLE: Trump declines to back nationwide abortion ban, says it should be left to the states
SUMMARY: Pressure has mounted on Trump to make his own views on abortion public after the Florida Supreme Court allowed the state's six-week ban on abortion to go into effect.

TITLE: Student loan proposal targets accrued interest; Israel and Hamas war hits six months
SUMMARY: Biden administration targets accrued interest in latest student loan relief proposal. Israel withdraws troops as the Israel-Hamas war reaches the six month mark.

TITLE: Unauthorized ACA plan switches drive call for action against rogue agents
SUMMARY: Federal and state regulators are mulling what they can do to thwart the growing problem. Rogue health insurance brokers are switching consumers' plans without permission and collecting the commission.

TITLE: They had 3 suitcases and faced 5 flights of stairs. That's when a stranger appeared
SUMMARY: Alice Claus and her sister were exhausted after a long flight to Budapest. Then a young man on the street offered help right when they needed it.

TITLE: Morgan Wallen arrested for throwing a chair from a rooftop bar in Nashville
SUMMARY: The country music star was arrested on four charges, including reckless endangerment and disorderly conduct. The chair, thrown from a rooftop bar, landed on the street close to two police officers.

TITLE: Hundreds of balloons go airborne to witness the eclipse from the edge of space
SUMMARY: A NASA-backed program to launch research balloons is designed to study the atmosphere while training students.

TITLE: Jonathan Majors avoids jail time in assault and harassment sentencing
SUMMARY: The actor's once-rocketing career was derailed after he was found guilty of assaulting and harassing his then-girlfriend, Grace Jabbari, during an incident in Manhattan in March 2023.

TITLE: The Vatican says surrogacy and gender theory are 'grave threats' to human dignity
SUMMARY: A document called "Infinite Dignity" details what the Vatican sees as grave violations of dignity. Poverty, war and the abuse of migrants lead the list.

TITLE: Held Hostage by Hamas for 51 Days
SUMMARY:
Aviva Siegel was among the more than 200 Israelis taken hostage by Hamas on October 7th. She was held 51 days before being released. Her husband, Keith, who is a U.S. citizen, is still being held in Gaza. We hear about Aviva Siegel's time in captivity and her advocacy for the release of Keith and the remaining hostages.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Brazil's Supreme Court judge opens an investigation of Elon Musk over misinformation
SUMMARY: A Brazilian Supreme Court justice included Elon Musk as a target in an ongoing investigation over the dissemination of fake news and opened a separate investigation into Musk for alleged obstruction.

TITLE: Americans await the eclipse, with glasses secured and fingers crossed for clear skies
SUMMARY: The eclipse is fast approaching the U.S. Cities and states in the path of totality have issued emergency declarations to help manage traffic, and meteorologists are readying their final forecasts.

TITLE: Hungry for eclipse deals? These food and drink chains have you covered
SUMMARY: Food and beverage franchises are celebrating the eclipse with discounts and special offers for customers across the U.S., regardless of whether they're in the path of totality.

TITLE: Mexico's beach party is excited to see the eclipse first emerge
SUMMARY: The Mexican city of Mazatlán is the first place the total solar eclipse will be visible as it emerges over the Pacific Ocean today, and the weather here is perfect.

TITLE: Worried about eclipse damage to your eyes? Don't panic
SUMMARY: Eye damage is rare and sometimes temporary, but it never hurts to get it checked.

TITLE: Solar eclipse myths and rumors bubble up, from radiation to food poisoning
SUMMARY: NASA debunks these and other myths: Will a solar eclipse harm a pregnant woman's baby if she looks at it? Does an eclipse emit special radiation that can instantly blind you?

TITLE: Americans are getting into place as the eclipse approaches
SUMMARY: The eclipse is fast approaching the U.S. Cities and states in the path of totality have issued emergency declarations to help manage traffic, and meteorologists are readying their final forecasts.

TITLE: Montreal reports great conditions for a solar eclipse watch party in the park
SUMMARY: Montreal is in the path of totality, and its largest eclipse-watching event is taking place in Parc Jean-Drapeau.

TITLE: Trump's Truth Social shares are plunging again, erasing billions of dollars in value
SUMMARY: Truth Social shares fell sharply for a second consecutive day, wiping out billions of dollars from the value of Donald J. Trump's stake.

TITLE: A rare solar eclipse darkened skies and dazzled viewers across the U.S.
SUMMARY: Crowds and clouds didn't stop people from gathering across the path of totality. Viewers craned their necks and clapped as skies briefly darkened, a sight the U.S. won't see again until 2044.

TITLE: NAIA all but bans transgender athletes from women's sports
SUMMARY: The National Association of Intercollegiate Athletics, which oversees some 83,000 athletes competing in more than 25 sports, is thought to be the first college sports organization to take such a step.

TITLE: The UConn men's basketball team has won back-to-back NCAA championships
SUMMARY: The men's Huskies team is the first to win the NCAA basketball tournament back-to-back since the University of Florida in 2006 and 2007.

TITLE: March is 10th straight month to be hottest on record, scientists say
SUMMARY: For the 10th consecutive month, Earth set a new monthly record for global heat — with both air temperatures and the world's oceans hitting an all-time high, the European Union climate agency said.

TITLE: Young adults who started vaping as teens still can't shake the habit
SUMMARY: Teen vaping is trending downwards these days. But data from Colorado and around the country show the generation that made Juul cool is still hooked on nicotine.

TITLE: The most detailed look yet at the 'exodus' of local voting officials
SUMMARY: A new report finds more election officials are leaving their jobs now than at any point in the past two decades. But the report also adds new context to the phenomenon.

TITLE: Is climate change action a human right? A European court will rule for the first time
SUMMARY: Europe's highest human rights court began its session Tuesday on a group of climate change cases aimed at forcing countries to meet international obligations to reduce greenhouse gas emissions.

TITLE: NASA has been asked to create a time zone for the moon. Here's how it would work
SUMMARY: A new lunar time zone is all about ensuring the success of future, multinational missions to the moon.

TITLE: The true story behind Netflix's 'Scoop' and the Prince Andrew interview on Epstein
SUMMARY: Sam McAlister was the BBC booker who persuaded Prince Andrew to go on record about his friendship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. It's the subject of new Netflix movie <em>Scoop

TITLE: For one Nigerian family, freedom after a kidnapping hasn't ended their terror
SUMMARY: Ten years after the mass abduction of 276 Chibok schoolgirls, kidnapping in Nigeria continues to rise. Nearly 1,000 people were kidnapped in the first three months of 2024. Here is one family's story.

TITLE: In the womb, a brother's hormones can shape a sister's future
SUMMARY: When siblings share a womb, sex hormones from a male fetus can cause lasting changes in a female littermate. This effect exists for all kinds of mammals — perhaps humans too.

TITLE: Arkansas led the nation sending letters home from school about obesity. Did it help?
SUMMARY: About 20 years ago, Arkansas started weighing children in school and sending home letters to try to combat obesity. Even though obesity rates only have risen, many other states picked up the policy.

TITLE: European court rules on cases seeking to force countries to meet climate goals
SUMMARY: Europe's highest human rights court ruled Tuesday that its member nations have an obligation to protect their citizens from the ill effects of climate change.

TITLE: One of these novelists will receive the $150K Carol Shields Prize
SUMMARY: The shortlist for the Carol Shields Prize was announced Tuesday morning. The award recognizes "creativity and excellence in fiction by women and non-binary writers in Canada and the United States."

TITLE: Trump says abortion should be left to states; Vatican takes stance on gender theory
SUMMARY: Trump says abortion should be left to states, the Vatican released a new document calling gender theory a "grave threat" to society.

TITLE: International Booker Prize shortlist for 2024 spans three continents
SUMMARY: The International Booker Prize celebrates fiction that's been translated into English. This year's shortlist, announced Tuesday morning, features books in six languages from three continents.

TITLE: Senate to begin Mayorkas impeachment trial this week. Here's what you need to know
SUMMARY: The Senate is set this this week to begin the impeachment trial for Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas.

TITLE: 'A masterclass in how to give terrible answers': Inside that Prince Andrew interview
SUMMARY: Sam McAlister was the BBC booker who persuaded Prince Andrew to go on record about his friendship with convicted sex offender Jeffrey Epstein. It's the subject of new Netflix movie <em>Scoop

TITLE: Israel's Palestinian citizens grow louder in protesting the Gaza war
SUMMARY: Palestinian citizens make up 20% of Israel's population, and many grieve the suffering in Gaza. Hundreds were arrested or lost jobs for questioning the war there, and doing so can still be perilous.

TITLE: Chechnya is banning music that's too fast or slow. These songs wouldn't make the cut
SUMMARY: Authorities in the Russian republic of Chechnya will only allow music between 80 and 116 beats per minute, though it's unclear how the rule will be enforced.

TITLE: James and Jennifer Crumbley, school shooter's parents, sentenced to 10-15 years
SUMMARY: Both Crumbleys were convicted on four counts of involuntary manslaughter over the 2021 shooting at Michigan's Oxford High School carried out by their son, Ethan Crumbley, who was 15 at the time.

TITLE: The Arizona Supreme Court allows a near-total abortion ban to take effect soon
SUMMARY: The Arizona Supreme Court has ruled that an old law from the 1860s can stand in the state, outlawing nearly all abortions.

TITLE: Norfolk Southern will pay $600 million to settle East Palestine derailment lawsuit
SUMMARY: Norfolk Southern has agreed to settle a class-action lawsuit stemming from the fiery train derailment in East Palestine, Ohio in early 2023.

TITLE: How is the Movie "Oppenheimer" Being Received in Japan?
SUMMARY: Understandably, a movie about the man who steered the development of atomic bombs is seen differently in a country where some 200,000 people were killed by those bombs. "Oppenheimer" opened in Japan 8 months after premiering in the U.S.  Our reporter talks to movie goers in Nagasaki, Japan.

TITLE: Peter Higgs, who proposed the existence of the so-called 'God particle,' has died
SUMMARY: Higgs predicted the existence of the Higgs boson particle, helping explain how matter formed after the Big Bang. His death at 94 was announced by the University of Edinburgh, where he was a professor.

TITLE: Here are the 42 questions on the juror questionnaire in Trump's hush money case
SUMMARY: Jurors will be asked to identify the the news and social media programs they use, podcasts they listen to and if they have supported or been a member of white supremacist and extremist groups.

TITLE: Terrance the octopus came to live with a family. Then she laid dozens of eggs
SUMMARY: The Clifford family was as prepared as possible to welcome Terrance the octopus. But there was one thing they missed: she was pregnant. And then she laid a whole lot of eggs.

TITLE: Learning To Live As Neighbors In The Shadow Of A Brutal, Violent History
SUMMARY:
Many of us don't have the opportunity to handpick our neighbors. We buy or rent a place in a neighborhood with good schools or an easy commute.

Some of us become friends with those who live nearby, others of us never talk to our neighbors at all. For most though, we co-exist.

In the midst of a brutal civil war, neighbors killed their neighbors simply because of who they were.

Thirty years ago this month, that wasn't the case in Rwanda.

We visit a Rwandan village where how neighbors live alongside one another is deliberate, and complicated.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: A Boeing whistleblower raises fresh concerns about the 787, and the FAA investigates
SUMMARY: The FAA says it is investigating a whistleblower's claims about flaws in the assembly of Boeing's 787 Dreamliner. The company calls those allegations inaccurate, and insists the plane is safe to fly.

TITLE: James and Jennifer Crumbley, a school shooter's parents, are sentenced to 10-15 years
SUMMARY: Both Crumbleys were convicted on four counts of involuntary manslaughter tied to the 2021 shooting at Michigan's Oxford High School carried out by their son, Ethan Crumbley, who was 15 at the time.

TITLE: Ex-assistant principal charged with child neglect in case of boy who shot teacher
SUMMARY: A former assistant principal at a Virginia elementary school has been charged with felony child neglect more than a year after a 6-year-old boy brought a gun to class and shot a teacher.

TITLE: NPR defends its journalism after senior editor says it has lost the public's trust
SUMMARY: A veteran NPR editor publicly questions whether the public radio network has, in its push for greater diversity and representation, overlooked conservative viewpoints.

TITLE: Prosecutors say an Idaho man planned a church attack to support the Islamic State
SUMMARY: Authorities said Alexander Scott Mercurio adopted the Muslim faith against his Christian parents' wishes and was in contact with FBI informants posing as Islamic State group supporters.

TITLE: Elections reveal a growing gender divide across South Korea
SUMMARY: While many other developed countries are observing a similar phenomenon, experts say South Korea's fast social development and politicization of gender issues make its case particularly intense.

TITLE: How much aid's waiting to enter Gaza? Depends who you ask
SUMMARY: Humanitarian aid trucks sit at Gaza's border. Yet Israeli officials deny aid groups' accusations that they're restricting aid or that Palestinians in Gaza are starving.

TITLE: EPA puts limits on 'forever chemicals' in drinking water
SUMMARY: PFAS chemicals have been used for decades to waterproof and stain-proof consumer products and are linked to health problems.

TITLE: The government announced winners of a contest to tell real voices from deepfake audio
SUMMARY: Four organizations won a FTC contest for their tools that help tell real audio clips from deepfakes. The winners' approaches illuminate challenges AI audio deepfakes pose.

TITLE: A gunman stole his twin from him. This is what he's learned about grieving a sibling
SUMMARY: About 60,000 children a year in the U.S. lose a sibling. Zion Kelly joined that unlucky group in 2017 when his twin, Zaire, was killed. Zion has learned a lot about grief, and himself, since then.

TITLE: Women's NCAA championship TV ratings crush the men's competition
SUMMARY: At its peak, 24 million basketball fans tuned in to watch the  women's championship between Iowa and South Carolina, making it the most-watched basketball game since 2019.

TITLE: Tension at Al-Aqsa Mosque is deepening with each day of the Israel-Hamas war
SUMMARY: Friction between Palestinians, Jewish activists and police over Jerusalem's religious sites are a flashpoint of the Israeli-Palestinian conflict. The war in Gaza has brought the tensions to the fore.

TITLE: Arizona says century-old abortion ban can be enforced; EPA limits 'forever chemicals'
SUMMARY: Arizona's Supreme Court says an abortion ban passed during the Civil War should be the law of the land today. The EPA is putting limits on PFAS in drinking water.

TITLE: Okinawa feels impact of U.S. and Japan military shifts
SUMMARY: Okinawa, which sits closer to China than to Japan's main islands, is the focus of U.S. and Japanese efforts to beef up defenses in Japan's southwest islands.

TITLE: A first glimpse of Khan Younis, a Gaza city now lying in ruins
SUMMARY: Israeli troops withdrew Sunday from the city after a four-month battle against Hamas. Displaced Palestinians returning there found immense destruction. Most went back to living in tents in Rafah.

TITLE: National Siblings Day is a celebration born of love — and grief
SUMMARY: Claudia Evart, a woman who lost both her sister and her brother in separate accidents, created the day to honor the special relationships between siblings. It is on April 10 every year.

TITLE: Why beating inflation is turning out to be as hard as losing weight
SUMMARY: Annual inflation proved to be hotter than expected last month, staying stubbornly above 3%. It continues to move in the wrong month in recent months. Pushing it lower is proving to be hard.

TITLE: Biden is hosting Japan's Kishida. But the Nippon Steel deal is not on the agenda
SUMMARY: President BIden and Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida Fumio will announce efforts to strengthen military ties, as well as collaborations on space exploration and artificial intelligence.

TITLE: Real-life 'Rosie the Riveters' reunite in D.C. to win the nation's top civilian honor
SUMMARY: Rosie the Riveter became an iconic symbol of the millions of women who worked industrial jobs during WWII. Dozens, now in their 90s and 100s, are accepting a Congressional gold medal on their behalf.

TITLE: Seizures, broken spines and vomiting: Scientific testing that helped facilitate D-Day
SUMMARY: Biomedical engineer Rachel Lance says British scientists submitted themselves to experiments that would be considered wildly unethical today in an effort to shore up the war effort.

TITLE: 6 months into war, Palestinians face high unemployment and a 'disastrous' economy
SUMMARY: A Palestinian Authority official says there are around 700,000 Palestinians in the West Bank and Gaza who have gone six months without work since the war between Israel and Hamas began on Oct. 7.

TITLE: World Athletics will pay $50,000 to Olympic gold medalists in track and field events
SUMMARY: The prizes, which will also go to the winners of the marathon and race walk, come as the Olympic Games have shifted away from amateurism. Many medalists already earn bonuses from their home countries.

TITLE: Trump backed a federal abortion ban as president. Now, he says he wouldn't sign one.
