SUMMARY: The former president has a long history of shifting - and at times confusing - stances on abortion rights.

TITLE: Consumer Reports asks USDA to remove Lunchables from schools' lunch menus
SUMMARY: The group found high levels of sodium and the presence of heavy metals in meal kits it tested. A Kraft Heinz spokesperson said all of its products meet strict safety standards.

TITLE: Why are Young Men and Women in South Korea Drifting Apart Politically?
SUMMARY:
While the ideological gender gap among young people is widening across the developed world, it is particularly alarming in South Korea. Experts are concerned about what it means for the country's future. Our reporter in Seoul examines the phenomenon.

Sign up for State of the World+ to listen sponsor-free and support the work of NPR journalists. Visit plus.npr.org

TITLE: Why anti-abortion advocates are reviving a 19th century sexual purity law
SUMMARY: The Comstock Act is the latest front in the fight over reproductive rights. Here's what you need to know about the 1873 law and the consequences if it's enforced the way some conservatives would like.

TITLE: Trump backed a federal abortion ban as president. Now, he says he wouldn't sign one
SUMMARY: The former president has a long history of shifting - and at times confusing - stances on abortion rights.

TITLE: 10 writers win 2024 Whiting Awards for emerging authors
SUMMARY: Each writer will receive $50,000 to help support their craft — one of largest awards granted to new authors.

TITLE: EU lawmakers approve an overhaul of the bloc's migration laws
SUMMARY: European Union lawmakers have approved a major revamp of the bloc's migration laws, hoping to end years of division  and deprive the far right of a vote-winning campaign issue ahead of June elections.

TITLE: Want to be a more confident decision maker? Try these classic negotiation tactics
SUMMARY: Negotiating isn't just for salary discussions. You can use it to divide up domestic labor, decide on a restaurant or deal with customer service representatives, says negotiation coach Joan Moon. Learn how to deploy classic business negotiation techniques to improve your everyday life.

TITLE: South Korea's opposition wins in landslide parliamentary elections
SUMMARY: South Korea's liberal opposition wins nearly two-thirds of the seats in parliamentary elections, blowing a crushing defeat to President Yoon Suk Yeol.

TITLE: Japan will give new cherry trees to replace those lost in D.C. construction
SUMMARY: Japan is giving the U.S. 250 new cherry trees to help replace the hundreds that are being ripped out this summer as construction crews work to repair the seawall around the capital's Tidal Basin.

TITLE: In this Rwandan village, survivors and perpetrators of the genocide live side by side
SUMMARY: It's been 30 years since the Rwandan genocide. In some places today, survivors live side-by-side with perpetrators in so-called reconciliation villages.

TITLE: Most doxxing campaigns only last a few days. But the effects can be felt for months
SUMMARY: Doxxing campaigns have been used to "name and shame" people who have expressed opinions about the Israel-Hamas war.

TITLE: Here's the new plan to boost background checks for guns bought at shows or online
SUMMARY: The Justice Department's new rule requires background checks for all gun sales, not just ones sold at gun stores. Attorney General Merrick Garland said it will save lives.

TITLE: How Florida and Arizona Supreme Court rulings change the abortion access map
SUMMARY: How far do women have to travel to access abortion care? An economics professor has been tracking that data since 2009. Interactive maps show how access has changed dramatically since 2021.

TITLE: White-sounding names get called back for jobs more than Black ones, a new study finds
SUMMARY: Economists sent 83,000 fake job applications to a slew of major U.S. companies, and found that the typical firm favored white applicants over Black ones by around 9%.

TITLE: So long, skinny jeans. See you in the next cycle
SUMMARY: Skinny jeans are out and looser pants are in. But it's so much more than that. This is the logic and life cycle behind fashion trends.

TITLE: Five things to know as the tax deadline looms
SUMMARY: April 15th, the deadline to file your income taxes, is just around the corner. Filings so far this year are on track with last year's, while the average refund is slightly larger.

TITLE: On a remote island, a test of wills between the Philippines and China
SUMMARY: About 250 Filipinos live on Thitu Island, the largest and most inhabited island of the Spratlys, in the South China Sea. But Chinese ships are never far away.

TITLE: Here's what worries scientists about bird flu's spread among cattle
SUMMARY: Avian influenza is still spreading among dairy cattle. Scientists are paying close attention to how the virus is changing and what that means for its pandemic potential.

TITLE: Biden to hold summit with Japan, Philippines; FAFSA delays threaten college enrollment
SUMMARY: President Biden hosts the leaders of Japan and the Philippines. Fewer high school seniors are completing their FAFSA form.

TITLE: Here are 3 solutions to get blood to folks in 'blood deserts.' One is often illegal
SUMMARY: Doctors have coined a term to describe places where blood for transfusions is not readily available: "blood deserts." When blood banks aren't around, they try different strategies to help patients.

TITLE: O.J. Simpson, football legend acquitted of notorious killings, dies at 76
SUMMARY: Orenthal James Simpson "succumbed to his battle with cancer" on Wednesday, according to a family statement on social media.

TITLE: Israelis are returning to Sderot, the biggest city attacked by Hamas
SUMMARY: Almost everyone fled Sderot after Hamas militants killed 50 residents and visitors on Oct. 7. Now most have returned, but soldiers are guarding schools and residents are traumatized and feel insecure.

TITLE: The first foreign-born grand champion of sumo, Akebono Taro, dies at age 54
SUMMARY: Born Chad George Ha'aheo Rowan in Hawaii, Akebono moved to Tokyo in the 1980s, won his first grand championship in 1993, the first of 11 such titles, and retired in 2001. He died of heart failure.

TITLE: Many FBI agents are struggling to make ends meet. Housing costs are to blame
SUMMARY: FBI agents in high-cost areas can face long commutes and trouble paying the bills. Their advocates are asking for a housing allowance to lighten the load.

TITLE: The VA has its fix for a home loan debacle, but many vets who got hurt won't get help
SUMMARY: The VA halted foreclosures after an NPR investigation found thousands of vets were facing foreclosure and it wasn't their fault. Now the VA's unveiling a rescue plan that leaves some out in the cold.

TITLE: Journalist says a 'land grab' in Tanzania is forcing the Maasai off their land
SUMMARY: <em>Atlantic

TITLE: O.J. Simpson's trial divided the nation. What legacy does he leave behind?
SUMMARY:
O.J. Simpson was more than a football star. More than a pop culture icon or a defendant acquitted of murder.

He became a symbol of America's complicated relationship to race, celebrity, and justice. His family announced that he died of cancer Wednesday at age 76.

The murder trial of O.J. Simpson became not only about one man and two victims, but the entire country. Coming up, we assess the legacy of a case, and a verdict, that put race in America on the stand.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: A Remote Island Outpost that is Part of a Geopolitical Fight
SUMMARY: Ownership of the Spratly Islands are in dispute. This has been the case for decades, but tensions have been raised recently as China has tried to expand its claims in the remote area. We get a rare glimpse of one of the islands that has a Filipino community living on it.

TITLE: Vietnam sentences real estate tycoon to death in its largest-ever fraud case
SUMMARY: Truong My Lan, the 67-year-old chairwoman of the real estate company Van Thinh Phat, was formally charged with fraud amounting to $12.5 billion — nearly 3% of the country's 2022 GDP.

TITLE: Another Boeing whistleblower says he faced retaliation for reporting 'shortcuts'
SUMMARY: This week brought more damaging allegations about Boeing as an engineer accused the company of taking production "shortcuts." He joins a growing list of whistleblowers who say they faced retaliation.

TITLE: 4 years ago, Sanders and Biden united Democrats. Biden needs young progressives again
SUMMARY: Four years ago, Bernie Sanders dropped his presidential bid and endorsed Joe Biden, helping Biden expand his coalition, including with young voters. Is another "unity" moment possible in 2024?

TITLE: Would you qualify for the jury on a Trump trial? Find out in the quiz
SUMMARY: Why is a famous elementary particle in the news? Where is Chechnya and what did it ban? Which prince is Andrew again? If you know these things, you'll get at least a 3 out of 11.

TITLE: The U.S. counterintelligence head says the list of threats is long and getting longer
SUMMARY: Mike Casey tells NPR that the scale of spying against the United States is "impressive and terrifying." He says: "More players are getting into it with more tools, going after more targets."

TITLE: After 40 years of smoking, she survived lung cancer thanks to new treatments
SUMMARY: Scientific advances in immunotherapy and new targeted therapies have increased survival rates. But screening among former and current smokers still needs to improve to save more lives.

TITLE: Ford expands a recall of thousands of its Bronco and Escape editions
SUMMARY: Nearly 43,000 vehicles are impacted by the recall, including the 2022 Escape and the 2022 and 2023 Bronco Sport editions that have 1.5L engines.

TITLE: 3 men stranded on a Pacific island were rescued by spelling 'help' with palm leaves
SUMMARY: The men began their trip on Easter Sunday and had been gone for six days when a woman called the U.S. Coast Guard to report them missing.

TITLE: O.J Simpon's complicated legacy; Ukraine passes new draft law
SUMMARY: O.J. Simpson leaves behind a complicated cultural legacy. Ukraine's parliament has adopted a law to mobilize hundreds of thousands of new soldiers.

TITLE: Palestinians forgo Eid celebrations to mourn for Gaza
SUMMARY: The holy month of Ramadan concluded this week with Eid al-Fitr, a celebration with food, family and friends. For Palestinians, the war in Gaza has weighed heavily on this year's holiday.

TITLE: 6 in 10 U.S. Catholics are in favor of abortion rights, Pew Research report finds
SUMMARY: Although the Catholic Church officially opposes abortion, the report says there's far greater diversity of opinion among laity in the U.S.

TITLE: An artificial womb could build a bridge to health for premature babies
SUMMARY: Artificial wombs could someday save babies born very prematurely. Even though the experimental technology is still in animal tests, there are mounting questions about its eventual use with humans.

TITLE: How Iran and Israel became archenemies
SUMMARY: Iran blames Israel for a strike on its Syria consulate, and has vowed to retaliate. Iran's 1979 Islamic revolution transformed previously cordial relations between Iran and Israel to fierce hostility.

TITLE: Ethiopian singer Muluken Melesse dies at 73
SUMMARY: One of the most popular Ethiopian vocalists of the late 20th century, he rose to fame at a time of great political unrest in Ethiopia.

TITLE: Biden says Iran could soon attack Israel, and warns, 'Don't'
SUMMARY: President Biden said an attack by Iran against Israel could happen sooner rather than later. He said the United States will help defend Israel.

TITLE: The Forever Stamp is forever rising in price. How does the U.S. cost compare globally?
SUMMARY: U.S. stamps are heading for their sixth price hike since 2021. In raw numbers, only four countries in a recent study of 31 developed nations had cheaper stamps than the U.S.

TITLE: What Rwanda Looks Like 30 Years After the Genocide
SUMMARY: It has been three decades since the East African country of Rwanda experienced a genocide that changed the country and shocked the world. We look at the state of their society today.

TITLE: CDC warns that measles spike poses a 'renewed threat' to the disease's elimination
SUMMARY: So far this year, the U.S. has seen more than 120 cases of the highly contagious disease — more than double the cases for all of 2023. Still, chances of widespread transmission remains low.

TITLE: Robert MacNeil, creator and first anchor of PBS 'NewsHour,' dies at 93
SUMMARY: MacNeil, who created the even-handed, no-frills PBS newscast "The MacNeil-Lehrer NewsHour" in the 1970s and co-anchored the show for with his late partner, Jim Lehrer, for two decades, died on Friday

TITLE: Google blocks California news in response to bill that would force tech giant to pay
SUMMARY: The company on Friday said it has started blocking California-based news outlets to protest a pending bill that supporters say would extend a lifeline to the ailing news industry.

TITLE: Is Israel perpetuating a cycle of radicalization rather than ending it?
SUMMARY:
For months, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has been insisting that the goal of Israel's bombardment in Gaza is to "destroy Hamas."

But in the path of that destruction, more than 33,000 Palestinian civilians have been killed. Regular people, entire families, and more than 13,000 children.

Yet, it's not clear if Israel is any closer to its stated goal of destroying Hamas. In fact, is it possible that the horrors of this war could ignite a cycle of radicalization in the region?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

TITLE: Republicans aim to stop noncitizen voting in federal elections. It's already illegal
SUMMARY: The reality is noncitizens are already banned from voting in federal elections and numerous studies have found that it almost never happens.

TITLE: 1 person killed and 13 injured in semitrailer crash at a Texas public safety office
SUMMARY: A Texas semitrailer driver rammed a stolen 18-wheeler into a public safety building where his renewal for a commercial driver's license had been rejected, authorities said. The driver was arrested.

TITLE: Man stabs 5 people to death in Sydney shopping center before fatally shot by police
SUMMARY: Multiple people, including a small child, were also injured in the attack.

TITLE: This Pennsylvania county picks presidents. Here's what it can tell us about 2024
SUMMARY: Erie County, Pa., is one of just a handful of places that boomeranged from supporting Obama in 2008 and 2012, to Trump in 2016, to Biden in 2020. It's worth watching in 2024.

TITLE: Wisconsin's 'Mad City' is a rational choice for Biden's appeal to youth
SUMMARY: It is not much of an exaggeration, if it is one at all, that college towns are to the Democrats today what factory towns were through most of the 20<sup>th

TITLE: Man stabs 6 people to death in Sydney shopping center before fatally shot by police
SUMMARY: The suspect stabbed nine people at the shopping center in Sydney's eastern suburbs before a police inspector shot him after he turned and raised a knife, police said.

TITLE: Iranian commandos seize an Israeli-linked container ship near Strait of Hormuz
SUMMARY: Commandos from Iran's paramilitary Revolutionary Guard rappelled down from a helicopter onto a container ship near the Strait of Hormuz and seized the vessel as tensions in the region heightened.

TITLE: U.S. border arrests decline amid increased enforcement in Mexico
SUMMARY: Arrests for crossing the U.S. border illegally fell slightly in March, authorities said, bucking a usual spring increase amid increased immigration enforcement in Mexico.

TITLE: Kansas governor vetoes proposed ban on gender-affirming care for minors
SUMMARY: Democratic Gov. Laura Kelly also vetoed a measure to require more reporting from abortion providers and what she called a "vague" bill making it a crime to coerce someone into having an abortion.

TITLE: Tiger Woods sets Masters record, making 24th consecutive cut
SUMMARY: The 48-year-old golf legend's energetic return to Augusta comes after he withdrew mid-tournament last year due to a foot injury.

TITLE: Trump's next rally arena: a Manhattan courthouse
SUMMARY: The presumptive GOP nominee will stand trial Monday in the first criminal trial of a former president. At this point, Trump is used to trying to leverage his appearances as part of his campaign.

TITLE: Iran has launched a drone attack on Israel
SUMMARY: The launch, a major escalation in the conflict in the Middle East, comes after Iranian leader Ayatollah Ali Khamenei vowed retaliation for an earlier strike on an Iranian consulate in Syria.

TITLE: Filmmaker and Coppola family matriarch Eleanor Coppola dies at 87
SUMMARY: The documentarian was known for chronicling the movie-making process of family members Francis Ford Coppola and Sofia Coppola.

TITLE: Faith Ringgold, quilt and visual artist, dies at 93
SUMMARY: Known best for her story quilts depicting African-American experiences and feminine life, she also created paintings, sculpture and children's books. She was 93.

TITLE: Iran launches a drone attack on Israel, a major escalation of Middle East conflict
SUMMARY: Sirens sounded across Israel overnight as Israeli officials urged residents to take shelter. The attack follows a vow of retaliation from Iran after an earlier strike on an Iranian consulate in Syria.

TITLE: House GOP leaders plan to take up Israel aid after Iran attack
SUMMARY: House Majority Leader Steve Scalise said the chamber will consider legislation to support Israel after Iran launched dozens of drones toward Israel late Saturday night.

TITLE: Israel shoots down missiles and drones after Iran launches unprecedented attack
SUMMARY: Sirens sounded across Israel overnight as Israeli officials urged residents to take shelter. The attack follows a vow of retaliation from Iran after an earlier strike on an Iranian consulate in Syria.

TITLE: Trump attacks judge and prosecutors in his hush money case in last rally before trial
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump on Saturday lit into New York prosecutors and the criminal hush money case they brought against him during his last rally before his trial begins Monday.

TITLE: Police in Australia identify the Sydney stabbing attacker who killed 6 people
SUMMARY: Police have identified the assailant who stabbed six people to death at a busy Sydney shopping center before he was fatally shot by a police officer.

TITLE: Chicago shooting kills 7-year-old girl and wounds 7 people including small children
SUMMARY: Eight people were shot including a young girl who was killed in what Chicago police believe was gang-related violence on the city's South Side on Saturday night.

TITLE: If convicted this year, Trump could lose the right to vote for himself
SUMMARY: In a year of unprecedented political developments, the New York hush money trial could mean one fewer vote for Donald Trump in Florida.

TITLE: These Mormon women are rejecting Trump, fraying GOP support in a key state
SUMMARY: In this swing state, every voting bloc can make a difference. That includes Maricopa County's LDS community, where Republican women have been turning away from former President Donald Trump.

TITLE: How to give kids autonomy? 'Anxious Generation' author says a license to roam helps
SUMMARY: Kids have too much screen time and not enough autonomy, says author Jonathan Haidt. His book <em>The Anxious Generation

TITLE: Scottie Scheffler wins the Masters for the 2nd time
SUMMARY: Scottie Scheffler has won the prestigious golf tournament, taking the green jacket in Augusta, Ga.

TITLE: Iran attacked Israel, escalating an already volatile conflict. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Iran launched an unprecedented barrage of over 300 drones and missiles at Israel over the weekend. Israel and allies shot down nearly all of the weapons. Israel called for sanctions on Iran.

TITLE: Lightning, rains kill 36 people in Pakistan
SUMMARY: Lightning and heavy rains have killed at least 36 people, mostly farmers, across Pakistan in the past three days, as authorities in the country's southwest declared a state of emergency.

TITLE: Trump's criminal trial, a first for a former president, begins Monday
SUMMARY: For the first time in U.S. history, a former president will sit in a courtroom for the first day of his criminal trial. It kicks off with an 18-person jury selection. A decision could come by summer.

TITLE: Growing up, he struggled to read. Then a young teacher saw his potential
SUMMARY: Juleus Ghunta is a published children's author and award-winning poet. But growing up, he could barely read. That was until a teacher saw his potential.

TITLE: To make sure grandmas like his don't get conned, he scams the scammers
SUMMARY: Livestreamers who bait scammers find creative ways to waste their time. This makes for entertaining viewing. But as scams spike, one streamer, Kitboga, wants to protect as many victims as possible.

TITLE: His story inspired 'Hotel Rwanda.' Now he's speaking out against the government
SUMMARY: Paul Rusesabagina, whose life inspired the movie <em>Hotel Rwanda

TITLE: Samsung gets $6.4 billion to build massive semiconductor plants in central Texas
SUMMARY: One of the facilities Samsung is building will be the size of 11 football fields, Commerce Secretary Gina Raimondo said. The new investment will create thousands of jobs, the White House said.

TITLE: Got tinnitus? A device that tickles the tongue helps this musician find relief
SUMMARY: More than 25 million adults in the U.S. have tinnitus, a condition that causes ringing or buzzing in the ears. An FDA approved device that stimulates the tongue, helped 84% of people who tried it.

TITLE: Gay people often have older brothers. Why? And does it matter?
SUMMARY: Studies worldwide show that queer people tend to have more older brothers than other kinds of siblings. Justin Torres, a queer novelist and the youngest of three brothers, asks: Should it matter?

TITLE: We, The Voters — The Left. The Right. The Disillusioned.
SUMMARY: <em>We, The Voters — The Left. The Right. The Disillusioned

TITLE: Philadelphia gun violence victims find support through residents and nonprofits
SUMMARY: As gun violence spiked in Philadelphia after the pandemic, some residents and nonprofits banded together to help victims.

TITLE: What to know about Iran's strike on Israel; Jury selection begins for Trump trial
SUMMARY: Iran strikes Israel in retaliation for an attack that killed top Iranian officers at an Iranian consulate in Syria. Former President Donald Trump's hush money trial is set to begin Monday in New York.

TITLE: Sudan's conflict hits the 1-year mark, sparking fears of repeated atrocities
SUMMARY: Since fighting broke out between the Sudanese Armed Forces and rebel paramilitaries a year ago, experts estimate over 14,000 people have been killed and millions displaced and facing starvation.

TITLE: FBI agents are searching the ship that crashed into Baltimore's Key Bridge
SUMMARY: Federal agents are executing a search warrant in connection with an investigation into the vessel that flattened a Baltimore bridge last month.

TITLE: 5 takeaways from Salman Rushdie's new memoir 'Knife'
SUMMARY: Nearly two years after the renowned author was stabbed on stage in Chautauqua, N.Y., Rushdie's new memoir unpacks everything he's been feeling since the attack.

TITLE: Trump's criminal trial, a first for a former president, has begun in New York
SUMMARY: For the first time in U.S. history, a former president will sit in a courtroom for the first day of his criminal trial. It kicks off with an 18-person jury selection. A decision could come by summer.

TITLE: Florida voters will decide on abortion rights this fall. Here's what some are saying
SUMMARY: The campaign to amend Florida's constitution to protect abortion rights kicked off in Orlando, attracting voters on both sides of the issue. The ballot question needs 60% approval to pass.

TITLE: Why Nike's new Olympic track uniform for women is stirring controversy
SUMMARY: One of the options for women runners is a bodysuit that is noticeably cut high on the hips. Critics say the outfit looks uncomfortable, revealing — and problematic.

TITLE: Alabama holds its first ever U.S. Olympic trial for a little-known sport
SUMMARY: The U.S. Olympic Team trials for slalom kayak and canoe were held at Montgomery Whitewater, a new artificial watersports complex. The city hopes to draw more tourism, while the sport seeks new fans.

TITLE: Never seen an exploding star? This year, you'll have your chance
SUMMARY: A nova of the T Coronae Borealis star system is expected to happen at some point through September, and will make it as bright as the North Star for several days.

TITLE: When rogue brokers switch a person's ACA health insurance, tax surprises can follow
SUMMARY: Some tax filers' returns are being rejected because they failed to provide information about Affordable Care Act coverage they didn't even know they had.

TITLE: 'Rust' armorer Hannah Gutierrez-Reed sentenced to 18 months in prison
SUMMARY: Gutierrez-Reed has been in custody since she was found guilty of involuntary manslaughter in March by a New Mexico jury. Her attorney asked for probation and will appeal the case.

TITLE: Iran's leaders insist the attack against Israel was a 'victory'
SUMMARY: Iranian officials have heaped praise on the attack, with a top lawmaker saying that "it humiliated the Israeli regime." But Israel says 99% of Iran's missiles and drones were intercepted.

TITLE: Drugmakers' low U.S. taxes belie their high sales
SUMMARY: Most of the largest pharmaceutical companies report losing money in the United States, despite the majority of their sales coming from Americans. The result is lower U.S. taxes for the companies.

TITLE: Photos: A year of war in Sudan
SUMMARY: A year of war has torn through Sudan, causing devastation and more than 8 million people to be displaced.

TITLE: Now That Iran Has Attacked Israel, What Happens Next?
SUMMARY: Following the attack of more than 300 weaponized drones and missiles launched by Iran at Israel, the Israeli prime minster is getting pressure from the U.S. for Israel to be measured in its response, while some domestic politicians are demanding a strong reaction. Our correspondent in Tel Aviv gives us the latest. And Jordan was part of the success in shooting down the majority of projectiles bound for Israel. We hear what the reaction has been in that country where 60 percent of the population is of Palestinian origin.

TITLE: Truth Social shares tumble again. It's making for an incredibly volatile ride
SUMMARY: Trump Media & Technology Group fell sharply after saying it was issuing new shares. Trump's stake is still worth billions of dollars, however.

TITLE: Supreme Court temporarily revives Idaho law banning gender affirming care for minors
SUMMARY: The law makes it a felony for doctors to medically treat gender dysphoria in minors. It will now go into effect except in the case of two anonymous plaintiffs who may continue to receive treatment.

TITLE: Iran's attack on Israel is a major escalation. What comes next for the region?
SUMMARY:
Iran launched a barrage of more than 300 drones and missiles at Israel over the weekend, saying it was in response to an airstrike earlier this month that hit Iran's consulate in Syria and killed seven Iranian military officials, including two generals.

Israel neither confirmed nor denied responsibility for the Syria strike, though the Pentagon said Israel was responsible.

Sima Shine is a former senior Israeli intelligence official. She now runs the Iran desk at the Institute for National Security Studies in Tel Aviv. She says this attack is "crossing the Rubicon" from the point of view of Iran, and explains what Israel's retaliation could be.

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Boeing challenges whistleblower allegations, details how airframes are put together
SUMMARY: Two Boeing engineering executives went into detail Monday to describe how panels are fitted together, particularly on the 787 Dreamliner.

TITLE: The House plans to hold separate votes on aid for Israel and Ukraine after delays
SUMMARY: Aid for Israel became more urgent after the weekend's attack, House Speaker Mike Johnson said. After months of delays, he is also putting forward a bill that provide additional aid to Ukraine.

TITLE: Caitlin Clark and Angel Reese are selected in the first round of the WNBA draft
SUMMARY: Caitlin Clark became the all-time leading scorer in college basketball history during her time as a student, while Angel Reese led the SEC division in points and rebounds for two seasons.

TITLE: A knife attack in Australia is being treated as terrorism
SUMMARY: Australian police say a knife attack in Sydney that wounded a bishop and a priest during a church service as worshippers watched online and in person, and sparked a riot was an act of terrorism.

TITLE: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators shut down airport highways and bridges in major cities
SUMMARY: Pro-Palestinian demonstrators blocked roadways in Illinois, California, New York and the Pacific Northwest on Monday, temporarily shutting down travel into some of the nation's airports.

TITLE: USC says it is canceling its valedictorian speech because of safety concerns
SUMMARY: Asna Tabassum received some backlash about her social media content on the conflict between Israel and Palestine. Tabassum said she questions the university's reasoning for canceling the speech.

TITLE: Suicides make up majority of gun deaths, but remain overlooked in gun violence debate
SUMMARY: Suicide is the leading cause of gun-related deaths in the United States. But it's often only an afterthought in the public debate about gun violence.

TITLE: NPR suspends veteran editor as it grapples with his public criticism
SUMMARY: NPR has suspended Senior Editor Uri Berliner after he wrote an essay accusing the public radio network of becoming too progressive in its news coverage and losing the public's trust.

TITLE: A new generation is uncovering the tiny doodles left by engineers on old microchips
SUMMARY: Engineers left these drawings as a way to sign their work. Many are puns that made them chuckle to themselves. Now social media has rediscovered them and hobbyists try to keep that history alive.

TITLE: Why homeless people are losing health coverage in Medicaid mix-ups
SUMMARY: Nearly 130,000 Montanans lost Medicaid coverage during recent eligibility reviews. People who are homeless are more likely to have chronic health issues and particularly vulnerable to losing coverage.

TITLE: Senate trial on Mayorkas set to start, but Democrats are likely to dispose of charges
SUMMARY: On Tuesday House impeachment managers will deliver the impeachment articles against Homeland Security Secretary Alejandro Mayorkas to the Senate.

TITLE: ABBA, The Notorious B.I.G. and Green Day named to the National Recording Registry
SUMMARY: Every year, the Library of Congress names 25 "audio treasures" to be preserved permanently. This year's selections range from ABBA and Green Day to World War I-era jazz pioneer James Reese Europe.

TITLE: As Iran attacked Israel, old and faked videos and images got millions of views on X
SUMMARY: Images and videos from previous conflicts, video games and AI generators were often spread by accounts that pay to be boosted on the social media site once known as Twitter.

TITLE: Bitcoin is about to hit an event called the halving — and it may spark a huge rally
SUMMARY: Crypto investors are getting excited about an upcoming quadrennial event called the halving that will effectively reduce the supply of new bitcoin in half. Here's what it all means.

TITLE: ISIS destroyed his instruments. He made a new one from scraps and composed an album
SUMMARY: Musician and composer Ameen Mokdad opens up about his album <em>The Curve

TITLE: Supreme Court hears challenge to law used to prosecute hundreds of Jan. 6 defendants
SUMMARY: The case tests the statute used to prosecute hundreds of defendants charged with invading the Capitol to stop the counting of electoral ballots for president in 2020.

TITLE: Rise and grind? Working late, volatile hours may lead to depression, illness by 50
SUMMARY: Burnt out much? A study links working late, or variable shifts with health problems later in life. Maybe it's time to quit hustle culture for good.

TITLE: Biden has to decide soon whether to sanction Venezuela. Here's what to know
SUMMARY: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro's government faces a deadline this week — to commit to holding free and fair elections or face renewed U.S. oil sanctions.

TITLE: Report: China continues to subsidize deadly fentanyl exports
SUMMARY: Fentanyl made from Chinese chemicals is killing tens of thousands of Americans. A House committee report found new evidence the Chinese government supports tax breaks to subsidize the drug trade.

TITLE: Iran hails attack on Israel as a 'victory'; Photos of Sudan, 1 year into a brutal war
SUMMARY: Iran says its attack against Israel was a success, despite the fact that 99% of the drones were intercepted. A Sudanese photographer documents how war has upended life in his country.

TITLE: Finally! Tough new safety rules on silica dust are out to protect miners' lungs
SUMMARY: Addressing a problem first identified 50 years ago, federal regulators say stricter new rules to limit miners' exposure to silica dust are expected to finally go on the books on Tuesday.

TITLE: Fire ravages 17th-century Old Stock Exchange in Copenhagen, toppling the iconic spire
SUMMARY: Passersby rushed to help emergency services save priceless paintings and other valuables as a fire raged through one of Copenhagen's oldest buildings on Tuesday.

TITLE: A video shows two men toppling rock formations at Lake Mead trail
SUMMARY: The National Park Service is seeking the public's help in identifying the two men, caught on video pushing rocks off a cliff near the Redstone Dunes Trail earlier this month.

TITLE: A former Marine gets 9 years for firebombing a California Planned Parenthood clinic
SUMMARY: The 24-year-old had pleaded guilty to four felony counts related to the firebombing of a Southern California Planned Parenthood clinic in 2022. The clinic was closed and no one was injured.

TITLE: Johnson's leadership is under threat in the House over foreign aid bills
SUMMARY: Kentucky Republican Thomas Massie said he would vote to oust Mike Johnson as House Speaker if it came to the floor. He told Johnson in a closed-door meeting that he should resign.

TITLE: It's a wild ride to get to the bottom of what everyone's hiding in 'A Better World'
SUMMARY: A very sinister thriller with a dash of science-fiction and full of inscrutabilities, Sarah Langan's novel is as entreating and creepy as it is timely and humane.

TITLE: Report: Last year ended with a surge in book bans
SUMMARY: According to PEN America, 4,349 books were banned from schools between July and December 2023, more than the entire previous school year. More than 3,000 of those bans were in Florida.

TITLE: The U.S. has come up with its own global strategy to thwart the next pandemic
SUMMARY: The Biden administration has launched a new effort to improve the ability of the U.S. to prevent, detect and respond to global health threats. Some experts say the new strategy doesn't go far enough.

TITLE: The Devastating Conflict the World is Ignoring
SUMMARY: More than 8 million people have been displaced in Sudan, according to the United Nations. A powerful paramilitary group has been fighting the Sudanese army for over a year. We hear from a Sudanese poet, who is trying to draw attention to the overlooked conflict in her country.

TITLE: Supreme Court gives skeptical eye to key statute used to prosecute Jan. 6 rioters
SUMMARY: Conservatives on the court expressed varying degrees of skepticism about the charge of obstructing an official proceeding.

TITLE: Finally! New federal safety rules on silica dust aim to protect miners' lungs
SUMMARY: Addressing a problem first identified 50 years ago, federal regulators say stricter new rules to limit miners' exposure to silica dust are expected to finally go on the books on Tuesday.

TITLE: New federal safety rules on silica dust aim to protect miners' lungs
SUMMARY: Addressing a problem first identified 50 years ago, federal regulators say stricter new rules to limit miners' exposure to silica dust are expected to finally go on the books on Tuesday.

TITLE: Voting technology company settles lawsuit against OAN over 2020 election claims
SUMMARY: The settlement between Smartmatic and One America News Network is the latest development in a larger legal pushback by voting equipment companies targeted by fraud claims related to the 2020 election.

TITLE: Bob Graham, former U.S. senator and Florida governor, has died at 87
SUMMARY: Graham gained national prominence as chairman of the Senate Intelligence Committee in the aftermath of the 2001 terrorist attacks and as an early critic of the Iraq war.

TITLE: The Rise and Fall of the Panama Canal
SUMMARY: The Panama Canal has been dubbed the greatest engineering feat in human history. It's also (perhaps less favorably) been called the greatest liberty mankind has ever taken with Mother Nature. But due to climate change, the Canal is drying up and fewer than half of the ships that used to pass through are now able to do so. So how did we get here? Today on the show, we're talking to Cristina Henriquez, the author of a new novel that explores the making of the Canal. It took 50,000 people from 90 different countries to carve the land in two — and the consequences of that extraordinary, nature-defying act are still echoing through our present.

TITLE: Storm dumps heaviest rain ever recorded in the United Arab Emirates
SUMMARY: By the end of Tuesday, more than 5.59 inches of rain had soaked Dubai over 24 hours. An average year sees 3.73 inches at Dubai International Airport, which partially flooded and halted arrivals.

TITLE: Venezuela orders the closure of its embassy in Ecuador
SUMMARY: Venezuela's president ordered the closure of his country's embassy in Ecuador in solidarity with Mexico in its protest over a raid by Ecuadorian authorities on the Mexican embassy in Quito.

TITLE: Some independent candidates start their own political parties to ease ballot access
SUMMARY: Some states make it much easier to get on the ballot as a minor-party presidential candidate, compared with running as an independent. That's why RFK Jr. and Cornel West have made their own parties.

TITLE: Why London's Muslim mayor needs the same security as the king
SUMMARY: London Mayor Sadiq Khan talks to NPR about being a Muslim politician in Britain — and his fears around a second possible Donald Trump presidency.

TITLE: As gun violence looms over Pennsylvania youth, local organizations offer safe spaces
SUMMARY: Children and teens deal with the threat of gun violence on a daily basis in southeastern Pennsylvania. So community members and organizations are banding together to try to solve the dire problem.

TITLE: Medicare's push to improve chronic care attracts businesses, but not many doctors
SUMMARY: Most Medicare enrollees have two or more chronic conditions, making them eligible for a program that rewards physicians for doing more to manage their care. But not many doctors have joined.

TITLE: Columbia University president is set to testify about antisemitism on campus
SUMMARY: The testimony from Columbia's president comes several months after lawmakers grilled the presidents of Harvard, MIT and the University of Pennsylvania.

TITLE: With 100 days before the Paris Olympics, Team USA hopefuls meet the press
SUMMARY: U.S. Olympic and Paralympic Committee officials and Team USA contenders met in New York City this week to discuss how they're preparing ahead of the Summer Games in Paris.

TITLE: Coral reefs can't keep up with climate change. So scientists are speeding up evolution
SUMMARY: Climate change is heating oceans faster than the world's coral reefs can handle. So scientists are breeding corals that can withstand hotter temperatures – but only to a point.

TITLE: After catch and release, here's how to make sure reef fish survive
SUMMARY: People who fish in Florida and in federal waters are required to have special gear on board to help ensure groupers, snappers and other reef fish survive when they're returned to the water.

TITLE: Biden wants to hike tariffs on imports of Chinese steel and aluminum
SUMMARY: The White House says China uses subsidies and government programs to undercut U.S. steel. President Biden wants to triple tariffs on the imports and take other new steps to curb imports.

TITLE: Why this vote at a Tennessee Volkswagen plant is historic for the South
SUMMARY: Volkswagen workers in Chattanooga, Tenn., are voting this week on whether to join the United Auto Workers union. Two previous attempts to unionize the plant failed. Ballots will be counted on Friday.

TITLE: Senate mulls next steps in Mayorkas impeachment; ocean heat is mass bleaching coral
SUMMARY: The Senate kicks off the impeachment trial of the Homeland Security secretary. Coral reefs are undergoing a mass bleaching event that could soon be the worst on record.

TITLE: How do you keep calm and carry on in a world full of crises?
SUMMARY: We asked folks whose job it is to make the world a better place: How do you find the inner strength to keep plugging away in tough times? And what advice do you have for fledgling activists?

TITLE: Watch: Salman Rushdie on the moment he was attacked on stage, and why he felt lonely
SUMMARY: Salman Rushdie is a storyteller. So when you ask him to describe the day, in 2022, when he was attacked and nearly killed by a young man with a knife, Rushdie paints a vivid picture.

TITLE: Persistent shortage of growth hormone frustrates parents and clinicians
SUMMARY: As a shortage of growth hormone used to treat rare diseases in children drags on, families and doctors are struggling with insurers' requirements to get prescriptions filled.

TITLE: Death doula says life is more meaningful if you 'get real' about the end
SUMMARY: Alua Arthur helps people plan for death. A big part of her work is helping them reconcile the lives they lived with the lives they might have wanted. Her memoir is called<em> Briefly Perfectly Human.

TITLE: Ford recalls 456,000 Broncos, Mavericks that may lose power, raising crash risks
SUMMARY: The automaker is recalling Bronco Sport and Maverick vehicles due to a battery detection issue that can result in loss of drive power, increasing crash risks.

TITLE: Senators to be sworn in as jurors in Mayorkas impeachment trial
SUMMARY: The Senate is still negotiating what the scope of the homeland security secretary's trial will be and whether to allow debate in the Democratic-controlled chamber.

TITLE: Speaker Johnson is moving forward with foreign aid bills despite threat to oust him
SUMMARY: Divisions within the House Republican conference could threaten both the future of the package and Mike Johnson's speakership.

TITLE: NBA bans Jontay Porter after gambling probe shows he shared information, bet on games
SUMMARY: The Toronto Raptors player has been banned for life from the NBA after a probe found he disclosed confidential information to sports bettors and bet on games, even betting on the Raptors to lose.

TITLE: NPR editor Uri Berliner resigns with blast at new CEO
SUMMARY: The senior editor says CEO Katherine Maher has "divisive views" that confirm the issues he wrote about in an essay accusing NPR of losing the public's trust.

TITLE: The Debate in Israel Over Who Should Be Required Serve in the Military
SUMMARY: Ultra-Orthodox Israelis have long been exempt from compulsory military service. But the October 7th attack by Hamas and Israel's subsequent military response have brought forward calls for change. The government's decision on whether to end the exemption has major political consequences.

TITLE: A new Lennon-McCartney collab has dropped — but this time, it's by the Beatles' sons
SUMMARY: A new single, "Primrose Hill," was co-written by Sean Ono Lennon and James McCartney, the youngest sons of Beatles musicians John Lennon and Paul McCartney.

TITLE: Watch: A circus elephant runs loose in a Montana town before being recaptured
SUMMARY: Sheriff Ed Lester said the animal was apparently "spooked by a vehicle" and briefly escaped before being recaptured by handlers. Videos of the unexpected sight were shared widely on social media.

TITLE: The Supreme Court opens the door to more discrimination claims involving job transfers
SUMMARY: The U.S. Supreme Court has made it easier for workers to bring employment discrimination suits over job transfers. The decision was unanimous, but the reasoning was not.

TITLE: Senate kills articles of impeachment against Homeland Security Secretary Mayorkas
SUMMARY: The Senate rejected the two articles that accuse Mayorkas of refusing to enforce immigration laws. The House voted to impeach him in February.

TITLE: A new report on the Maui wildfires cites communications breakdowns
SUMMARY: As wildfires ripped across Maui last August, a broad communications breakdown left authorities in the dark and residents without emergency alerts, according to a report released Wednesday.

TITLE: Lawyers for Nassar assault survivors have reached $100M deal with Justice Department
SUMMARY: The U.S. Justice Department has agreed to pay approximately $100 million to settle claims with about 100 people who say they were sexually assaulted by sports doctor Larry Nassar.

TITLE: Poland's president visits Donald Trump as allies eye a possible return
SUMMARY: Former President Donald Trump met Wednesday with Polish President Andrzej Duda, the latest in a series of meetings with foreign leaders as they brace for the possibility of a second Trump term.

TITLE: Indonesians leave homes near erupting volcano and airport closes due to ash danger
SUMMARY: Indonesian authorities closed an airport and residents left homes near an erupting volcano Thursday due to the dangers of spreading ash, falling rocks, and the possibility of a tsunami.

TITLE: Amid concerns about kids and guns, some say training is the answer
SUMMARY: The number of U.S. children dying from gunshot wounds has climbed in recent years. Keeping guns out of reach is one way to curb the trend — others argue to teach kids to handle guns responsibly.

TITLE: Guns are killing more U.S. children. Shooting survivors can face lifelong challenges
SUMMARY: Guns are now the leading cause of death among American children. And many more children are injured in shootings, putting them at risk for life-altering disability, pain, and mental trauma.

TITLE: A portrait of Haitians trying to survive without a government
SUMMARY: Haiti is on the verge of collapse, with little to no government. But many Haitians have already learned to live without the support of the state, as NPR discovered traveling to Cap-Haïtien.

TITLE: College is hard enough — try doing it while raising kids
SUMMARY: More than 5 million college students are also parents. But many colleges do little to support them. Most don't even offer child care.

TITLE: Many baby boomers own homes that are too big. Can they be enticed to sell them?
SUMMARY: Lots of older Americans say they'd love to downsize, but it doesn't make financial sense. The housing roadblock has left some would-be buyers stuck. We asked experts what policies could change that.

TITLE: States botched more executions of Black prisoners. Experts think they know why
SUMMARY: A study showed states made more mistakes when executing Black prisoners by lethal injection than they did with prisoners of other races. Execution workers and race experts said they're not surprised.

TITLE: COMIC: Our sun was born with thousands of other stars. Where did they all go?
SUMMARY: Our sun was born in a cosmic cradle with thousands of other stars. Astrophysicists say they want to find these siblings in order to help answer the question: Are we alone out there?

TITLE: Ralph Nader, Consumer Crusader
SUMMARY: Whether it's pesticides in your cereal or the door plug flying off your airplane, consumers today have plenty of reasons to feel like corporations might not have their best interests at heart. At a moment where we're seeing unprecedented product recalls, and when trust in the government is near historic lows, we're going to revisit a time when a generation of people felt empowered to demand accountability from both companies and elected leaders — and got results. Today on the show, the story of the U.S. consumer movement and its controversial leader: the once famous, now infamous Ralph Nader.

TITLE: Housing costs keep inflation stubborn; New report on Maui wildfires released
SUMMARY: Inflation is proving stubborn this year, and the cost of rent may be to blame. Hawaii's attorney general has released the first report into last year's Maui fires.

TITLE: What are 'orphan crops'? And why is there a new campaign to get them adopted?
SUMMARY: The grass pea is one: a hardy crop that can thrive in a drought. An agriculturist is spearheading an effort to diversity what farmers grow as climate change threatens staples like corn and wheat.

TITLE: Photos: UAE sees its heaviest rains in 75 years
SUMMARY: Schools and businesses were closed across the United Arab Emirates after about a year's worth of rain fell in a single day. Flooding has also disrupted travel at Dubai International Airport.

TITLE: 'Sesame Street' writers authorize a strike if they don't reach a contract by Friday
SUMMARY: Writers for the children's program want better residuals and annual raises, and for auxiliary works, such as social media segments, to be covered by union benefits. Their contract expires Friday.

TITLE: Lethal heat in West Africa is driven by human-caused climate change
SUMMARY: The recent deadly heat in West Africa is driven by human activities, including the burning of fossil fuels, particularly in the wealthy Northern Hemisphere, according to an international report.

TITLE: The Kennedys are endorsing Biden, not their family member RFK Jr.
SUMMARY: The Kennedys have been critical of Robert F. Kennedy's third-party run, which has the potential to draw votes away from President Biden — who the family is formally endorsing on Thursday.

TITLE: Maine lawmakers pass sweeping gun legislation following the Lewiston mass shooting
SUMMARY: The Maine Legislature approved gun safety legislation including background checks on private gun sales, waiting periods for gun purchases and criminalizing gun sales to prohibited people.

TITLE: Florida kicked their son off Medicaid in the 'unwinding' but not their daughter
SUMMARY: Nearly 1-in-4 adults who lost Medicaid coverage in the past year are now uninsured, according to a new survey. As states winnow the rolls, many families are caught in confusing red tape.

TITLE: China's cities are sinking, putting tens of millions at risk
SUMMARY: Nearly a third of China's urban population lives in areas that are subsiding, according to a sweeping national survey of 82 major Chinese cities. In coastal areas, that makes sea level rise worse.

TITLE: The Kennedys endorse Biden, not their family member RFK Jr.
SUMMARY: The Kennedys have been critical of Robert F. Kennedy's third-party run, which has the potential to draw votes away from President Biden — who the family endorsed Thursday.

TITLE: Trader Joe's recalls basil linked to 12 salmonella infections in 7 states
SUMMARY: The Food and Drug Administration warns Trader Joe's customers in dozens of states to throw out fresh basil after a federal investigation linked the product to a salmonella outbreak.

TITLE: What to know about the U.N. vote on whether to admit Palestinians as full members
SUMMARY: The U.N. Security Council met Thursday to debate and vote on the Palestinian application for full membership in the United Nations, which would allow it to vote during U.N. proceedings.

TITLE: Is a Popular Music Genre in India Spreading Hate?
SUMMARY: H-Pop is the Indian popular music and poetry of Hindu nationalism. But critics worry that the music is spreading hate and encourages violence against Muslims.

TITLE: Dickey Betts, founding member of the Allman Brothers Band, dies at 80
SUMMARY: The influential guitarist, songwriter and singer was best known for the song "Ramblin' Man." Betts's blues, rock and country-influenced guitar style helped define Southern rock in the 1960s and '70s.

TITLE: Gaza cease-fire resolutions roil U.S. local communities
SUMMARY: As local elected officials continue to face pressure to pass resolutions calling for an end to the fighting in Gaza, some aren't sure how or whether to take a stand at all.

TITLE: NYPD breaks up pro-Palestinian protest at Columbia University
SUMMARY: Police began making dozens of arrests after Columbia University's president asked for help clearing protesters — citing the "encampment and related disruptions pose a clear and present danger."

TITLE: Trump Media shares surge after a miserable run. Pros say stay away
SUMMARY: Trump Media shares surged over the most recent two trading days — but the company continues to weather a miserable run since its stock market debut last month.

TITLE: House foreign aid bills advance with Democrats' help; Johnson may still be in peril
SUMMARY: With Democratic support, the legislation overcomes a major procedural hurdle and is expected to head to a weekend vote by the full House.

TITLE: Israel launches missile strikes into Iran in response to Tehran's attack Sunday
SUMMARY: There are also reports of explosions in Iraq and Syria. The extent of Israel's strikes weren't yet clear.

TITLE: Who created the idea of litter – and why? Play this month's Throughline history quiz.
SUMMARY: Where did the idea come from that individuals, rather than corporations, should keep the world litter-free? What history is hidden in the trash? Find out here.

TITLE: The backlash against protests; plus, how OJ Simpson changed media forever
SUMMARY: Earlier this week, pro-Palestinian protestors blocked traffic on highways and bridges in San Francisco, Chicago, New York and Seattle. On that same day, the Supreme Court made it incredibly difficult to protest in a lot of the American South. In this episode, host Brittany Luse looks at the state of protest in America. She sits down with Sandhya Dirks, an NPR reporter who covers race and identity, and Elizabeth Blair, a senior arts reporter at NPR. Together, they discuss shifting attitudes towards protest as well as new anti-protest legislation. Then, they play a game of But Did You Know?

TITLE: Israel launches missile strikes into Iran, U.S. military official says
SUMMARY: Iranian news has not reported any such strike and concluded the sounds reported were the interception of one or more drones. Israel's military has not responded to NPR's request for comment.

TITLE: Alvin Bragg, Manhattan's district attorney, draws friends close and critics closer
SUMMARY: Alvin Bragg, Manhattan's District Attorney, has great friends and determined critics

TITLE: What's going to explode in space? Find out in the quiz
SUMMARY: In other news, the WNBA draft was haute, a star system is hot and a Nike uniform was deemed neither haute nor hot.

TITLE: Where gun violence is common, some students say physical safety is a top concern
SUMMARY: The federal government is investing billions to bolster school safety and mental health resources to combat gun violence. But some sense a disconnect between those programs and what students need.

TITLE: Fake Botox has sickened patients nationwide. Here's what to know — and what to avoid
SUMMARY: Public health authorities are investigating reports of counterfeit injections sickening 19 people across nine states. Experts say getting bona fide Botox starts with finding a trustworthy provider.

TITLE: Here's what's in the House foreign aid bills
SUMMARY: The House bills largely mirror a foreign aid package that passed the Senate in February, with aid to Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan. The House has an additional bill targeting Iran, China and Russia.

TITLE: The Rise of 'Grid Zero': Why more Instagram users are hiding their profile
SUMMARY: Many users are concealing their public photos and sharing instead in private spaces. It's something of a protest against the over-sharing culture of social media. And Gen Z is driving the trend.

TITLE: Taylor Swift's 'Tortured Poets' is written in blood
SUMMARY: With <em>The Tortured Poets Department

TITLE: Google worker says the company is 'silencing our voices' after mass firings
SUMMARY: The tech giant fired 28 employees who took part in a protest over the company's Project Nimbus contract with the Israeli government. One fired worker tells her story.

TITLE: Israel strikes Iran, U.S. official says; Taylor Swift's 'Tortured Poets' is here
SUMMARY: Israel has launched a strike against Iran, a U.S. official tells NPR. Taylor Swift's highly anticipated "Tortured Poets Department" is here.

TITLE: Google worker says the company is 'silencing our voices' after dozens are fired
SUMMARY: The tech giant fired 28 employees who took part in a protest over the company's Project Nimbus contract with the Israeli government. One fired worker tells her story.

TITLE: Amsterdam was flooded with tourists in 2023, so it won't allow any more hotels
SUMMARY: Twenty-six hotels that already have permits can move forward, but after that a hotel can only be built if one shuts down. Tourists spent about 20.7 million nights in Amsterdam hotels last year.

TITLE: What we know so far about Israel's strike on Iran — and what could happen next
SUMMARY: Israel and Iran seem to be downplaying the attack, the latest in a series of retaliatory strikes between the two. Analysts say that could be a sign of the de-escalation world leaders are calling for.

TITLE: 'We created this problem:' a pediatric surgeon on how gun violence affects children
SUMMARY: Mikael Petrosyan of Children's National Hospital says gun violence against children is preventable.

TITLE: Remembering Robert MacNeil, longtime host of PBS 'NewsHour'
SUMMARY: During his decades-long career, MacNeil reported on the Kennedy assassination, the Cuban missile crisis and the fall of the Berlin Wall. He died April 12.<em> Originally broadcast in 1986 and 1995.

TITLE: Tesla recalls Cybertruck over sticky problem. Blame it on — yes — soap
SUMMARY: Accelerator pedals on the new Cybertrucks can get stuck, a potentially dangerous production flaw.  The reason why they're so sticky is soap.

TITLE: Israel Strikes Back at Iran, Will This Calm or Inflame Tensions?
SUMMARY:
Israel and Iran have been trading attacks on each other for a week including, for the first time, attacks on each other's territory. Will Israel's latest retaliation be the end of this wave of hostilities, or will Iranian response bring the long-standing enemies closer to all-out war? We hear from NPR's national security correspondent and our correspondent in Israel.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: What World War II taught us about how to help starving people today
SUMMARY: The modern study of the starvation was sparked by the liberation of concentration camp survivors. U.S. and British soldiers rushed to feed them — and yet they sometimes perished.

TITLE: Biden administration adds Title IX protections for LGBTQ students, assault victims
SUMMARY: The new rules also broaden the interpretation of Title IX to cover pregnant, gay and transgender students. They do not address whether schools can ban trans athletes from women's and girls' teams.

TITLE: Mandisa, Grammy-winning singer and 'American Idol' alum, has died at 47
SUMMARY: The singer gained stardom after finishing ninth on "American Idol" in 2006. In 2014, she won a Grammy for best contemporary Christian music album for "Overcomer," her fifth album.

TITLE: Voting ends in historic Tennessee Volkswagen union election
SUMMARY: Volkswagen workers in Chattanooga, Tenn., voted over three days this week on whether to join the United Auto Workers union. The vote tally is expected to take several hours.

TITLE: Ballot count is underway in Tennessee Volkswagen union election
SUMMARY: Volkswagen workers in Chattanooga, Tenn., voted over three days this week on whether to join the United Auto Workers union. The vote tally is expected to take several hours.

TITLE: Volkswagen workers vote yes to unionizing, igniting UAW's push to organize the South
SUMMARY: Volkswagen workers in Chattanooga, Tenn., voted overwhelmingly to unionize with the UAW, setting a new trajectory for labor unions in the American South.

TITLE: USC cancels filmmaker's keynote amid controversy over canceled valedictorian speech
SUMMARY: USC announced the cancellation of a keynote speech by filmmaker Jon M. Chu just days after making the choice to keep the student valedictorian, who expressed support for Palestinians, from speaking.

TITLE: Senate passes reauthorization of key surveillance program despite privacy concerns
SUMMARY: The legislation would extend for two years the program known as Section 702 of the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Act, or FISA. It now goes to President Biden's desk to become law.

TITLE: Man who set himself on fire outside Trump trial dies of injuries, police say
SUMMARY: The man took out pamphlets espousing conspiracy theories, tossed them around, then doused himself in an accelerant and set himself on fire outside the courthouse Friday, officials and witnesses said.

TITLE: What to know about week 1 of Trump's criminal trial, with jury selection complete
SUMMARY: New York Judge Juan Merchan told jurors this week to prepare to hear opening statements on Monday.

TITLE: Ukraine's prime minister says, if passed, $60B U.S. aid package will be critical
SUMMARY: Ukrainian Prime Minister Denys Shmyhal discusses on NPR's <em>All Things Considered

TITLE: Biden administration restricts oil and gas leasing in Alaska's petroleum reserve
SUMMARY: The administration said it will restrict new oil and gas leasing on 13 million acres in Alaska to help protect wildlife such as caribou and polar bears as the Arctic continues to warm.

TITLE: Women of color still lag behind in STEM jobs, despite efforts to change
SUMMARY: STEM careers are still lagging when it comes to hiring women of color.

TITLE: The San Francisco Zoo will receive a pair of pandas from China
SUMMARY: San Francisco is the latest U.S. city preparing to receive a pair of pandas from China, in a continuation of Beijing's famed "panda diplomacy."

TITLE: House approves sell-or-be-banned TikTok measure, attaching it to foreign aid bill
SUMMARY: The bill represents the most serious threat yet to the video app used by half of Americans.

TITLE: House passes foreign aid bills to Israel, Ukraine and Taiwan
SUMMARY: The package now heads to the Senate, where it is also expected to pass.

TITLE: Military court convicts U.S. sailor of attempted espionage
SUMMARY: A naval chief petty officer who served on a Japan-based destroyer was found guilty of sharing classified information with a foreign government, the Navy's investigative agency said.

TITLE: A video shows people trying to pull 2 black bear cubs from trees in North Carolina
SUMMARY: A video shows apartment complex residents in North Carolina trying to pull two wild black bear cubs from a tree to pose with them. One person manages to grab a cub before it runs away.

TITLE: 2 Japanese navy helicopters crash in the Pacific Ocean — 1 dead and 7 missing
SUMMARY: Two Japanese navy helicopters carrying eight crew members crashed in the Pacific Ocean during a nighttime training flight after possibly colliding with each other.

TITLE: Siblings, 8 and 5, killed as suspected drunk driver crashes into children's birthday
SUMMARY: A young brother and sister died and several people were injured, some seriously, when a vehicle driven by a suspected drunken driver crashed into a young child's birthday party at a boat club.

TITLE: At least 2 killed, many injured in shooting at Memphis block party, police say
SUMMARY: Eight people were shot including two men who were killed at an unsanctioned public party in a Memphis city park Saturday night, police said.

TITLE: Israeli strikes on southern Gaza city of Rafah kill 13, including nine children
SUMMARY: Israeli strikes on the southern Gaza city of Rafah killed 13 people, including nine children. Meanwhile, the United States approved $26bn in aid for Israel, including around $9bn for Gaza.

TITLE: Trump cancels rally due to weather, as he tries to balance his trial and campaign
SUMMARY: Donald Trump had to cancel his first planned rally since the start of his criminal hush money trial because of a storm Saturday evening in North Carolina.

TITLE: 15 people injured in tram crash at Universal Studios Hollywood
SUMMARY: A tram accident at Universal Studios Hollywood in Los Angeles injured 15 people Saturday night, authorities and the company said.

TITLE: Gaza hostages raise painful reminders as Jews prepare for Passover
SUMMARY: Among the themes of Passover is freedom from captivity. For many Jews this year, the holiday brings up the pain of knowledge that hostages are still captive after the Oct. 7 Hamas attack on Israel.

TITLE: Israeli strikes on southern Gaza city of Rafah kill 18, including 14 children
SUMMARY: Israeli strikes on the southern Gaza city of Rafah killed 18 people, including 14 children. Meanwhile, the United States approved $26bn in aid for Israel, including around $9bn for Gaza.

TITLE: An AI Salvador Dalí will answer any question when called on his famous 'lobster phone'
SUMMARY: <em>Ask Dalí

TITLE: Israeli strikes on southern Gaza city of Rafah kill 22, including 18 children
SUMMARY: Israeli strikes on the southern Gaza city of Rafah killed 22 people, including 18 children. Meanwhile, the United States approved $26 billion in aid for Israel, including around $9 billion for Gaza.

TITLE: In Ukraine, the vote to renew U.S. aid was cheered. But unease for the future remains
SUMMARY: Congress moved a step closer on Saturday toward finalizing long-delayed military assistance for Ukraine. But relief among Ukrainians has been mixed with uneasiness over future U.S. assistance.

TITLE: Photos: Jerusalem's sacred crossroads endures in a time of war
SUMMARY: The convergence of three Christian, Muslim and Jewish holidays this spring led to fears of violence. But the city central to these major religions has remained largely peaceful.

TITLE: The Lyrids meteor shower is peaking. Here's how to enjoy it with a bright moon
SUMMARY: The Lyrids meteor shower is active until April 29 and is peaking overnight from Sunday into Monday. To see it, it's best to find an area with trees or a mountain blocking out the moon.

TITLE: Conductor Andrew Davis, who headed orchestras on 3 continents, dies at 80
SUMMARY: Davis led the Toronto Symphony Orchestra, Britain's Glyndebourne Festival, the BBC Symphony Orchestra, the Melbourne Symphony Orchestra and the Lyric Opera in Chicago.

TITLE: Terry Anderson, AP reporter held captive for years, dies at 76
SUMMARY: Snatched from a street in war-torn Lebanon in 1985, reporter Terry Andersen chronicled his years of imprisonment in a 1993 best-selling book. He died at home in New York on Sunday.

TITLE: Tesla cuts its car prices around the world after week of turmoil for the company
SUMMARY: The company dropped its starting prices of its Model X, Model Y and Model S by $2,000 in the U.S.

TITLE: Los Angeles Mayor Karen Bass safe after suspect breaks into official residence
SUMMARY: Police in Los Angeles arrested a suspect following a break-in at the home of Mayor Karen Bass on Sunday morning, officials said.

TITLE: Ecuadorians vote in referendum to approve toughening fight against gangs
SUMMARY: Ecuador's president got a resounding victory Sunday in a referendum that he touted as a way to crack down on criminal gangs behind a spiraling wave of violence.

TITLE: North Korea fires missile into ocean in its latest weapons launch, South Korea says
SUMMARY: North Korea fired a ballistic missile toward its eastern waters on Monday, South Korea's military said, the latest in a recent series of weapons launches by the North.

TITLE: Israeli military intelligence chief resigns over failure to prevent Oct. 7 attack
SUMMARY: The head of Israel's military intelligence directorate resigned on Monday over the failures surrounding Hamas' unprecedented Oct. 7 attack, the deadliest assault in Israel's history.

TITLE: Europe is warming up faster than any other continent, and the heat is deadly
SUMMARY: The number of heat-related deaths in Europe increased 30% in the last 20 years. Climate change is to blame.

TITLE: How do you build without over polluting? That's the challenge of new Catan board game
SUMMARY: A new version of the popular board game Catan aims to make players wrestle with a 21st-century problem: How do you develop and expand without overly polluting the planet?

TITLE: Many in Gen Z ditch colleges for trade schools. Meet the 'toolbelt generation'
SUMMARY: With demand for jobs like HVAC technicians, electricians and wind turbine installers, enrollment is ticking up at vocational schools as four-year college costs continue to soar.

TITLE: A cheap drug may slow down aging. A study will determine if it works
SUMMARY: Studies suggest people who take metformin for diabetes may be at lower risk for cancer, heart disease and dementia. Now researchers aim to test if it prevents age-related diseases in healthy people.

TITLE: Supreme Court weighs whether cities can punish unhoused people for sleeping outside
SUMMARY: Lower courts ruled it's "cruel and unusual" to fine or jail people on public land if no shelter is available. An Oregon city says that's hamstrung efforts to keep public spaces safe and open to all.

TITLE: On Earth Day, Biden is launching a new site to apply for Climate Corps jobs
SUMMARY: President Biden has been trying to get young voters excited about his 2024 reelection bid, even though polls show they're disappointed with some of his policies.

TITLE: 'Ban them all.' With Paris Games looming, Chinese doping scandal rocks Olympic sport
SUMMARY: The World Anti-Doping Agency acknowledges it knew of doping concerns involving 23 Chinese swimmers before the 2021 Tokyo Games but failed to alert others. Some of those swimmers later won gold medals.

TITLE: Four 'American Indicators' share their view of the U.S. economy — and their politics
SUMMARY: The economy is a top voting issue for many Americans. Four "American Indicators," people reflecting different sectors of the economy in different parts of the country, talk about their politics.

TITLE: North Korea fires short-range missiles into the sea in its latest weapons test
SUMMARY: North Korea on Monday test-fired suspected short-range ballistic missiles into the sea, the country's neighbors said, as speculation swirled that it could soon launch a banned satellite into orbit.

TITLE: TikTok faces its biggest threat yet; Earth Day tips for sustainable living
SUMMARY: The House passed a bill that would ban TikTok unless the China-based ByteDance sells it. These small changes will help you live more sustainably.

TITLE: How two good friends became sworn siblings — with the revival of an ancient ritual
SUMMARY: Thousands of years ago, there was a ceremony to bind close friends together as sworn siblings. Could the practice be resurrected today to strengthen modern friendships? Two women did just that.

TITLE: Caitlin Clark and Fever frenzy hit the WNBA, boosting ticket prices and jersey sales
SUMMARY: Demand is skyrocketing to see Caitlin Clark play with the Indiana Fever. Ahead of her WNBA debut, ticket sales are soaring and some teams are relocating their games to larger venues.

TITLE: Israel 'spoofs' GPS to deter attacks, but it also throws off planes, ships and apps
SUMMARY: GPS "spoofing" sends false location signals to satellites to deter rockets and missiles. It also increases risks for planes, ships and technology that rely on the system.

TITLE: Looking for new ways to appreciate nature? 2 new birding books may help
SUMMARY: Novelist Amy Tan's The Backyard Bird Chronicles centers on an array of birds that visit her yard, as Trish O'Kane's Birding to Change the World

TITLE: Oncologists' meetings with drug reps don't help cancer patients live longer
SUMMARY: Drug company reps commonly visit doctors to talk about new medications. A team of economists wanted to know if that helps patients live longer. They found that for cancer patients, the answer is no.

TITLE: Freedom Monument Park tells honest story of enslaved people
SUMMARY: The new Freedom Monument Sculpture Park in Montgomery, Alabama, is designed to get visitors closer to the experiences of enslaved people in America.

TITLE: Taylor Swift and 'Tortured Poets' smash the Spotify album streaming record
SUMMARY: On Friday — the day Swift released her 11th album, <em>The Tortured Poets Department

TITLE: How the Founding Fathers' concept of 'Minority Rule' is alive and well today
SUMMARY: Journalist Ari Berman says the founding fathers created a system that concentrated power in the hands of an elite minority — and that their decisions continue to impact American democracy today.

TITLE: First day of Trump's hush money trial kicks off with opening statements and a witness
SUMMARY: The prosecution is arguing that Donald Trump wanted to keep information out of the public fearing that it would turn off voters in 2016. The defense argues Trump did nothing illegal.

TITLE: With close calls mounting, the FAA will require more rest for air traffic controllers
SUMMARY: Federal regulators are increasing the amount of required rest between shifts for air traffic controllers. The changes come as two recent close calls on runways add to concerns about aviation safety.

TITLE: Columbia University shifts classes to remote-only after a wave of protests on campus
SUMMARY: Yale University, Emerson College and New York University are among the few schools where students are staging encampments calling for divestment from Israel.

TITLE: California proposes law to allow Arizona doctors to perform abortions as ban proceeds
SUMMARY: California Gov. Gavin Newsom says his administration is working on emergency legislation. Earlier this month, the Arizona Supreme Court ruled that a near-total abortion ban could take effect.

TITLE: Clothing store Express, a mall favorite, has filed for bankruptcy
SUMMARY: Express, which dressed generations of mall shoppers in slacks and blouses, now owns Bonobos and UpWest. It's closing dozens of stores but also plans to get sold to a consortium to survive.

TITLE: Why Should the U.S. Send Aid to Ukraine?
SUMMARY: The U.S. Congress is poised to finally approve a package of aid to Ukraine worth over $60 billion, with the House having approved the funds on Saturday. The Ukrainian prime minister was in Washington to urge for the aid to be passed and explains why Americans should continue to assist in his country's war effort.

TITLE: The U.K.'s plan to deport asylum-seekers to Rwanda has cleared Parliament
SUMMARY: The British government has pushed the plan as a way to deter asylum-seekers from taking boats to Britain. But the U.N. human rights office has warned aviation authorities not to take part.

TITLE: TikTok ban expected to become law, but it's not so simple. What's next?
SUMMARY: The Senate is poised to pass the bill the House advanced over the weekend. President Biden is set to sign it. From there, TikTok says the battle will move to the courts.

TITLE: U.K. Parliament approves a plan to deport asylum-seekers to Rwanda
SUMMARY: The British government has pushed the plan as a way to deter asylum-seekers from taking boats to Britain. But the U.N. human rights office has warned aviation authorities not to take part.

TITLE: North Korean leader Kim led rocket drills that simulated a nuclear counterattack
SUMMARY: State media described the drill as aimed at demonstrating the strength and diverse attack means of North Korea's nuclear forces amid deepening tensions with the United States and South Korea

TITLE: United Methodists will again debate LGBTQ clergy and same-sex weddings
SUMMARY: The United Methodist Church is holding its first General Conference since the pandemic and will consider whether to change policies on several LGBTQ issues.

TITLE: What the Starbucks case at the Supreme Court is all about. Hint: It's not coffee
SUMMARY: Starbucks and some of its baristas have been in a contentious fight over unionizing since 2021. Now, the Supreme Court is hearing a case that could have implications for unions far beyond Starbucks.

TITLE: Talks for a plastic pollution treaty are stalling. Could the U.S. be doing more?
SUMMARY: Critics say the U.S. has been unwilling to push for measures in a global agreement that would drive big cuts in plastic waste.

TITLE: Concerns over antisemitism rise as Jews begin observing Passover
SUMMARY: Protests on college campuses related to the Israel-Hamas War have many Jews nervous heading into the holiday.

TITLE: Biden is campaigning in Florida a week before a new abortion ban takes effect
SUMMARY: There's a referendum on abortion rights on the ballot in Florida in November. President Biden's campaign says that could help buoy his chances there.

TITLE: After 26,000 public comments, FTC to vote on rule banning noncompete agreements
SUMMARY: The Federal Trade Commission will vote Tuesday on whether to issue a final rule banning noncompete agreements. The Biden administration has argued that noncompetes harm workers and stifle competition.

TITLE: New federal grants aimed to support elections. Many voting officials didn't see a dime
SUMMARY: Voting officials cheered when it was announced that a portion of a multibillion-dollar federal grant program would go to election security. But in many cases, the allocations didn't go as planned.

TITLE: 3 Maryland juveniles are charged with hate crimes. How did it get to that point?
SUMMARY: The arrests of the three middle schoolers came last month. Experts say young kids are increasingly exposed to hate ideologies, leaving communities to figure out how to respond.

TITLE: Ex-National Enquirer publisher testifies against Donald Trump in hush money trial
SUMMARY: David Pecker has previously cooperated with federal investigations into payments made to two women who were going to allege they had affairs with Trump ahead of the 2016 presidential election.

TITLE: Well, hello, Voyager 1! The venerable spacecraft is once again making sense
SUMMARY: After a nasty computer glitch five months ago, Voyager 1 is once again able to communicate with Earth in a way that mission operators can understand.

TITLE: Gaza solidarity protests sweep U.S. colleges; SCOTUS tackles Starbucks union case
SUMMARY: Tensions are high as campus protests over the war in Gaza stretch across the U.S. The Supreme Court will hear a case about pro-union Starbucks employees.

TITLE: What's at stake as the Supreme Court hears Idaho case about abortion in emergencies
