SUMMARY: The Supreme Court will consider the question: Should doctors treating pregnancy complications follow state or federal law if the laws conflict? Here's how the case could affect women and doctors.

TITLE: Justice Department pays $138 million over FBI failures in Larry Nassar case
SUMMARY: The DOJ settlement goes to 139 victims of Larry Nassar, the disgraced team doctor of USA Gymnastics who sexually assaulted elite and Olympic gymnasts, after the FBI failed to promptly investigate.

TITLE: Pro-Palestinian encampments and protests spread on college campuses across the U.S.
SUMMARY: After dozens of pro-Palestinian protesters were arrested at Columbia, Yale and NYU, students at colleges from Massachusetts to Minnesota to California are erecting encampments in solidarity.

TITLE: A hunk of space junk crashed through a Florida man's roof. Who should pay to fix it?
SUMMARY: "It was not like anything I had ever seen before," Alejandro Otero says. It turned out his home was hit by debris from the International Space Station that had been circling the Earth for three years.

TITLE: Report on UNRWA concludes Israel has not provided evidence of employees' militancy
SUMMARY: An independent review commissioned by the United Nations did not have a mandate to investigate Israel's other claim that a dozen UNRWA employees took part in the Oct. 7 Hamas-led attack on Israel.

TITLE: Trump to score additional $1.2 billion windfall thanks to his Truth Social app
SUMMARY: Trump is getting additional shares in his social media company, Trump Media & Technology Group, as part of his current agreement. He still can't cash in yet though.

TITLE: Scrambled GPS: the New Electronic Fog of War
SUMMARY: Two stories of how our reliance on GPS becomes problematic in regions experiencing war. In Ukraine, the power grid's use of GPS becomes a liability. And in the Middle East today, GPS "spoofing" causes a variety of issues from plane navigation to internet dating.

TITLE: U.S. bans noncompete agreements for nearly all jobs
SUMMARY: The Federal Trade Commission has voted to ban employment agreements that typically prevent workers from leaving their companies for competitors, or starting competing businesses of their own.

TITLE: Tesla profits have plummeted. Elon Musk remains all-in on robotaxis
SUMMARY: Tesla's sales are down. It's slashing car prices and laying off staff. Yet CEO Elon Musk remains bullish on a future that's self-driving and battery-powered.

TITLE: Senate overwhelmingly passes aid for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan with bipartisan vote
SUMMARY: The bill passed the Senate on an overwhelming 79-18 vote late Tuesday after the House had approved the package Saturday. Biden is expected to quickly sign the legislation.

TITLE: Remnants of the bird flu virus have been found in pasteurized milk, the FDA says
SUMMARY: The agency stressed the material is inactivated and that the findings "do not represent actual virus that may be a risk to consumers," but it's continuing to study the issue.

TITLE: South Koreans sue government over climate change, saying it's violating human rights
SUMMARY: Plaintiffs including 17-month-old boy nicknamed Woodpecker bring landmark climate litigation in South Korea, the first in Asia to get a public hearing.

TITLE: Supreme Court to examine a federal-state conflict over emergency abortions
SUMMARY: The case comes from Idaho, where the law banning abortions is sufficiently strict that the state's leading hospital system says its patients are at risk.

TITLE: Most nursing homes don't have enough staff to meet the federal government's new rules
SUMMARY: The new rules mean 4 out of 5 nursing homes will need more aides and nurses. Unions hailed the change, but advocates say it's not enough care, while nursing home owners say it's an "impossible task."

TITLE: DOT cracks down on airline 'junk fees' with stronger passenger protections
SUMMARY: In an effort to crack down on airlines that charge passengers steep fees to check bags and change flights, the Biden administration announced new regulations aimed at expanding consumer protections.

TITLE: No more noncompetes, FTC says; Tenessee bill would allow teachers to carry guns
SUMMARY: The Federal Trade Comission voted yesterday to ban nearly all noncompete agreements. Tenessee's lawmakers have passed a bill allowing teachers to carry guns on campus.

TITLE: How do you get siblings to be nice to each other? Latino families have an answer
SUMMARY: Over the past few decades, psychologists have begun to understand how parents across many cultures teach their children to build deep, fulfilling relationships with their siblings.

TITLE: Runaway horses gallop through central London, blazing a path of mayhem and injuries
SUMMARY: Five military horses got spooked during a training exercise, bolting and weaving a path of destruction across the city before being captured. Several people and horses are being treated for injuries.

TITLE: Reggie Bush reinstated as 2005 Heisman Trophy winner after changes in NCAA rules
SUMMARY: The University of Southern California had returned the award a decade ago after an NCAA investigation that found Bush received what were then impermissible benefits during his time with the Trojans.

TITLE: South Koreans sue government over climate change, saying policy violates human rights
SUMMARY: Plaintiffs including 17-month-old boy nicknamed Woodpecker bring landmark climate litigation in South Korea, the first in Asia to get a public hearing.

TITLE: 130 million Americans routinely breathe unhealthy air, report finds
SUMMARY: Climate change is making it harder to meet clean air goals, says the 25th annual State of the Air report from the American Lung Association.

TITLE: President Biden signs law to ban TikTok nationwide unless it is sold
SUMMARY: The measure was included in a foreign aid package providing support to Ukraine and Israel. TikTok has vowed to challenge the law in federal court.

TITLE: Airlines are ordered to give full refunds instead of vouchers and to stop hiding fees
SUMMARY: In an effort to crack down on airlines that charge passengers steep fees to check bags and change flights, the Biden administration announced new regulations aimed at expanding consumer protections.

TITLE: Biden signs $95 billion military aid package for Ukraine, Israel and Taiwan
SUMMARY: Ukraine will get most of the assistance as it struggles to combat Russia's overwhelming firepower. The bill also includes more weapons for Israel, and humanitarian help for Gaza.

TITLE: With federal fraud trial looming, George Santos drops out of New York House race
SUMMARY: The scandal-plagued former Republican congressman, ousted from his House seat last year, abandoned his long-shot independent bid for Congress. But he suggested his political career may not be over.

TITLE: Barbara Walters forged a path for women in journalism, but not without paying a price
SUMMARY: Walters was the first woman to co-anchor a national news show on prime time television. "The path she cut is one that many of us have followed," says biographer Susan Page, author of <em>The Rulebreaker.

TITLE: The Story of One Child Living in Gaza
SUMMARY:
As Israel's war against Hamas continues, children in Gaza are suffering. According to the United Nations, more than 25,000 children have been killed or injured since October. That's one child every ten minutes. We hear about one of those children, a twelve year-old boy injured in Gaza.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Taylor Swift set a new record this week with, well, records. The vinyl kind.
SUMMARY: Taylor Swift, whose latest album is now the first to surpass one billion Spotify streams in a single week, has smashed another record as well.

TITLE: In Florida, an exodus of people fleeing rising anti-immigrant sentiment
SUMMARY: Nearly a year ago, Florida passed one of the toughest immigration laws in the country. In some communities, it's caused a mass exodus. Those who stayed behind say, it's made life terrifying.

TITLE: Shot by Israeli troops while getting aid, a boy in Gaza fights for his life
SUMMARY: UNICEF says one child is injured or killed in Gaza every 10 minutes. This is the story of a 12-year-old boy shot by Israeli forces while he was trying to get food aid.

TITLE: Heated arguments at the Supreme Court in newest abortion case
SUMMARY: At issue is a clash between federal and state law about how pregnant women must be treated in the emergency room.

TITLE: Gateway Pundit files for bankruptcy after election conspiracy defamation lawsuits
SUMMARY: The influential website faced multiple defamation suits over conspiracy theories about 2020 election fraud that it's accused of promoting.

TITLE: What consumers should know about the milk testing positive for bird flu
SUMMARY: Federal officials and scientific experts say the virus detected in retail milk samples may be inactive and unable to cause an infection.

TITLE: Meadows, Giuliani, 11 'fake electors' from 2020 are among those indicted in Arizona
SUMMARY: Arizona is now the fourth state where charges have been brought against individuals involved in so-called "fake elector" schemes that sought to undermine Joe Biden's victory over Donald Trump.

TITLE: World Central Kitchen workers killed in Israeli strikes will be honored at memorial
SUMMARY: The aid workers were killed April 1 when a succession of Israeli armed drones ripped through vehicles in their convoy as they left one of World Central Kitchen's warehouses on a food delivery mission.

TITLE: Pro-Palestinian protests spread to the campuses of USC and the University of Texas
SUMMARY: Arrests were made at both schools. The LAPD said it would continue patrolling USC's campus into Thursday, while Texas Gov. Greg Abbott said the protestors at UT-Austin belong in jail.

TITLE: American Airlines passenger alleges discrimination over use of first-class restroom
SUMMARY: In a complaint to the airline, Pamela Hill-Veal, a retired judge, says that while on a Chicago-to-Phoenix flight, a flight attendant berated her and accused her of slamming the lavatory door.

TITLE: Amazon warehouse workers in Alabama might get a third try at unionizing
SUMMARY: Federal officials threw out the first vote, ruling that Amazon improperly interfered. The results of the second vote remain inconclusive. The federal government now determines what happens next.

TITLE: Biden is giving $6 billion to Micron for a semiconductor project in upstate New York
SUMMARY: The Micron project comes after the White House has announced massive investments for Intel, TSMC and Samsung in recent weeks using funds from the 2022 CHIPS and Science Act.

TITLE: Caleb Williams, likely top NFL draft pick, traces success to an interception at age 9
SUMMARY: Caleb Williams is expected to be taken No. 1 by the Chicago Bears in Thursday's NFL Draft. Williams, who played quarterback at Southern California and Oklahoma, faced challenges at a young age.

TITLE: He missed a chance to be the first Black astronaut. Now, at 90, he's going into space
SUMMARY: Edward J. Dwight Jr. is set to be on the next Blue Origin rocket into space. The rare opportunity comes more than six decades after he was passed over to become a NASA astronaut.

TITLE: Animals get stressed during eclipses. But not for the reason you think
SUMMARY: After studying various species earlier this month, some scientists now say they understand the origin of animal behavior during solar eclipses.

TITLE: The Supreme Court will hear Trump's claim he's immune from criminal prosecution
SUMMARY: Trump's argument for immunity is broad: He contends that he cannot be prosecuted for his "official acts" as president unless he is first impeached, convicted by the Senate and removed from office.

TITLE: Coal and new gas power plants will have to meet climate pollution targets
SUMMARY: Fifteen years after the EPA said greenhouse gasses are a danger to public health, the agency finalized rules to limit climate-warming pollution from existing coal and new gas power plants.

TITLE: States find a downside to mandatory reporting laws meant to protect children
SUMMARY: Colorado is looking at ways to weed out false reporting of child abuse and neglect as the number of reports reaches a record high. New York and California are reworking the policies, too.

TITLE: Arizona indicts Trump allies in 'fake elector' scheme; bird flu remnants found in milk
SUMMARY: Arizona is now the fourth state to bring "fake elector" charges against Donald Trump's allies. Retail milk has tested positive for bird flu remnants. Here's what to know.

TITLE: China launches a new crew to its space station, advancing toward lunar mission
SUMMARY: Three astronauts will spend six months on China's space station. Some experts worry China's ambitious space program could pose a threat to U.S. space superiority and military effectiveness.

TITLE: Harvey Weinstein's 2020 sex crimes conviction in New York overturned
SUMMARY: The New York State Court of Appeals ruled Thursday that the former movie mogul had not received a fair trial in 2020 that led to a 23-year sentence, and ordered a new trial.

TITLE: An American hostage is seen alive for the first time since Oct. 7 in a Hamas video
SUMMARY: Hersh Goldberg-Polin, who turned 24 last month while in captivity, has spent more than 200 days in captivity. His left arm was partially blown off by a grenade during the Hamas-led attack on Oct. 7.

TITLE: How's your city attracting people downtown these days? NPR wants to hear from you
SUMMARY: Many cities are rolling out new events and initiatives to get more people downtown again. We want to hear what's working where you are.

TITLE: After two Boeing 737 Max crashes, families are still seeking answers from DOJ
SUMMARY: More than five years after two 737 MAX crashes killed 346 people, families of the victims are still pushing the Justice Department to hold Boeing accountable. They're frustrated by the response.

TITLE: Some 300 musicians, from Diplo to Nile Rodgers, lobby Congress for ticketing reform
SUMMARY: Billie Eilish, Fall Out Boy, Nile Rodgers, Cyndi Lauper, Lorde, Sia, Diplo and Chappell Roan are among the signatories of an open letter urging a Senate committee to support the Fans First Act.

TITLE: Venice tests a 5-euro fee for day-trippers as the city grapples with overtourism
SUMMARY: The fragile lagoon city of Venice launched a pilot program to charge day-trippers an entry fee that authorities hope will discourage crowds on peak days and make the city more livable for residents.

TITLE: Haiti's Prime Minister Ariel Henry has resigned as a transitional council takes over
SUMMARY: Haiti's de facto prime minister, Ariel Henry, has formally stepped down and a new transitional council has been sworn in. Finance chief Michel Patrick Boisvert is the new interim prime minister.

TITLE: Kim Kardashian visits the White House to highlight criminal justice reform
SUMMARY: Vice President Harris and Kardashian are meeting with a four people convicted of non-violent drug offenses who received pardons this week from President Biden.

TITLE: Emergency flights for pregnant patients up sharply in Idaho under strict abortion law
SUMMARY: The number of people needing flights out of Idaho for emergency abortions is up sharply since the state's abortion ban took effect.

TITLE: Why experts say inflation is relatively low but voters feel differently
SUMMARY: Grocery prices are a key component of any household budget, and rising food prices can sour the electorate's mood.

TITLE: 17 states challenge federal rules entitling workers to accommodations for abortion
SUMMARY: The lawsuit comes after federal regulations were published on implementing the Pregnant Workers Fairness Act. The language means workers can ask for time off to obtain and recover from an abortion.

TITLE: Guatemalan AG raids Save the Children office over a migrant children rights complaint
SUMMARY: Prosecutor Rafael Curruchiche said that the complaint filed by an unidentified foreigner had raised serious concerns because it involved allegations of abuse of children.

TITLE: Ukraine pulls U.S.-provided Abrams tanks from the front lines over drone threats
SUMMARY: Five of the 31 tanks have already been lost to Russian attacks in Ukraine, where the use of surveillance and hunter-killer drones had made it difficult for them to operate.

TITLE: Here's why Spain's prime minister Pedro Sánchez is considering stepping down
SUMMARY: Socialist Prime Minister Pedro Sánchez left Spain in suspense after announcing he may step down because of what he called an "unprecedented" smear campaign against his wife.

TITLE: What to know about a possible Israeli military offensive in Rafah
SUMMARY: In Gaza's southernmost city, where more than a million Palestinians have sought shelter and where aid groups have centralized operations, worries have grown over a possible Israeli military operation.

TITLE: More than 500 people have been arrested at pro-Palestinian protests at colleges
SUMMARY: Students and others are protesting Israel's war against Hamas in Gaza and, in some cases, their school's investments in Israel. Presidents at several schools face calls to resign amid the protests.

TITLE: United Methodist Church begins reorganization over LGBTQ+ issues
SUMMARY: The United Methodist Church has voted to restructure itself in a way that could allow for LGBTQ+ clergy and same-sex weddings.

TITLE: A year later, Florida businesses say the state's immigration law dealt a huge blow.
SUMMARY: Florida passed in 2023 one of the strictest immigration laws in the country, and now businesses struggle to find workers in several sectors of the economy

TITLE: A Baltimore teacher is accused of using AI to make his boss appear racist
SUMMARY: This wild case emphasizes the serious potential for criminal misuse of artificial intelligence that experts have been warning about for some time, one professor said.

TITLE: Former tabloid publisher details actions on behalf of Trump ahead of 2016 election
SUMMARY: David Pecker, the former publisher of the <em>National Enquirer,

TITLE: Alabama woman who says police assaulted her after calling 911 files federal lawsuit
SUMMARY: Twyla Stallworth, a woman from Andalusia, Ala., filed a federal lawsuit against the city, its police department and Grant Barton, the police officer involved in the incident.

TITLE: Where can you call an artist on a lobster? Find out in the quiz
SUMMARY: Plus, Tesla's next move, Taylor's new record and why zoo animals (sometimes) get weird during eclipses.

TITLE: China's influence operations against the U.S. are bigger than TikTok
SUMMARY: Intelligence officials and lawmakers describe the Chinese-owned social media app as a national security threat. But they haven't shared that evidence with the public.

TITLE: Trump's immunity arguments and the experiences of the justices who might support it
SUMMARY: Five of the six conservatives spent much of their lives in the Beltway, working in the White House and Justice Department, seeing their administrations as targets of unfair harassment by Democrats.

TITLE: Idaho's biggest hospital says emergency flights for pregnant patients up sharply
SUMMARY: Idaho's biggest hospital system says the number of people needing flights out of Idaho for emergency abortions is up sharply since the state's abortion ban took effect.

TITLE: Campus protests over Gaza could affect graduation; Steve Inkseep interviews Blinken
SUMMARY: Hundreds of students have been arrested at pro-Palestinian protests at colleges nationwide. NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with Antony Blinken in an exclusive interview about U.S.-China relations.

TITLE: A Baltimore-area teacher is accused of using AI to make his boss appear racist
SUMMARY: This wild case emphasizes the serious potential for criminal misuse of artificial intelligence that experts have been warning about for some time, one professor said.

TITLE: Pro-Palestinian campus protesters face looming deadlines and risk of arrest
SUMMARY: Hundreds of students have been arrested for participating in pro-Palestinian protests in recent days. And some schools, like Columbia and GW, have given them deadlines to dismantle their encampments.

TITLE: A year later, Florida businesses say the state's immigration law dealt a huge blow
SUMMARY: Florida passed in 2023 one of the strictest immigration laws in the country, and now businesses struggle to find workers in several sectors of the economy

TITLE: A Delta Air Lines flight makes an emergency return following concerns with plane wing
SUMMARY: The flight was forced to make an emergency return to JFK airport after the crew observed issues related to the right wing emergency exit slide, as well as a sound near the right wing.

TITLE: Taylor Swift fans mean business with Tortured Poet soap, Eras yarn, Kelce cookies
SUMMARY: Entrepreneurial Swifties are selling crafty products inspired by Taylor Swift's music and style. Swift herself has been known to send notes and even homemade gifts to creative super-fans.

TITLE: Blinken tells China it's in their interest to stop helping Russia
SUMMARY: NPR's Steve Inskeep speaks with U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken following his talks with Chinese leader Xi Jinping and top Chinese officials in Beijing.

TITLE: King Charles III is returning to royal duties after his cancer diagnosis
SUMMARY: Buckingham Palace hasn't said what type of cancer Charles had or if he's finished treatment. It said he'll make a public visit to a cancer clinic Tuesday and will welcome Japan's emperor in June.

TITLE: A baby girl born orphaned and premature after an Israeli airstrike in Gaza has died
SUMMARY: The newborn died after five days in an incubator. Her family was killed in an air strike. UNICEF says 13,000 children have been killed in Gaza since Oct. 7, with thousands more orphaned and wounded.

TITLE: Taylor Swift fans mean business with Tortured Poets soap, Eras yarn, Kelce cookies
SUMMARY: Entrepreneurial Swifties are selling crafty products inspired by Taylor Swift's music and style. Swift herself has been known to send notes and even homemade gifts to creative super-fans.

TITLE: DRC is seeing its worst mpox outbreak — but has no vaccines or treatments yet. Why?
SUMMARY: With nearly 5,000 cases reported so far this year — and concerns about a new strain — the Democratic Republic of Congo is considering the declaration of a public health emergency.

TITLE: Net neutrality is back: U.S. promises fast, safe and reliable internet for all
SUMMARY: The U.S. will reinstate Obama-era regulations for internet service providers that promise fast, reliable and fair internet speeds for all consumers. What happened when those rules were taken away?

TITLE: Climate activist who defaced Edgar Degas sculpture sentenced to 60 days in prison
SUMMARY: A federal judge sentenced Joanna Smith to 60 days in prison for smearing paint on the case surrounding Edgar Degas' <em>Little Dancer, Aged Fourteen

TITLE: Delta flight makes emergency return after exit slide separates from Boeing aircraft
SUMMARY: The Los Angeles-bound flight was forced to make an emergency return to New York's JFK airport after an emergency slide came apart from the Boeing 767, the airline said.

TITLE: Biden administration abandons plan to ban menthol cigarettes, citing 'feedback'
SUMMARY: An anti-smoking advocate says the decision to leave menthol cigarettes on the market "prioritizes politics over lives, especially Black lives."

TITLE: In Columbia University's protests of 1968 and 2024, what's similar — and different
SUMMARY: There are parallels between the two high-profile events, most starkly the proliferation of similar protests around the country. But key differences set them apart.

TITLE: Climate activist who defaced Edgar Degas sculpture exhibit sentenced
SUMMARY: A federal judge sentenced Joanna Smith to 60 days in prison for smearing paint on the case surrounding Edgar Degas' <em>Little Dancer, Aged Fourteen

TITLE: Midwest tornadoes cause severe damage in Omaha suburbs
SUMMARY: Multiple tornadoes were reported in Nebraska but the most destructive storm moved from a largely rural area into suburbs northwest of Omaha. Hundreds of homes and other structures have been damaged.

TITLE: UAW strike at Daimler Truck averted at 11th hour
SUMMARY: More than 7,000 Daimler Truck workers, most of them in North Carolina, had threatened to go on strike. The UAW says the workers will get raises of at least 25% plus cost of living allowances.

TITLE: Tornadoes collapse buildings and level homes in Nebraska and Iowa
SUMMARY: Tornadoes wreaked havoc Friday in the Midwest, causing a building to collapse with dozens of people inside and destroying and damaging hundreds of homes, many around Omaha, Nebraska.

TITLE: South Africa remembers an historic election every April 27, Freedom Day
SUMMARY: South Africans celebrate their "Freedom Day" every April 27, when they remember their country's pivotal first democratic election in 1994 that announced the official end of apartheid.

TITLE: Iran women's protests are the focus of 'Persepolis' author Marjane Satrapi's new book
SUMMARY: The French Iranian author and artist, best known for her graphic novel Persepolis, edited and contributed to a new graphic anthology titled Woman, Life, Freedom,

TITLE: Mike Johnson and the troubled history of recent Republican speakers
SUMMARY: Johnson is the sixth Republican elevated to the speakership since 1994. The five who preceded him all saw their time in the office end in relative degrees of defeat or frustration.

TITLE: Got brothers or sisters? Warm sibling bonds help booster happiness as you age
SUMMARY: Researchers have found that a warm, close bond with a sibling in early adult life is predictive of good emotional health later in life, with less loneliness, anxiety and depression.

TITLE: What abortion politics has to do with new rights for pregnant workers
SUMMARY: A new regulation to protect the rights of pregnant workers is the subject of an anti-abortion lawsuit because it includes abortion as a pregnancy "related medical condition."

TITLE: A 100-degree heat wave in Gaza offers a sweltering glimpse of a tough summer to come
SUMMARY: The heat bore down on Palestinians living in tents and aid groups working in the sun. UNRWA reported several heat injuries among its staff, and at least one 18-year-old Palestinian died from the heat.

TITLE: A student club is suing its school, saying its pro-Palestinian views were censored
SUMMARY: Members of the Washington, D.C., school Arab students club say their rights were violated "because the school does not want their viewpoint ... to be heard."

TITLE: An illegal migrant, age 17, drowned in a Bosnian river. Here's how citizens responded
SUMMARY: On the risky journey from the Global South to Europe, migrants often perish. In a town in Bosnia-Herzegovina, near a river where dozens have drowned, citizens seek to provide closure to the families.

TITLE: Got brothers or sisters? Warm sibling bonds help boost happiness as you age
SUMMARY: Researchers have found that a warm, close bond with a sibling in early adult life is predictive of good emotional health later in life, with less loneliness, anxiety and depression.

TITLE: Hamas says it's preparing to respond to Israel's latest Gaza cease-fire proposal
SUMMARY: The militant group says it's examining the latest Israeli suggestions for a cease-fire in Gaza, seven months into the conflict that has claimed tens of thousands of lives.

TITLE: Both sides prepare as Florida's six-week abortion ban is set to take effect Wednesday
SUMMARY: The state currently bans most abortions after 15 weeks of pregnancy. That will drop to six weeks, with a few exceptions — a timetable that abortion rights advocates say is hard to meet

TITLE: Hamas releases video of a second American being held hostage in Gaza
SUMMARY: Hamas has released a video showing two captives, one of them an American, as part of an effort to prove that the two men are still alive. It was the second video of a U.S. citizen released this week.

TITLE: Bernie Sanders says Netanyahu is attacking campus protests to deflect war criticism
SUMMARY: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu criticized ongoing campus protests across the U.S. as antisemitic. The Vermont senator said it was an attempt to "deflect attention" from Israel's actions.

TITLE: Trump VP contender Kristi Noem responds to backlash over story about killing her dog
SUMMARY: The Republican South Dakota governor details what she says was a tough decision to shoot an "untrainable" family dog in a forthcoming memoir. Animal rights advocates and Democrats decried the move.

TITLE: An Afghan migrant, age 17, drowned in a Bosnian river. Here's how citizens responded
SUMMARY: On the risky journey from the Global South to Europe, migrants often perish. In a town in Bosnia-Herzegovina, near a river where dozens have drowned, citizens seek to provide closure to the families.

TITLE: Gaza protestors picket White House correspondents dinner, as Biden ribs Trump
SUMMARY: The war in Gaza spurred large protests outside a glitzy roast with President Joe Biden, journalists, politicians and celebrities Saturday but went all but unmentioned by participants inside.

TITLE: Harvey Weinstein hospitalized after his return to New York from upstate prison
SUMMARY: Harvey Weinstein's lawyer said that the onetime movie mogul has been hospitalized for tests after his return to New York City following an appeals court ruling nullifying his 2020 rape conviction.

TITLE: A mix-up over bioengineered tomato seeds sparked fears about spread of GMO crops
SUMMARY: An organic seed company was distressed to learn it had marketed a GMO purple tomato by mistake. The incident raised alarm about the impact of new GMO plants.

TITLE: These dreamy photos of historical Cairo will transport you to another time
SUMMARY: Photographer Nour El Massry captures ethereal images of Egyptian landscapes, interiors and architecture in one of the world's largest megacities.

TITLE: The Louvre Museum looks to rehouse the 'Mona Lisa' in its own room — underground
SUMMARY: Louvre Director Laurence des Cars said her institution is looking at upgrading both the visitor experience surrounding the iconic painting as well as the museum overall.

TITLE: We asked, you answered: Let's make a toast to the ways you keep calm and carry on
SUMMARY: Our readers responded to our callout, sharing the strategies they use to lift their spirits in the face of setbacks and woes. And yes, one way is: A jam happy face on toast!

TITLE: At least 3 people are dead after tornadoes slam Oklahoma, Iowa and Nebraska
SUMMARY: Multiple tornadoes over several days leveled buildings and left a trail of damage in parts of the South and Midwest.

TITLE: Candace Parker, 3-time WNBA and 2-time Olympic champion, says 'it's time' to retire
SUMMARY: After 16 seasons, two Olympic gold medals and three WNBA championships, Candace Parker announced her retirement from professional basketball on Sunday.

TITLE: 30 years since the end of apartheid, is South Africa still an emblem of democracy?
SUMMARY:
Three decades ago, South Africa held its first democratic election, closing the door on the apartheid era.

And Nelson Mandela was elected its first Black president.

Today, the country is still led by Mandela's political party - the African National Congress. But polls show that voters are growing increasingly dissatisfied with the party's leadership, and next month's national elections could lead to the ANC having to share power with opposition parties.

Thirty years ago, South Africa became an emblem of a multiracial democracy. Decades on, how is that legacy holding up?

TITLE: At least 4 people are dead after tornadoes slam Oklahoma, Iowa and Nebraska
SUMMARY: Multiple tornadoes over several days leveled buildings and left a trail of damage in parts of the South and Midwest.

TITLE: World Central Kitchen says it will resume operations in Gaza
SUMMARY: The aid group said the humanitarian situation in Gaza remains dire and that it has almost 8 million meals ready to distribute. The group halted efforts after Israeli strikes killed seven workers.

TITLE: Nearly 300 people arrested at campus protests against the war in Gaza this weekend
SUMMARY: Police took more than 250 protesters into custody in Arizona, Indiana, Massachusetts and Missouri this weekend, as the war in Gaza continues to embroil campuses across the nation.

TITLE: CDC says 3 women diagnosed with HIV after receiving 'vampire facial'
SUMMARY: Although HIV transmission from contaminated blood through unsterile injection is a well-known risk, the CDC said this is the first documentation of probable infections involving cosmetic services.

TITLE: Military families in Hawaii spark trial over 2021 jet fuel leak that tainted water
SUMMARY: A trial for a mass environmental injury case begins in Hawaii on Monday, more than two years after a U.S. military facility poisoned thousands of people when it leaked jet fuel into drinking water.

TITLE: Elevator or stairs? Your choice could boost longevity, study finds
SUMMARY: A new study shows people who are in the habit of climbing stairs are less likely to die from heart disease compared to those who don't. Stair climbers also had a slight boost in longevity.

TITLE: All grown up, but still fighting? Why more siblings are turning to therapy, together
SUMMARY: Plenty of people go to couples therapy — why not siblings therapy? Experts say the long, complicated relationships between siblings are worth exploring and tending to.

TITLE: ICC reportedly weighs arrest warrants for Israeli officials; new abortion lawsuit
SUMMARY: The International Criminal Court is reportedly preparing arrest warrants for Netanyahu and other Israeli officials. What the latest abortion lawsuit has to do with new rights for pregnant workers

TITLE: Quiz: Can you pass our 9 question test on the latest theories of COVID-19 transmission
SUMMARY: The World Health Organization has issued a report updating terminology and explanations regarding the spread of the novel coronavirus. See if you're up on the latest vocab.

TITLE: As student protesters get arrested, they risk being banned from campus too
SUMMARY: Students continue to protest at campuses across the country, despite the risk of arrest. Some schools now threaten demonstrators with disciplinary action, while others promise the opposite.

TITLE: Top British gymnast Ondine Achampong tears ACL, may miss Paris Olympic Games
SUMMARY: Ondine Achampong says she tore her ACL during a bars dismount. The surgery and recovery from the knee injury can take up to a year. She was expected to be a medalist at the 2024 Paris Summer Olympics.

TITLE: How much should I spend on a wedding present? Life Kit's tips of the month
SUMMARY: Our April roundup of expert advice includes a nifty negotiation tactic, guidance on how to prevent digital eye strain and why you should travel during 'shoulder season.'

TITLE: What consumers should know as Philips agrees to $1.1 billion CPAP settlement
SUMMARY: Under a related deal, users who return devices by Aug. 9 can get an extra $100. As part of the recall, the company is offering repairs, replacements or refunds of the machines' cost.

TITLE: The jump in measles cases in 2023 is 'very concerning' says WHO official
SUMMARY: And the numbers in 2024 aren't looking any better. Why is this highly infectious disease on the rise? And how can it be tamed?

TITLE: Transgender health care must be paid for by state insurance, says an appeals court
SUMMARY: The federal appeals court in Richmond, Va., ruled in favor of transgender patients on Monday. The case was brought by Medicaid recipients in West Virginia and state employees in North Carolina.

TITLE: U.S. to require automatic emergency braking on new vehicles in 5 years
SUMMARY: The National Highway Traffic Safety Administration unveiled the final version of the new regulation on Monday and called it the most significant safety rule in the past two decades.

TITLE: Gérard Depardieu will be tried for alleged sexual assaults on a film set
SUMMARY: French actor Gérard Depardieu will face a criminal trial in October over the alleged sexual assaults in 2021 of two women on the set of a film, prosecutors announced Monday.

TITLE: Mexico is taking Ecuador to the top U.N. court over storming of the Mexican Embassy
SUMMARY: Mexico is taking Ecuador to the top U.N. court Tuesday, accusing the nation of violating international law by storming the Mexican Embassy in Quito.

TITLE: Protesters at Columbia University have begun occupying a campus building
SUMMARY: Students entered Hamilton Hall early Tuesday morning and began moving furniture and climbing through open windows.

TITLE: Scientists restore brain cells impaired by a rare genetic disorder
SUMMARY: A therapy that restores brain cells impaired by a rare genetic disorder may offer a strategy for treating conditions like autism, epilepsy, and schizophrenia.

TITLE: As pro-Palestinian protests spread, more university leaders weigh police involvement
SUMMARY: As college administrators face growing unrest on campuses, a growing number are grappling with whether to bring in law enforcement to quell the demonstrations.

TITLE: AI is contentious among authors. So why are some feeding it their own writing?
SUMMARY: Many authors are concerned about the use of their copyrighted material in generative AI models. At the same time, some are actively experimenting with the technology.

TITLE: A U.S. diplomat tells NPR why she resigned in protest over the policy in Gaza
SUMMARY: As protests against the U.S. policy in Gaza unfold on college campuses across the country, the State Department is facing its own protests too.

TITLE: Abortion rights on the ballot may not be bad news for Republicans everywhere
SUMMARY: More states than ever are gearing up to vote on abortion rights this fall, including Republican-led Missouri. There, voters could show the issue isn't a down-ballot Democratic dream everywhere.

TITLE: Victims of harassment by federal judges often find the judiciary is above the law
SUMMARY: Federal judges have enormous power over their courtrooms and their chambers, which can leave employees vulnerable to abuse, with few ways to report their concerns anonymously.

TITLE: A simple smile saved this man's life
SUMMARY: Ken Wilcox's life felt hopeless, like there was nowhere left to turn. Then a simple act from a stranger on the street changed his perspective and his life.

TITLE: Sign here? Financial agreements may leave doctors in the driver's seat
SUMMARY: Agreeing to an out-of-network doctor's financial policy, which protects their ability to get paid and may be littered with confusing jargon, can create a binding contract that leaves a patient owing.

TITLE: Columbia students barricade themselves in campus building; China's EV vehicles
SUMMARY: Pro-Palestinian student protesters have occupied a campus building. Electric vehicles are the newest front of competition between the U.S. and China.

TITLE: Columbia University protesters occupy a campus building, echoing 1968
SUMMARY: Students began occupying Hamilton Hall early Tuesday morning. Now, access to the Manhattan school is restricted to essential-service employees and students who live in on-campus residential halls.

TITLE: Mammograms should start at age 40, new guidelines recommend
SUMMARY: A rise in breast cancer among younger women prompted the U.S. Preventive Task Force to issue new screening guidelines. They recommend mammograms every other year, starting at age 40.

TITLE: Donkeys take center stage at an annual festival in Colombia
SUMMARY: Every year, the town of San Antero celebrates the hardworking pack animals that haul crops and supplies for farmers who can't afford trucks or motorcycles. There's even a donkey beauty pageant.

TITLE: House Democratic leaders say they would help save Speaker Johnson's job
SUMMARY: Democrats have been telegraphing for weeks their willingness to help Mike Johnson — a Republican — keep his job as speaker if members of his own party trigger a vote to oust him.

TITLE: A top U.N. court won't order Germany to halt weapons exports to Israel
SUMMARY: Nicaragua brought the case arguing that by providing arms to Israel, Germany is failing to prevent possible genocide against Palestinians in Israel's war with Hamas in Gaza.

TITLE: Trump ordered to pay $9,000 for violating gag order in criminal hush money trial
SUMMARY: Judge Juan Merchan previously issued a gag order that specifically bars Trump from making or directing others to make public statements about potential jurors, court staff or family members of staff.

TITLE: With a deadline looming, countries race for a global agreement to cut plastic waste
SUMMARY: A United Nations official said negotiators have a "clear path to landing an ambitious deal" on plastic pollution. But environmentalists say the plastic industry is undermining an effective agreement.

TITLE: University protesters want divestments from Israel. Here's what that means
SUMMARY: Campus protesters want administrators to sell off investments in companies with ties to Israel. Here's a look at what divestment means — and why universities are saying no.

TITLE: Saying he was too nice in his first term, Trump plots an aggressive second chance
SUMMARY: In a new interview with TIME Magazine, Trump promises to prosecute President Biden, unleash the National Guard on immigrants and says it's "irrelevant" if he's comfortable criminalizing abortions.

TITLE: The Biden administration is moving to reclassify marijuana. Here's what that means
SUMMARY: The Justice Department is expected to propose a new, lower classification for marijuana that would lessen restrictions on the drug. But there's another review process to come.

TITLE: An Agonizing Choice: Whether to Flee Southern Gaza Ahead of Assault
SUMMARY:
Israel has been public with it's plan to conduct an assault on the city of Rafah, in southern Gaza, absent a ceasefire agreement with Hamas. Such a military operation could be catastrophic for more than a million Palestinian civilians there, many having fled there from fighting elsewhere in Gaza. We hear the voices of people who are weighing the risks of staying and wondering where they can go.

For more coverage of all sides of this conflict, go to npr.org/mideastupdates

TITLE: Eight newspapers sue OpenAI, Microsoft for copyright infringement
SUMMARY: The New York Daily News, the Chicago Tribune and others contend that the tech companies illegally copied their work without seeking permission or ever paying the publishers.

TITLE: Wages, employment, inflation are up, causing headaches for the Fed rates
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady this week — and possibly for months to come — as policymakers try to sort through mixed signals about the U.S. economy.

TITLE: A freed Israeli hostage waits with hope for her husband, still held by Hamas in Gaza
SUMMARY: Aviva Siegel, 63, was taken hostage by Hamas militants on Oct. 7, along with her husband Keith. She was released after 51 days, but he was not. On Saturday, Hamas released a video showing Keith alive.

TITLE: Top companies are on students' divest list. But does it really work?
SUMMARY: Campus protesters want administrators to sell off investments in companies with ties to Israel. Here's a look at what divestment means — and why universities are saying no.

TITLE: Trump may get another chance to be president. He's planning an aggressive second term
SUMMARY: In a new interview with TIME Magazine, Trump promises to prosecute President Biden, unleash the National Guard on immigrants and says it's "irrelevant" if he's comfortable criminalizing abortions.

TITLE: Wages, employment, inflation are up, causing headaches for the Fed
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve is expected to hold interest rates steady this week — and possibly for months to come — as policymakers try to sort through mixed signals about the U.S. economy.

TITLE: First responders were sentenced in Elijah McClain's death. But has justice been done?
SUMMARY: All first responders charged in the fatal botched arrest of Elijah McClain have been sentenced, but questions remain about whether it's changed how Black people are treated by police and paramedics.

TITLE: Israel will invade Gaza's Rafah 'with or without' a hostage deal, Netanyahu says
SUMMARY: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu made the vow Tuesday amid the negotiations mediated by Egypt that seek to reach a cease-fire deal that could see the release of some or all of the remaining hostages.

TITLE: Judges block Louisiana's congressional map. A Supreme Court appeal is likely
SUMMARY: A federal court has blocked Louisiana's new congressional map in a case that could determine the balance of power in the next Congress and set up another Supreme Court test of the Voting Rights Act.

TITLE: Judi Dench reflects on a career built around Shakespeare
SUMMARY:
Dame Judi Dench has played everyone from the writer Iris Murdoch to M in the James Bond films. But among the roles the actress is most closely associated, are Shakespeare's heroines and some of his villians.

Amongst those roles are the star-crossed lover Juliet, the comical Titania and the tragic Lady Macbeth. Now she's reflecting on that work, and Shakespeare's work in Shakespeare: The Man Who Pays The Rent.

The book is comprised of Dench's conversations with her friend, the actor and director Brendan O'Hea.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Bestselling novelist Paul Auster, author of 'The New York Trilogy,' dies at 77
SUMMARY: A leading figure in his generation of postmodern American writers, Auster wrote more than 20 novels, including City of Glass, Sunset Park, 4 3 2 1 and The Brooklyn Follies.

TITLE: Here's this year's list of the most endangered historic places in the U.S.
SUMMARY: The National Trust's annual list includes Eatonville, the all-Black Florida town memorialized by Zora Neale Hurston, Alaska's Sitka Tlingit Clan houses, and the home of country singer Cindy Walker.

TITLE: The announcement of a new prime minister divides Haiti's transitional council
SUMMARY: A surprise announcement that revealed Haiti's new prime minister is threatening to fracture a recently installed transitional council tasked with choosing new leaders for the gang-riddled country.

TITLE: Walmart says it will close its 51 health centers and virtual care service
SUMMARY: The Arkansas-based company said that after managing the clinics it launched in 2019 and expanding its telehealth program, it concluded "there is not a sustainable business model for us to continue."

TITLE: New York police have cleared Hamilton Hall and the encampment at Columbia University
SUMMARY: New York police officers cleared pro-Palestinian student encampments late Tuesday night at two campuses as similar protests continued to simmer across the country's higher education institutions.

TITLE: When judges get free trips to luxury resorts, disclosure is spotty
SUMMARY: Many federal judges receive free rooms and subsidized travel to luxury resorts for legal conferences. NPR found that dozens of judges did not fully disclose the perks they got.

TITLE: How some faculty members are defending student protesters, in actions and in words
SUMMARY: The protests sweeping college campuses don't just involve students. Professors are increasingly pushing back against university administrations they see as infringing on students' free speech rights.

TITLE: For many Missouri Catholics, abortion rights means choosing between faith, politics
SUMMARY: The state is shaping up to be big battleground over abortion rights in November. Research shows a majority of U.S. Catholics supports abortion rights — even though church leadership does not.

TITLE: Florida's 6-week abortion ban is now in effect, curbing access across the South
SUMMARY: Florida has been a major access point for abortion in the South. Now its residents, along with thousands more in the region, will have to seek abortion care elsewhere after six weeks of pregnancy.

TITLE: Christian conservatives wrestle with shifting GOP stance on Arizona abortion ban
SUMMARY: After former President Donald Trump and Arizona GOP senate candidate Kari Lake distanced themselves from the law, some abortion rights opponents are left wondering who they can count on.

TITLE: Reforms and heartbreak after final sentencing in Elijah McClain's death
SUMMARY: Three police officers and two paramedics faced felony charges in death of McClain, a young Black man not suspected of a crime. Two cops were aquitted.

TITLE: NPR poll: Democrats fear fascism, and Republicans worry about a lack of values
SUMMARY: A new 2024 election poll from NPR/PBS NewsHour/Marist shows fundamental divides over concerns for America's future and what to teach the next generation.

TITLE: Republicans in Congress are trying to reshape election maps by excluding noncitizens
SUMMARY: There's growing support from Republicans in Congress for excluding non-U.S. citizens from a special census count that the 14th Amendment says must include the "whole number of persons in each state."

TITLE: Before living in a pineapple under the sea, SpongeBob was born as an educational tool
SUMMARY: Nickelodeon's megahit show <em>SpongeBob SquarePants

TITLE: El Niño weather is leading to droughts and power cuts in South America
SUMMARY: A drought has upended life in several South American cities, leading to water rationing and power cuts as well as forest fires.

TITLE: Florida abortion ban takes effect; NYPD breaks up Columbia protests
SUMMARY: People in Florida no longer have access to abortion after six weeks of pregnancy. Police have cleared Hamilton Hall and the pro-Palestinian encampment at Columbia University.

TITLE: What is 'communal living' and is it right for me?
SUMMARY: People who've lived in co-ops, communes, group houses and 'intentional communities' share four questions you should ask yourself before taking the leap.

TITLE: After chronicling California at 'L.A. Times' for 43 years, Louis Sahagún has retired
SUMMARY: In his 43 years at the <em>L.A. Times

TITLE: Why is a 6-week abortion ban nearly a total ban? It's about how we date a pregnancy
SUMMARY: The time a person has to decide whether to have an abortion in Florida and other states with six-week abortion bans is at most two weeks. Why? It's has to do with how we date early pregnancy.

TITLE: Oh dear! Baby gear! Why are the manuals so unclear?
SUMMARY: Sure, new parents are an anxious lot. But instruction manuals for devices meant to keep the baby safe and healthy are daunting and add to the anxiety. Why are they so confusing?

TITLE: Majorie Taylor Greene is planning a vote next week to oust Speaker Johnson
SUMMARY: Rep. Marjorie Taylor Greene, R-Ga., says she will follow through on her threat to hold a vote to oust Speaker Mike Johnson sometime next week, despite signs that her effort will fail.

TITLE: Ford recalls Maverick pickups because tail lights can go dark, increasing crash risk
SUMMARY: Ford is recalling nearly 243,000 Maverick small pickup trucks in the U.S. because the tail lights may not illuminate. The recall covers certain pickups from the 2022 through 2024 model years.

TITLE: Biden forgives more than $6 billion in loans for 317,000 Art Institutes students
SUMMARY: President Biden announced the relief for attendees of the now-shuttered art schools, saying they "falsified data, knowingly misled students, and cheated borrowers into taking on mountains of debt."

TITLE: Violence erupts at UCLA as protests over Israel's war in Gaza escalate across the U.S.
SUMMARY: Members of pro-Palestinian and pro-Israel groups in Los Angeles sometimes tussled, with reports that protesters used fireworks and pepper spray. It was hours before police restored calm.

TITLE: Invasion Worries in Eastern Europe
SUMMARY: European countries that border Russia are concerned that they'll be invaded next if an emboldened Russia is successful in Ukraine, even though they're members of the NATO alliance. We go to the Baltic nation of Estonia and hear from people who are making preparations in case of invasion.

TITLE: Fed keeps interest rates at 23-year high
SUMMARY: The Federal Reserve held interest rates steady Wednesday, as inflation remained stubbornly above the Fed's 2% target. Investors now think it could be September or later before rates start to fall.

TITLE: Colombia will break relations with Israel over its actions in Gaza, Petro says
SUMMARY: President Gustavo Petro announced his country will break diplomatic ties with Israel Thursday over its actions in Gaza. "If Palestine dies, humanity dies, and we are not going to let it die," he said.

TITLE: Harvey Weinstein's New York trial, round two, is likely to move forward in the fall
SUMMARY: The New York State Court of Appeals overturned Weinstein's 2020 conviction last week, ruling that his trial was unfair.

TITLE: Duane Eddy, who put the twang in early rock guitar with 'Rebel Rouser', dies at age 86
SUMMARY: He was a pioneering guitar hero whose reverberating electric sound on instrumentals such as "Rebel Rouser" and "Peter Gunn" influenced George Harrison, Bruce Springsteen and countless other musicians.

TITLE: Hormones for menopause are safe, study finds. Here's what changed
SUMMARY: Women under 60 can benefit from hormone therapy to treat hot flashes and other symptoms of menopause. That's according to a new study, and is a departure from what women were told in the past.

TITLE: For weeks students have protested the war in Gaza — now things are escalating
SUMMARY:
From New York — to Illinois — to Los Angeles — encampments in support of Palestinians dot campuses across the country.

And over the last couple of days the tension has only increased as police have intervened on several campuses, including Columbia University, UCLA and the University of Texas. Hundreds of protestors have been arrested.

Pro-Palestinian protests on college campuses are growing in scope and intensity, and colleges are calling on law enforcement to help. Is it the right decision, and what happens next?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org

TITLE: Away from his New York trial, Donald Trump's campaign rallies are business as usual
SUMMARY: In Wisconsin and Michigan, Donald Trump largely avoided the hush money trial that has mostly sidelined his campaign efforts as he tried to woo voters with a familiar speech in two major swing states.

TITLE: The CDC says maternal mortality rates in the U.S. got better, after a pandemic spike
SUMMARY: The maternal mortality rate in the U.S. in 2022 – while still high – went back to where it was before deaths surged during the height of the COVID-19 pandemic, according to the latest CDC report.

TITLE: As abortion looks like a key issue in 2024, voters more divided by party than ever
SUMMARY: In a new report, Democrats are increasingly motivated by the issue of abortion - and increasingly supportive, as are independent voters. Republicans views have mostly remained the same.

TITLE: Colombia's president says ammunition has gone missing from 2 army bases
SUMMARY: Colombian President Gustavo Petro said Tuesday that hundreds of thousands of pieces of ammunition have gone missing from two military bases in the South American country.

TITLE: Newly elected prime minister in Solomon Islands is likely to keep close China ties
SUMMARY: Solomon Islands lawmakers elected former Foreign Minister Jeremiah Manele as prime minister Thursday in a development that suggests the South Pacific island nation will maintain close ties with China.

TITLE: Who will pay to replace Baltimore's Key Bridge? The legal battle has already begun
SUMMARY: Workers are still removing pieces of the Key Bridge from Baltimore Harbor, but the fight over who will pay to replace it has already begun. Past accidents offer some clues about how it could play out.

TITLE: Amazon, Target and other retailers pull weighted infant sleepwear over safety fears
SUMMARY: Federal regulators, medical experts and safe-sleep advocates have warned of the potential danger of weighted infant sleepwear, but manufacturers say their products have helped millions of families.

TITLE: House passes bill aimed to combat antisemitism amid college unrest
SUMMARY: House Speaker Mike Johnson met with a group of Jewish students at Columbia University who say they've experienced antisemitic speech and harassment from protesters on and off campus.

TITLE: Voters in this 'boomerang' county say they're nostalgic for the Trump economy
SUMMARY: Voters in Northampton County, Pa., say they remember having more money when Donald Trump was in office. But when it comes time to cast their ballots this year, other issues are at play too.

TITLE: After downsizing healthcare for years, Pentagon says medical readiness was a casualty
SUMMARY: Former combat surgeons warn it won't be easy to restore medical readiness to where it was during the last war, much less where is needs to be for the next one.

TITLE: Who is Keith Davidson, the lawyer who negotiated hush money payments from Trump?
SUMMARY: Attorney Keith Davidson, a key witness who represented Stormy Daniels and Karen McDougal, will go back on the stand Thursday morning to continue testifying against Trump in New York.

TITLE: College student explores rare mental health condition in award-winning podcast
SUMMARY: This year's winning entry is an emotional account of living with schizoaffective disorder, from a student at Miami Dade College.

TITLE: U.S. v. Google: As landmark 'monopoly power' trial closes, here's what to look for
SUMMARY: Is Google an illegal monopoly that's thwarted rivals to remain on top or is it simply a beloved search engine? Now it's up to the judge to decide.

TITLE: Police enter UCLA anti-war encampment; Arizona repeals Civil War-era abortion ban
SUMMARY: Law enforcement officers have moved into a pro-Palestinian encampment at UCLA. Arizona lawmakers voted to repeal a Civil War-era abortion ban.

TITLE: The U.S. may be missing human cases of bird flu, scientists say
SUMMARY: Officially, only one person has caught the illness during the current outbreak. But with limited testing, cases could be flying under the radar.

TITLE: After downsizing health care for years, Pentagon says medical readiness was a casualty
SUMMARY: Former combat surgeons warn it won't be easy to restore medical readiness to where it was during the last war, much less where is needs to be for the next one.

TITLE: Biden says he supports the right to protest but denounces 'chaos' and hate speech
SUMMARY: President Biden had an unexpected update to his schedule Thursday to address the pro-Palestinian protests roiling campuses across the country.

TITLE: Peloton is laying off workers and replacing the CEO — again
SUMMARY: It's déjà vu for the luxury fitness company: Peloton is cutting about 400 more jobs, and its CEO is stepping down just two years after a major shakeup.

TITLE: Why does TB have such a hold on the Inuit communities of the Canadian Arctic?
SUMMARY: Canada has one of the world's lowest rates of tuberculosis. Yet this deadly disease is surging among Indigenous people in this icy, remote part of the country.

TITLE: Whistleblower Joshua Dean, who raised concerns about Boeing jets, dies at 45
SUMMARY: Dean's family says he quickly fell into critical condition after being diagnosed with a MRSA bacterial infection. He is the second aviation whistleblower to die in the past three months.

TITLE: Why are so many government officials concerned about TikTok?
SUMMARY: Congress and President Biden say TikTok must shed its financial ties to China or face a ban in the U.S. But <em>Washington Post

TITLE: FTC bars former Pioneer CEO in Exxon Mobil deal, saying he colluded with OPEC
SUMMARY: Exxon Mobil's $60 billion deal to buy Pioneer Natural Resources received federal clearance, but former Pioneer CEO Scott Sheffield was barred from joining the new company's board of directors.

TITLE: What Does Winning Look Like for Ukraine Now?
SUMMARY: After months of delay in Congress, Ukraine is finally receiving the U.S. military aid it says is crucial in winning its fight against Russia. But after two years of war, what it means to win is increasingly complicated. We hear about the state of the conflict from our correspondent in Kyiv and our Pentagon correspondent.

TITLE: As Kenya's flood toll rises, Human Rights Watch says officials must step up efforts
SUMMARY: Human Rights Watch accuses Kenyan authorities of not responding adequately to ongoing floods that have killed more than 170 people since the start of the rainy season.

TITLE: Indiana will have its first competitive primary election in two decades
SUMMARY: Indiana has its first competitive primary for governor in two decades, as six Republicans vie for their party's nomination. Current Governor Eric Holcomb is term-limited after eight years in office.

TITLE: Captain sentenced to 4 years in fiery deaths of 34 aboard scuba boat in California
SUMMARY: The Sept. 2, 2019, blaze was the deadliest maritime disaster in recent U.S. history, and prompted changes to maritime regulations, congressional reform and several ongoing lawsuits.

TITLE: Turkey halts all trade with Israel over military actions in Gaza
SUMMARY: The government described the step as the "second phase" of measures against Israel, adding the steps would remain in force until Israel allows a "sufficient flow of humanitarian aid to Gaza."

TITLE: Apple shows its steepest quarterly decline in iPhone sales since pandemic's outset
SUMMARY: The 10% drop in year-over-year iPhone sales for the January-March period is latest sign of weakness in a product that generates most of Apple's revenue.

TITLE: Hobbyist photographer snaps photo of extremely rare bird in 1st U.S. sighting
SUMMARY: Michael Sanchez was testing out his new camera when he happened upon a feathered subject. The blue rock-thrush he photographed on the coast of northern Oregon last week has excited the birding world.

TITLE: Biden is giving the Medal of Freedom to a who's who of Democrats (and Katie Ledecky)
SUMMARY: President Biden is giving the nation's highest civilian honor to 19 people, a list that includes civil rights leaders, trailblazers and an unusually large contingent of high-profile Democrats.

TITLE: Black lawmakers reintroduce federal CROWN Act legislation to ban hair discrimination
SUMMARY: The bill which was previously passed in the House in 2019 and <a href="https://www.npr.org/2022/03/18/1087661765/house-votes-crown-act-discrimination-hair-style">2022

TITLE: After a boom in cash aid to tackle poverty, some states are now banning it
SUMMARY: Four states so far have passed laws prohibiting the use of public money for no-strings cash aid. Advocates for basic income say the backlash is being fueled by a conservative think tank.

TITLE: Bridge projects across U.S. offer clues to what may replace Baltimore's fallen span
SUMMARY: What a new bridge over Baltimore's Patapsco River will look like is still very much a matter of speculation. But one design stands out.

TITLE: Which celebrity feud escalated this week? Find out in the news quiz
SUMMARY: Where's the beef? What's the deal with marijuana? Why does this read like a '90s stand-up script? The answer to at least some of these questions can be found in the quiz. Were you paying attention?

TITLE: Launching an effective bird flu vaccine quickly could be tough, scientists warn
SUMMARY: Federal health officials say the U.S. has the building blocks to make a vaccine to protect humans from bird flu, if needed. But experts warn we're nowhere near prepared for another pandemic.

TITLE: Pregnant women in Missouri can't get divorced. Critics say it fuels domestic violence
SUMMARY: The state's law requires women seeking divorce to disclose whether they're pregnant — and state judges won't finalize divorces during a pregnancy. Texas and Arkansas have similar laws on the books.

TITLE: Siblings can share the darndest quirks — like picking up coins & keys with their toes
SUMMARY: Siblings — especially twins — sometimes share the strangest traits, like throwing a ball with their head or picking up keys and crayons with their toes. Researchers want to know whqt's up with that.

TITLE: How do you help patients who show up in the ER 100 times a year?
SUMMARY: For decades, nonprofits, health insurers and hospitals have been trying to solve the problem of the people who need the emergency room again and again. Here are some of the lessons they've learned.

TITLE: Google antitrust lawsuit closes; Steve Inskeep celebrates 20 years at Morning Edition
SUMMARY: Google's landmark antitrust lawsuit wraps today. Steve Inskeep celebrates 20 years as Morning Edition host. After a week of silence, Biden addresses the pro-Palestinian protests on college campuses.

TITLE: Have you seen this emotional support gator? Wally's owner says he's lost in Georgia
SUMMARY: Wally has many fans in Pennsylvania and across social media. His owner is enlisting their help, saying Wally was kidnapped, located by a trapper and released into a swamp while vacationing in Georgia.

TITLE: Katie Ledecky tells NPR about her plans for the Paris Olympics — and L.A. in 2028
SUMMARY: Katie Ledecky is used to getting medals, having earned 10 at the Olympics. But on Friday she received the Presidential Medal of Freedom, the highest award a civilian can get from the U.S. government.

TITLE: Campus protests over the war in Gaza have gone international
SUMMARY: Students in the U.K., France and Mexico have sought to erect what many of them call "solidarity encampments," prompting a variety of responses from university authorities and local law enforcement.

TITLE: Orangutan in the wild applied medicinal plant to heal its own injury, biologists say
SUMMARY: It is "the first known case of active wound treatment in a wild animal with a medical plant," biologist Isabelle Laumer told NPR. She says the orangutan, called Rakus, is now thriving.

TITLE: Scientists welcome new rules on marijuana, but research will still face obstacles
SUMMARY: When marijuana becomes a Schedule III instead of a Schedule I substance under federal rules, researchers will face fewer barriers to studying it. But there will still be some roadblocks for science.

TITLE: Israel Hamas War Protests Worldwide; Visiting a Donkey Festival in Colombia
SUMMARY: As protests over the Israel Hamas war roil college campuses across the U.S., similar protests are happening elsewhere in the world. We hear from some of them. And a quirky festival in Colombia celebrates the donkey.

TITLE: Senior UN official says northern Gaza is now in 'full-blown famine'
SUMMARY: Cindy McCain, the American director of the U.N. World Food Program, became the most prominent official so far to declare that trapped civilians in northern Gaza had gone over the brink into famine.

TITLE: Houston area braces for flooding to worsen following storms
SUMMARY: A flood watch remained in effect through Sunday afternoon as forecasters predicted additional rainfall Saturday night, bringing another 1 to 3 inches of water to the soaked region.

TITLE: Six months out from the election, Wisconsin students weigh voting for Biden
SUMMARY: Wisconsin's young voters — who have turned out in big numbers in recent elections — are key for either candidate to win the state. But Biden is facing some skepticism on the state's college campuses.

TITLE: A seafood bounty lures sea lions to S.F.'s Pier 39 in numbers not seen in 15 years
SUMMARY: It's a popular rest stop for sea lions, but the docks at the tourist hot spot these days are unusually packed out with the slippery residents. Conservationists are buoyed by the surge in visitors.

TITLE: After adopting its own Green New Deal, a college town sets a new target
SUMMARY: Ithaca, N.Y., will require that 50% of the money spent on its energy transition and on major infrastructure projects is directed toward those residents most at risk from climate change.

TITLE: When PTO stands for 'pretend time off': Doctors struggle to take real breaks
SUMMARY: What's a typical vacation activity for doctors? Work. A new study finds that most physicians do work on a typical day off. In this essay, a family doctor considers why that is and why it matters.

TITLE: Jerry Seinfeld and the fraught history of comedians and 'political correctness'
SUMMARY: Jerry Seinfeld has the become the latest in a string of public figures to blame "political correctness" for the death of comedy (among other societal ills). But what does the term actually refer to?

TITLE: Photos: Campus protests continue nationwide as some turned violent
SUMMARY: Photojournalists at NPR member stations documented  protests at college and university campuses nationwide this week.

TITLE: 'Dance Your Ph.D.' winner on science, art, and embracing his identity
SUMMARY: Weliton Menário Costa's award-winning music video showcases his research on kangaroo personality and behavior — and offers a celebration of human diversity, too.

TITLE: Some cities allow noncitizens to vote in local elections. Their turnout is quite low
SUMMARY: Some cities, like three in Vermont, allow non-U.S. citizens to vote in local elections. In these places, noncitizen turnout has remained low, as noncitizen voting remains a contentious national issue.

TITLE: She survived the 1970 Kent State shooting. Here's her message to student activists
SUMMARY: On May 4, 1970, the Ohio National Guard fired on Kent State students, killing four and wounding nine. A former student who now teaches there reflects on that day and offers lessons for protesters now.

TITLE: More than 16,000 pounds of ground beef sold at Walmart recalled over E. coli risk
SUMMARY: Cargill says that, out "of an abundance of caution," it is recalling several of its ground beef products produced in late April and sold at Walmart locations across the eastern U.S.
